text:
The audience of literature consists of listeners, readers, and viewers of poetic or prose works, whether in oral or written forms. The audience responds to the literary piece according to their aesthetic, emotional, and intellectual experiences and preferences; their need for entertainment; and their standards for moral satisfaction. These factors depend on the historical, cultural, and ethical milieu of the audience; thus one literary work may evoke varied responses from audiences of different circumstances, places, and times.

A literary work affects its audience by means of emotional, intellectual, and sensuous stimulation. The reactive function of the audience is either passive or participative. Reading a book is a relatively passive function. Responding to an epic bard’s chanting or singing by speaking words of encouragement, filling in gaps in the storytelling, dancing, singing in rituals, and the like are participative functions. Technology and tradition interplay in creating audience response. Technology could determine certain changes in the nature of audience response, as what happened with the introduction of the technologies of print and film. Tradition, however, maintains its influence on audiences in that they rely on established conventions and notions of literary forms and materials, and aesthetic and moral values in responding to a work of literature.

 

The Philippine audience of literature has undergone a series of transformations since precolonial times. Indigenous literature began with oral stories, songs, and riddles. This oral literature generally involved an “inter-creation” between the artist and the audience, as illustrated by the complex storytelling tradition of the Manobo, who have a rich oral literature. In the Manobo custom, the gathering of relatives for harvest is a typical occasion for storytelling. The performance usually begins at dusk, often lasting the whole night until dawn. At some point in the event, the storyteller volunteers, with nonverbal signals and in an indirect manner, to perform. The ritual opens with the ceremonial extinguishing of the candle, the better for the audience to imagine the story taking place right before their eyes, and to generate expectation and receptivity. The storyteller has to prepare process and method well, for the stamina required is prodigious. To ensure that audience interest does not flag, that listeners do not doze off midway into the all-night performance, the storyteller uses a whole array of vocal and linguistic devices. Viewpoints may shift from the omniscient to the third person, from the audience’s viewpoint (the second-person you) to the first-person plural (we). And then the storyteller may also use his/her own viewpoint, which may reveal his/her attitude. These are ways by which the storyteller arouses the audience’s feeling of moral satisfaction and amusement or sympathy for a character.

The storyteller uses linguistic devices such as shifting tenses, paraphrasing, and parallelism to indicate the peak points in the narrative. Changes of pace, which may be a shift from terse dialogue to an involved, dramatic dialogue, or a condensation of time at the appropriate points, may be used as well. To mark the denouement, the storyteller speeds up the pace, using rhetorical questions following one after the other.

All these methods are meant to elicit immediate audience response. These responses are abundant: the appearance of the hero provokes cheering, and the villain is roundly chided. Narrative flow is helped along when the audience interjects (“Hurry, think of something fast!”) or marks turning points (“Aha, take note of that.”). They themselves may formulate metaphors: “Perhaps the tinkling of the bells is like the humming of the bees!” The audience, as moral jurors, keeps up, commenting on the actions and decisions of the main characters: “Don’t ever agree to marry that man, Princess!” The storyteller may be encouraged by these verbal responses or may even be compelled to cut short a scene that the audience finds objectionable.

Thus, audience and storyteller are truly inter-creators. There is all the leeway for the individual performer’s creativity in fitting traditional material for a particular living audience. The storyteller, in effect, recreates literature alongside an actively participating audience—modifying, highlighting, adapting, adding, and omitting portions of the story in front of an audience that signifies their approval or disapproval. Later on, members of the audience themselves become the storytellers by orally transmitting the narrative. The story then is kept alive by means of oral recitation through generations.

Aside from the epic, other literary forms in the precolonial period were ballads, proverbs, and riddles. Many of these materials were derived from the epics, illustrating the genre’s centrality in the people’s lives. The preservation of these forms was largely oral through collective memory. Though a native syllabary existed and literacy was common, writing was used mainly for correspondence. Indigenous religion, governance, and literature were founded on oral tradition, which had been and would be sustained and developed over centuries.

Tribal lore served to foster equilibrium and balance, and to heal social fractures, weaving a close-knit consciousness of community. The communality of experience made for an audience that was uniformly familiar with the themes, situations, activities, and objects mentioned. There were no distinctions between young or old, men or women as audience; this unitary character made for one culture for all. The rules of the art form were universally known, easily enabling the audience to be critics. Moral judgment in these stories was bestowed by the community, and it was always the final, correct one.

The introduction of the printing press in 1593, during the early decades of the Spanish colonial regime, eventually led to the development of literature as a written form. Reading a written work, aside from or instead of listening to a spoken work, became a new literary experience for the audience.

The earliest books printed in the Philippines were religious texts, such as catechisms and spiritual guides, written by Spanish priests in the various Philippine languages. They were meant not for local audiences but for the foreign clergy to aid them in their mission of proselytization. In 1610, Tomas Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila (A Book for the Tagalog to Study the Spanish Language) appeared, which signaled a turning point for Philippine audiences and writers. It was the first published book written by a native. As its title indicates, Pinpin’s pioneering work was intended for a specific audience and for a specific purpose. It also suggests that there was an emerging print culture among the local audience in the early 17th century: that there was a native readership and a native market for books.

But apparently this print culture was slow to develop. Two decades after the Jesuits published the Visayan Doctrina Christiana (Christian Doctrine) in 1610, Fr Juan de Medina, in Historia de la Orden de S. Agustin de estas Islas Filipinas (History of the Augustinian Order in the Philippine Islands), 1630, ridiculed the idea of the indio (Christianized natives) buying a book or, if they did, of their overcoming their laziness to read it. By the 1650s, however, it seemed that reading was more common among the natives, or at least among those in Manila, whom Fr Domingo Fernandez Navarrete described as owners of religious books and whose “docility” was due to their fondness for reading these.

That early 17th-century audiences did not readily develop a reading habit had to do with the issue of access. On the one hand, books were expensive items at the time, not priced within the means of the general public. On the other, while many books were written in the various Philippine languages, they used the Roman alphabet, which was still alien to most natives, if they could read at all. But perhaps the more crucial issue was the dominance of oral tradition, and this persisted well into the 19th century, until the end of Spanish rule. In literature, print did not displace oral tradition; rather, both means of transmission coexisted. Some literary works were circulated in both print and oral forms, and this allowed the audience a more participative role, one that evoked the inter-creation dynamic between artist and audience of precolonial literature. This also made for a more transformative effect in the literary text itself and among the audience. The pasyon serves as a salient example in this respect.

The pasyon, a verse narrative of the Passion of Christ, is a written form. The original version was authored by Gaspar Aquino de Belen in Tagalog, published in 1703. So popular was this work that it saw multiple reprintings in the 18th and 19th centuries. It also inspired many other versions not only in Tagalog but also in various Philippine languages. The pasyon eventually came to be adapted for performance: read aloud or chanted as the pabasa during the Lenten season.

 
 

The most popular version of the pasyon was a text of anonymous authorship, first published in 1814, which came to be known as Pasyong Pilapil (The Passion by Pilapil) or Pasyong Genesis (The Passion of Genesis). While its common name attributes a certain authority to Fr Mariano Pilapil, one of the several priests who edited the original text, its authorship involved a collective effort among its audience. In the process of oral transmission, through innumerable copy transfers with varying degrees of faithfulness, through generations of performers’ innovations and adaptations, the Pasyong Pilapil came to reflect the popular consciousness that claimed it as its own. The audience effected subtle changes in its text even as Church authorities imposed orthodox doctrine from time to time. The fact that printed works had to seek an imprimatur gave the friars an amount of control over the written material, but this they did not or could not always wield effectively.

While pasyon works evolved through the years, as in the case of the Pasyong Pilapil, the form did have some measure of textual stability, given that it was written and printed. It was the pabasa that was the more fluid form, it being orally transmitted and open to the improvisations and interpretations of its performers as well as its audience. The pabasa involved a listening, not a reading, audience. It was not so bound to the accuracy of the text, for they did not have to be literate as the chanters or readers were.

The pabasa was traditionally held at the bisita, an ordinary structure put up to accommodate a large number of people. Food, celebration, and fiesta were very much integral components of the event. Liquor and fish were served to chanters, participants, and passersby alike. Truly a social as much as a religious occasion, the pabasa alarmed priests who railed against the drinking, courtship, and trysting that accompanied this religious ritual.

During the 18th and 19th centuries, a customary practice was to have the pasyon sung as part of the funeral ritual. A 1917 report describes how, in Batangas, pasyon stanzas were exchanged between harana (serenade) revelers and the dalaga (damsel) being courted. A related practice is the tapatan, which is a riddling contest, or a contest of wits, regarding pabasa text interpretation and character identification. The popularity of this activity is indicated by the practice of peasants simultaneously toiling in the fields and memorizing the pasyon excerpts to get the better of their tapatan rival.

Sung a cappella, pasyon chanting usually involves two groups responding antiphonally to each other, with several chanters ready to take up from where others leave off to take refreshments. One popular style of singing is the tagulaylay, which is a holdover from the precolonial style of chanting, characterized by extended trills.

Chanters, readers, and audience-participants usually take part in the ritual because of a panata (vow) of thanksgiving, petition, or devotion. The event is one of worship and edification. It also serves as entertainment, with the live chanting recalling traditional performances of the epic. For the audience, the pabasa is a continuation of the oral epic’s tradition of communal context. The pasyon story itself has taken on an epic quality, with Jesus as the mythic hero who undergoes various tests and triumphs in the end.

During the Spanish colonial period, the pasyon served as a channel for religious instruction. The series of aral (moral), which came at certain parts of the narration, drove home to the audience that people could not decree their own future and that they were constantly at death’s door. The faithful were urged to mistrust wealth, power, and praise, these being the things of this world which would not last. Since the only permanent reality was God, obedience to God unto death was the paramount principle (Javellana 1988).

Quite clearly, the pasyon and its aral served the ideological intent of Spanish colonialism to mold good colonials, with the presentation of ecclesiastical and civil authorities as God’s living representatives on Filipino earth. The aral would emphasize that enriching or even educating oneself was immoral. Yet the very same pasyon came to be a moral guide in ways that the colonial dispensation never intended. Jesus became a character alive for Filipinos. Dilemmas and decisions were aligned with the values of damayan (mutual aid) and the virtue of loob (inner strength). Moreover, what the audience internalized was Christ as unlettered, poor, and humble; the Pharisees and tagabayan (town or city people), who were His accusers, were of the learned, rich, and powerful class. In the end, through suffering, temptation, and death, it was Christ’s loob that prevailed over arrogance and power. Reynaldo Ileto, in Pasyon and Revolution, 1979, asserts that for the oppressed and exploited Filipinos, the pasyon bestowed a coherent meaning to the daily suffering and conflict that was their lot. It was loob that would win out in the end; liwanag (light, transcendence) was historically inevitable.

Providing a contrast to the pasyon, in terms of audience, participation, and effect, was the manual de urbanidad (conduct book), such as Modesto de Castro’s Pag Susulatan nang Dalauang Binibini na si Urbana at ni Feliza (Letters between Two Maidens Urbana and Feliza), 1864. It had a smaller audience because it required a more literate readership, which, in all likelihood, consisted predominantly of town dwellers with colonial aspirations. This epistolary exchange between two sisters—Urbana from a beaterio (religious house) in Manila, and Feliza from their hometown in Paombong, Bulacan—covers the code of conduct of the times concerning birth, death and courtship rituals, marital love, and the children’s upbringing. It is quite explicitly moralist and evokes a style of living elevated to a social art. Such topics as table manners, the proper attitude for games and play, rules in writing correspondence, and even etiquette for visiting, are dealt with in exacting detail. The author, through Urbana, advises the reader to refrain from rowdy behavior, swinging the feet, or crossing the legs. When their father dies, Urbana reminds Feliza that life is a pangingibang-bayan (exile), and death is a coming home to God, for human hardships are put to an end when the person is rescued from the suffering that is life.

In all these, the author stands as the sole judge of morality. Moral intentions, motivations, and attitudes are dissected minutely, reflecting a view of every person as inherently evil, deriving from the Catholic doctrine of the original sin. The audience’s role, meanwhile, is to be obediently responsive. The conduct book’s audience, consisting of the religious tagabayan who could afford books and learning, followed standards of eloquence and meaning determined by such religious materials as the sermon, ejemplo or didactic narrative, and lives of saints. These same materials are the source of the biblical examples, metaphors, and rhetorical devices used in Urbana at Feliza.

Place and character, however, come much nearer to audience than those in the pasyon. Paombong is a small rural town; the beaterio is in Manila. The situations of the small-town characters, their concerns and hopes, are sketched in recognizable outlines. Moreover, because both audience and author are united by a common religious practice and convention, there is a minimum of persuasiveness on the author’s part. We can assume that the audience easily reached a satisfying moral identification with Urbana and Feliza’s positive characters, even as they might not have been able to keep to its constrictions in real life.

Urbana at Feliza was read well into the first quarter of the 20th century. However, with the passing years, the audience’s moral identification with it weakened. The book was rooted on such assumptions as the moral leadership of the Church, the entrenchment of male authority and colonial state law, and the feudal context of individual freedom. All these assumptions eventually lost ground.

In the 19th century, as dissatisfaction with Spanish rule escalated, Filipino authors began to use literature for political ends. This added a new aspect to the relationship between the artist and audience. Given the strict censorship at the time, authors who were critical of the state or Church had to mask their statements and sentiments in acceptable forms and in figurative language. The audience, in turn, had to read deliberately for implied meanings and messages.

Such was the case with the metrical romance Florante at Laura by Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas, first published in 1838. It was an adventure-love story in the mold of traditional metrical romances; yet its subtle deviations from the conventions of the metrical romance allowed for alternative readings. Balagtas might have suggested this himself in his preface “Sa Babasa Nito” (To the Reader), in which he described the contents of the book as seemingly “green and immature” but its meat being savory to the discriminating reader. Thus the fantastic characters, plot, and settings of Florante at Laura have come to be read as allegorical. In the late 19th century, it was determined to be a depiction of the sufferings of the Filipino people under the oppressive Spanish colonial regime. This reading continues to be maintained and propagated to this day.

The propaganda movement—represented by persons like Marcelo H. del Pilar, Emilio Jacinto, and Andres Bonifacio—molded Tagalog into an infinitely more elastic and flexible expression of Philippine thought and feeling. Using as initial models the traditional awit and korido (terms for the metrical romance), the ejemplo, and even the sermon, they made the language bear the weight of extended satire, polemic, and political agitation. All these forms they used for an audience that they had to move not only to tears and laughter but also to armed revolution. The audience responded accordingly.

Late in the 19th century, print and oral culture worked together in the transmission of reformist and revolutionary literature. Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), which was published in Berlin in 1887, had a print run of 2,000 copies that reached only about a thousand readers in the Philippines. Yet it spawned much oral and written literature that carried various interpretations of its text. These did not differ too widely from the spirit and political intent of the book. Even as the Noli targeted a specific audience, composed of the Spanish-speaking ilustrado (educated native) and the liberal Spaniards, it refused to be contained; it reached a much wider audience that already was of a different class and language.

 

The literature of the Philippine Revolution—novel, essay, poetry, kundiman (love song), and drama—involved a more direct author-audience interaction despite class differences. The authors were mostly from the ilustrado class; they were educated, highly literate, and fluent in Spanish, whereas the mass audience spoke in their own local languages. Yet the political situation at the time and their common patriotic aspirations provided the necessity and direction for the interaction between them.

In the early 20th century, under the American administration, the introduction of English through the public education system and the conventions of writing in this language caused some changes once again among authors, the audience, and their relationship with one another. By the 1920s, there was a new elite in Philippine society: educated Filipinos fluent primarily in English, Western-oriented, and alienated from the native heritage. English became the medium of high literature that was meant for the elite audience, while the Philippine languages were used for low, popular material that catered to the masses. Eventually, another kind of audience emerged: the literary establishment made up of authors in English, editors, critics, teachers of literary history and criticism. It was they who presided over the development of taste and literary value.

Jose Garcia Villa’s poetry and other experimental works illustrate an aspect of the writing for the elite audience, particularly those steeped in Western expressionism, modern art, and avant-gardism. Villa’s avowal of “art for art’s sake” placed literature on a pedestal, beyond the reach of the mass audience. To appreciate his work, and that of other authors who subscribed to the dictum, one not only had to be literate but also specifically literate in English and in the Anglo-American literary tradition. This requirement limited the size of the audience. Countering this is Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s popular poem “Like the Molave,” 1940, which was often chosen by teachers for oral interpretation in schools. The traditional Spanish rhythms and the prosaic, declarative style of the poem were something a broad audience could easily relate to and appreciate.

The school of thought represented by Villa was not unchallenged. In fact, there was a great debate on it, with Salvador P. Lopez as the leading voice against Villa’s view of literature. In Literature and Society, 1940, which won at the Commonwealth Literary Contest, Lopez called for a literature that was socially and politically relevant. He advocated social consciousness in literature and the engagement of writers with their audience.

Meanwhile, oblivious of the debate, the mass audience carried on reading popular fare, mainly the fiction featured in the magazines published in various Philippine languages. The literary establishment found such material escapist, formulaic, melodramatic—in essence, unartistic. But it was what the general public could and chose to engage with. Magazines were bought because of the featured fiction, and magazines sold in massive numbers weekly throughout the country. After World War II, it was the komiks or comic book that became the mass audience’s favorite source of entertaining reading. The komiks featured illustrated short stories and serialized novels in every possible subgenre imaginable: from fantasy to love story, from historical drama to family saga, from detective and crime fiction to science fiction. All the komiks publications were in Tagalog; yet people from all over the country read them. The publications even served as an alternative source of language instruction for the non-Tagalog. The komiks were phenomenally popular, and their appeal lasted for decades. It was estimated that, in the 1980s, komiks were read every week by some 15-18 million Filipinos or around one-third of the Philippine population.

The popular magazines and the komiks encouraged reader participation by way of its letters-to-the-editor section. Letters could significantly determine the direction that Philippine literature would take. In the early 1950s, for instance, there was a brief attempt by magazine writers to experiment with local fiction by adding touches deriving from Western modernism. Coming from a background of James Joyce and Ernest Hemingway, many writers of this period deliberately tried to infuse angst and ennui in the native experience. However, although such stories were replete with details of local color, such as bagoong (fermented shrimp paste), tinapa (smoked fish), and tuba (coconut wine), the readers complained in their letters that the characters’ fictive experiences were alien to them. One reader lamented of one such story that it was “wa man gayuy lami” (quite dry). Another complained that the story bored him and gave him a headache, instead of exciting him. The editor of that magazine soon afterward decided to revive more of the stock adventure, sentimental, and detective stories.

The production of popular literature necessarily if not naturally involves making such concessions to the tastes and temperaments of the readers, not unlike how the storytellers of precolonial times modified their narratives to better appeal to their audience. To that same end, writers adjust elements in their works, be it in the development of the characters or the pace of the plot or even the conclusion itself. Some writers also take up writing in the popular forms of the day to reach a wider audience. In the early 20th century, for instance, journalists, poets, and writers of traditional literary forms shifted to writing novels, as the new genre was eagerly received by the mass audience and gaining a strong following among them. This was the case, too, with novelists who pursued writing for the komiks, such as Gregorio C. Coching and Clodualdo del Mundo, when the demand for the form was growing in the early 1950s. Later in the century, some komiks writers would likewise shift to writing Tagalog romance novels, which were the bestsellers of the day. Among them were Nerissa Cabral and Helen Meriz.

On the other hand, there were writers of social realist fiction, such as those now identified with the group called the “Agos sa Disyerto” and individual writers like Genoveva Edroza-Matute and Lualhati Bautista, who were writing for the audience of the mass-circulation Liwayway magazine. A heightened political consciousness caused a shift from English to the local language, Pilipino in particular, though the authors and their readers were based in the academe. Rolando S. Tinio, Jose F. Lacaba, and Gelacio Guillermo exemplified this shift.

During the martial law years (1972-81), the publishing of literary works was limited by the economic difficulties of the time and the censorship enforced by the Marcos dictatorship. It was radio that was the leading source nationwide of information and entertainment. Evidently, even in the 20th century, oral tradition continued to hold sway over the Philippine audience. This tradition, though, had evolved with the times with the use of modern technology.

After the EDSA Revolt of 1986, with the renewal of the freedom of the press and speech, and the revived nationalism and optimism among Filipinos, there was a burst of literary activity and an ensuing steady growth in publishing. In 1986, for instance, the total number of books published in the Philippines was at 804 titles. By 1995, this figure had risen to 1,229, of which 199 were literary titles. In literature, it was the genres of the essay and the novel that saw numerous new books produced by both established and up-and-coming authors. Significant as the growth in book publishing was, however, the total number of titles in 1995 is actually quite paltry considering that the population at that time was at around 70 million, and the literacy rate was at 94.5 percent. The reality was that the audience generally still preferred to listen to the radio and, more increasingly, watch television rather than read books or other printed matter. In stark contrast to 1,229 books published in 1995 is the number of television sets owned by Filipinos at the time, which was at 3.3 million units.

Electronic media not only challenged print publications in terms of being preferred by the audience, but it also changed written literature in itself as far as oral and visual elements were concerned. With their sensibilities transformed by television and film, the audience responded better to literary works that had an oral quality and a visual impact. This required literary writers to employ sharper and more dramatic devices in composing dialogue, describing place, and handling time. Writers knew well that electronic media had a wider reach than print both geographically and demographically. Thus some of them also wrote for television and film, aside from continuing to author works for print publication. Among those were Jose Dalisay Jr, who is primarily a fictionist but has also written screenplays for movies; Rene O. Villanueva, who wrote children’s literature but also authored scripts for television; and Lualhati Bautista, who writes fiction as well as movie and television scripts. Some writers shifted altogether to careers in film, such as Carlo J. Caparas who became a movie director, producer, and scriptwriter.

In more recent years, a new form of technology has been reshaping the communication landscape. Introduced in the Philippines in the 1990s and developing rapidly since, the Internet is changing the way literature is presented to and received by the audience. Online technology is allowing authors an immediacy in disseminating their works and a potential to reach a wider audience. Publishing online bypasses the constraints of deadlines and distribution, often lengthy and limited, involved in print publishing. Furthermore, blogs and social networking sites—with their capacity to generate feedback in the form of comments, likes, or posts—enable author and audience to interact and even inter-create in real time, as they once did in traditional oral literature. It might well be said that the Internet is democratizing contemporary literature by providing a medium for authors and audiences from all over the country to engage in the production and consumption of literature. This trend is thus decentralizing publishing, which has been traditionally concentrated in Metro Manila and undertaken by institutions connected with if not actually of the literary establishment. Or at least the Internet has the potential for such democratization. Access to online technology is still largely limited to urban areas and to the higher classes of society who have the educational background and economic means to use the technology. It is early days yet to determine the actual and lasting impact of the Internet on Philippine literature, but that it is transforming authors and audiences is inarguable.

Meanwhile, book publishing has stood its ground with the coming of the Internet. In fact, it has continued to grow, with 5,518 titles produced nationwide in 2007. Yet readership has been on the decline. Readership surveys conducted by the National Book Development Board reveal that the readership of books, newspapers, magazines, and comics among Filipino adults steadily declined from 94 percent in 2003, to 92 percent in 2007, to 88 percent in 2012. However, the 2012 survey also showed that people exposed to such stimuli as the television, malls, and the Internet were more likely to read non-schoolbooks than those who were not. Also, the surveys showed that more Filipino children were beginning to read at an earlier age: the figures of those who began reading non-schoolbooks at age six and below rose by 3 percent in 2003, 4 percent in 2007, and 9 percent in 2012.

 

The nature of readership today is changing according to the cultural, social, and technological circumstances of the times. But then transformation indeed marks the nature and history of the Philippine audience. Throughout the centuries, it has adapted and adjusted to its milieu; it has been affected by and has affected the literature that it calls its own.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo, updated by Patricia May Jurilla

The audience responds to the literary piece according to their aesthetic, emotional, and intellectual experiences and preferences; their need for entertainment; and their standards for moral satisfaction. These factors depend on the historical, cultural, and ethical milieu of the audience; thus one literary work may evoke varied responses from audiences of different circumstances, places, and times.

A literary work affects its audience by means of emotional, intellectual, and sensuous stimulation. The reactive function of the audience is either passive or participative. Reading a book is a relatively passive function. Responding to an epic bard’s chanting or singing by speaking words of encouragement, filling in gaps in the storytelling, dancing, singing in rituals, and the like are participative functions. Technology and tradition interplay in creating audience response. Technology could determine certain changes in the nature of audience response, as what happened with the introduction of the technologies of print and film. Tradition, however, maintains its influence on audiences in that they rely on established conventions and notions of literary forms and materials, and aesthetic and moral values in responding to a work of literature.

article.value: The Philippine audience of literature has undergone a series of transformations since precolonial times. Indigenous literature began with oral stories, songs, and riddles. This oral literature generally involved an “inter-creation” between the artist and the audience, as illustrated by the complex storytelling tradition of the Manobo, who have a rich oral literature. In the Manobo custom, the gathering of relatives for harvest is a typical occasion for storytelling. The performance usually begins at dusk, often lasting the whole night until dawn. At some point in the event, the storyteller volunteers, with nonverbal signals and in an indirect manner, to perform. The ritual opens with the ceremonial extinguishing of the candle, the better for the audience to imagine the story taking place right before their eyes, and to generate expectation and receptivity. The storyteller has to prepare process and method well, for the stamina required is prodigious. To ensure that audience interest does not flag, that listeners do not doze off midway into the all-night performance, the storyteller uses a whole array of vocal and linguistic devices. Viewpoints may shift from the omniscient to the third person, from the audience’s viewpoint (the second-person you) to the first-person plural (we). And then the storyteller may also use his/her own viewpoint, which may reveal his/her attitude. These are ways by which the storyteller arouses the audience’s feeling of moral satisfaction and amusement or sympathy for a character.

The storyteller uses linguistic devices such as shifting tenses, paraphrasing, and parallelism to indicate the peak points in the narrative. Changes of pace, which may be a shift from terse dialogue to an involved, dramatic dialogue, or a condensation of time at the appropriate points, may be used as well. To mark the denouement, the storyteller speeds up the pace, using rhetorical questions following one after the other.

All these methods are meant to elicit immediate audience response. These responses are abundant: the appearance of the hero provokes cheering, and the villain is roundly chided. Narrative flow is helped along when the audience interjects (“Hurry, think of something fast!”) or marks turning points (“Aha, take note of that.”). They themselves may formulate metaphors: “Perhaps the tinkling of the bells is like the humming of the bees!” The audience, as moral jurors, keeps up, commenting on the actions and decisions of the main characters: “Don’t ever agree to marry that man, Princess!” The storyteller may be encouraged by these verbal responses or may even be compelled to cut short a scene that the audience finds objectionable.

Thus, audience and storyteller are truly inter-creators. There is all the leeway for the individual performer’s creativity in fitting traditional material for a particular living audience. The storyteller, in effect, recreates literature alongside an actively participating audience—modifying, highlighting, adapting, adding, and omitting portions of the story in front of an audience that signifies their approval or disapproval. Later on, members of the audience themselves become the storytellers by orally transmitting the narrative. The story then is kept alive by means of oral recitation through generations.

Aside from the epic, other literary forms in the precolonial period were ballads, proverbs, and riddles. Many of these materials were derived from the epics, illustrating the genre’s centrality in the people’s lives. The preservation of these forms was largely oral through collective memory. Though a native syllabary existed and literacy was common, writing was used mainly for correspondence. Indigenous religion, governance, and literature were founded on oral tradition, which had been and would be sustained and developed over centuries.

Tribal lore served to foster equilibrium and balance, and to heal social fractures, weaving a close-knit consciousness of community. The communality of experience made for an audience that was uniformly familiar with the themes, situations, activities, and objects mentioned. There were no distinctions between young or old, men or women as audience; this unitary character made for one culture for all. The rules of the art form were universally known, easily enabling the audience to be critics. Moral judgment in these stories was bestowed by the community, and it was always the final, correct one.

The introduction of the printing press in 1593, during the early decades of the Spanish colonial regime, eventually led to the development of literature as a written form. Reading a written work, aside from or instead of listening to a spoken work, became a new literary experience for the audience.

The earliest books printed in the Philippines were religious texts, such as catechisms and spiritual guides, written by Spanish priests in the various Philippine languages. They were meant not for local audiences but for the foreign clergy to aid them in their mission of proselytization. In 1610, Tomas Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila (A Book for the Tagalog to Study the Spanish Language) appeared, which signaled a turning point for Philippine audiences and writers. It was the first published book written by a native. As its title indicates, Pinpin’s pioneering work was intended for a specific audience and for a specific purpose. It also suggests that there was an emerging print culture among the local audience in the early 17th century: that there was a native readership and a native market for books.

But apparently this print culture was slow to develop. Two decades after the Jesuits published the Visayan Doctrina Christiana (Christian Doctrine) in 1610, Fr Juan de Medina, in Historia de la Orden de S. Agustin de estas Islas Filipinas (History of the Augustinian Order in the Philippine Islands), 1630, ridiculed the idea of the indio (Christianized natives) buying a book or, if they did, of their overcoming their laziness to read it. By the 1650s, however, it seemed that reading was more common among the natives, or at least among those in Manila, whom Fr Domingo Fernandez Navarrete described as owners of religious books and whose “docility” was due to their fondness for reading these.

That early 17th-century audiences did not readily develop a reading habit had to do with the issue of access. On the one hand, books were expensive items at the time, not priced within the means of the general public. On the other, while many books were written in the various Philippine languages, they used the Roman alphabet, which was still alien to most natives, if they could read at all. But perhaps the more crucial issue was the dominance of oral tradition, and this persisted well into the 19th century, until the end of Spanish rule. In literature, print did not displace oral tradition; rather, both means of transmission coexisted. Some literary works were circulated in both print and oral forms, and this allowed the audience a more participative role, one that evoked the inter-creation dynamic between artist and audience of precolonial literature. This also made for a more transformative effect in the literary text itself and among the audience. The pasyon serves as a salient example in this respect.

The pasyon, a verse narrative of the Passion of Christ, is a written form. The original version was authored by Gaspar Aquino de Belen in Tagalog, published in 1703. So popular was this work that it saw multiple reprintings in the 18th and 19th centuries. It also inspired many other versions not only in Tagalog but also in various Philippine languages. The pasyon eventually came to be adapted for performance: read aloud or chanted as the pabasa during the Lenten season.

article.value: The most popular version of the pasyon was a text of anonymous authorship, first published in 1814, which came to be known as Pasyong Pilapil (The Passion by Pilapil) or Pasyong Genesis (The Passion of Genesis). While its common name attributes a certain authority to Fr Mariano Pilapil, one of the several priests who edited the original text, its authorship involved a collective effort among its audience. In the process of oral transmission, through innumerable copy transfers with varying degrees of faithfulness, through generations of performers’ innovations and adaptations, the Pasyong Pilapil came to reflect the popular consciousness that claimed it as its own. The audience effected subtle changes in its text even as Church authorities imposed orthodox doctrine from time to time. The fact that printed works had to seek an imprimatur gave the friars an amount of control over the written material, but this they did not or could not always wield effectively.

While pasyon works evolved through the years, as in the case of the Pasyong Pilapil, the form did have some measure of textual stability, given that it was written and printed. It was the pabasa that was the more fluid form, it being orally transmitted and open to the improvisations and interpretations of its performers as well as its audience. The pabasa involved a listening, not a reading, audience. It was not so bound to the accuracy of the text, for they did not have to be literate as the chanters or readers were.

The pabasa was traditionally held at the bisita, an ordinary structure put up to accommodate a large number of people. Food, celebration, and fiesta were very much integral components of the event. Liquor and fish were served to chanters, participants, and passersby alike. Truly a social as much as a religious occasion, the pabasa alarmed priests who railed against the drinking, courtship, and trysting that accompanied this religious ritual.

During the 18th and 19th centuries, a customary practice was to have the pasyon sung as part of the funeral ritual. A 1917 report describes how, in Batangas, pasyon stanzas were exchanged between harana (serenade) revelers and the dalaga (damsel) being courted. A related practice is the tapatan, which is a riddling contest, or a contest of wits, regarding pabasa text interpretation and character identification. The popularity of this activity is indicated by the practice of peasants simultaneously toiling in the fields and memorizing the pasyon excerpts to get the better of their tapatan rival.

Sung a cappella, pasyon chanting usually involves two groups responding antiphonally to each other, with several chanters ready to take up from where others leave off to take refreshments. One popular style of singing is the tagulaylay, which is a holdover from the precolonial style of chanting, characterized by extended trills.

Chanters, readers, and audience-participants usually take part in the ritual because of a panata (vow) of thanksgiving, petition, or devotion. The event is one of worship and edification. It also serves as entertainment, with the live chanting recalling traditional performances of the epic. For the audience, the pabasa is a continuation of the oral epic’s tradition of communal context. The pasyon story itself has taken on an epic quality, with Jesus as the mythic hero who undergoes various tests and triumphs in the end.

During the Spanish colonial period, the pasyon served as a channel for religious instruction. The series of aral (moral), which came at certain parts of the narration, drove home to the audience that people could not decree their own future and that they were constantly at death’s door. The faithful were urged to mistrust wealth, power, and praise, these being the things of this world which would not last. Since the only permanent reality was God, obedience to God unto death was the paramount principle (Javellana 1988).

Quite clearly, the pasyon and its aral served the ideological intent of Spanish colonialism to mold good colonials, with the presentation of ecclesiastical and civil authorities as God’s living representatives on Filipino earth. The aral would emphasize that enriching or even educating oneself was immoral. Yet the very same pasyon came to be a moral guide in ways that the colonial dispensation never intended. Jesus became a character alive for Filipinos. Dilemmas and decisions were aligned with the values of damayan (mutual aid) and the virtue of loob (inner strength). Moreover, what the audience internalized was Christ as unlettered, poor, and humble; the Pharisees and tagabayan (town or city people), who were His accusers, were of the learned, rich, and powerful class. In the end, through suffering, temptation, and death, it was Christ’s loob that prevailed over arrogance and power. Reynaldo Ileto, in Pasyon and Revolution, 1979, asserts that for the oppressed and exploited Filipinos, the pasyon bestowed a coherent meaning to the daily suffering and conflict that was their lot. It was loob that would win out in the end; liwanag (light, transcendence) was historically inevitable.

Providing a contrast to the pasyon, in terms of audience, participation, and effect, was the manual de urbanidad (conduct book), such as Modesto de Castro’s Pag Susulatan nang Dalauang Binibini na si Urbana at ni Feliza (Letters between Two Maidens Urbana and Feliza), 1864. It had a smaller audience because it required a more literate readership, which, in all likelihood, consisted predominantly of town dwellers with colonial aspirations. This epistolary exchange between two sisters—Urbana from a beaterio (religious house) in Manila, and Feliza from their hometown in Paombong, Bulacan—covers the code of conduct of the times concerning birth, death and courtship rituals, marital love, and the children’s upbringing. It is quite explicitly moralist and evokes a style of living elevated to a social art. Such topics as table manners, the proper attitude for games and play, rules in writing correspondence, and even etiquette for visiting, are dealt with in exacting detail. The author, through Urbana, advises the reader to refrain from rowdy behavior, swinging the feet, or crossing the legs. When their father dies, Urbana reminds Feliza that life is a pangingibang-bayan (exile), and death is a coming home to God, for human hardships are put to an end when the person is rescued from the suffering that is life.

In all these, the author stands as the sole judge of morality. Moral intentions, motivations, and attitudes are dissected minutely, reflecting a view of every person as inherently evil, deriving from the Catholic doctrine of the original sin. The audience’s role, meanwhile, is to be obediently responsive. The conduct book’s audience, consisting of the religious tagabayan who could afford books and learning, followed standards of eloquence and meaning determined by such religious materials as the sermon, ejemplo or didactic narrative, and lives of saints. These same materials are the source of the biblical examples, metaphors, and rhetorical devices used in Urbana at Feliza.

Place and character, however, come much nearer to audience than those in the pasyon. Paombong is a small rural town; the beaterio is in Manila. The situations of the small-town characters, their concerns and hopes, are sketched in recognizable outlines. Moreover, because both audience and author are united by a common religious practice and convention, there is a minimum of persuasiveness on the author’s part. We can assume that the audience easily reached a satisfying moral identification with Urbana and Feliza’s positive characters, even as they might not have been able to keep to its constrictions in real life.

Urbana at Feliza was read well into the first quarter of the 20th century. However, with the passing years, the audience’s moral identification with it weakened. The book was rooted on such assumptions as the moral leadership of the Church, the entrenchment of male authority and colonial state law, and the feudal context of individual freedom. All these assumptions eventually lost ground.

In the 19th century, as dissatisfaction with Spanish rule escalated, Filipino authors began to use literature for political ends. This added a new aspect to the relationship between the artist and audience. Given the strict censorship at the time, authors who were critical of the state or Church had to mask their statements and sentiments in acceptable forms and in figurative language. The audience, in turn, had to read deliberately for implied meanings and messages.

Such was the case with the metrical romance Florante at Laura by Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas, first published in 1838. It was an adventure-love story in the mold of traditional metrical romances; yet its subtle deviations from the conventions of the metrical romance allowed for alternative readings. Balagtas might have suggested this himself in his preface “Sa Babasa Nito” (To the Reader), in which he described the contents of the book as seemingly “green and immature” but its meat being savory to the discriminating reader. Thus the fantastic characters, plot, and settings of Florante at Laura have come to be read as allegorical. In the late 19th century, it was determined to be a depiction of the sufferings of the Filipino people under the oppressive Spanish colonial regime. This reading continues to be maintained and propagated to this day.

The propaganda movement—represented by persons like Marcelo H. del Pilar, Emilio Jacinto, and Andres Bonifacio—molded Tagalog into an infinitely more elastic and flexible expression of Philippine thought and feeling. Using as initial models the traditional awit and korido (terms for the metrical romance), the ejemplo, and even the sermon, they made the language bear the weight of extended satire, polemic, and political agitation. All these forms they used for an audience that they had to move not only to tears and laughter but also to armed revolution. The audience responded accordingly.

Late in the 19th century, print and oral culture worked together in the transmission of reformist and revolutionary literature. Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), which was published in Berlin in 1887, had a print run of 2,000 copies that reached only about a thousand readers in the Philippines. Yet it spawned much oral and written literature that carried various interpretations of its text. These did not differ too widely from the spirit and political intent of the book. Even as the Noli targeted a specific audience, composed of the Spanish-speaking ilustrado (educated native) and the liberal Spaniards, it refused to be contained; it reached a much wider audience that already was of a different class and language.

The literature of the Philippine Revolution—novel, essay, poetry, kundiman (love song), and drama—involved a more direct author-audience interaction despite class differences. The authors were mostly from the ilustrado class; they were educated, highly literate, and fluent in Spanish, whereas the mass audience spoke in their own local languages. Yet the political situation at the time and their common patriotic aspirations provided the necessity and direction for the interaction between them.

In the early 20th century, under the American administration, the introduction of English through the public education system and the conventions of writing in this language caused some changes once again among authors, the audience, and their relationship with one another. By the 1920s, there was a new elite in Philippine society: educated Filipinos fluent primarily in English, Western-oriented, and alienated from the native heritage. English became the medium of high literature that was meant for the elite audience, while the Philippine languages were used for low, popular material that catered to the masses. Eventually, another kind of audience emerged: the literary establishment made up of authors in English, editors, critics, teachers of literary history and criticism. It was they who presided over the development of taste and literary value.

Jose Garcia Villa’s poetry and other experimental works illustrate an aspect of the writing for the elite audience, particularly those steeped in Western expressionism, modern art, and avant-gardism. Villa’s avowal of “art for art’s sake” placed literature on a pedestal, beyond the reach of the mass audience. To appreciate his work, and that of other authors who subscribed to the dictum, one not only had to be literate but also specifically literate in English and in the Anglo-American literary tradition. This requirement limited the size of the audience. Countering this is Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s popular poem “Like the Molave,” 1940, which was often chosen by teachers for oral interpretation in schools. The traditional Spanish rhythms and the prosaic, declarative style of the poem were something a broad audience could easily relate to and appreciate.

The school of thought represented by Villa was not unchallenged. In fact, there was a great debate on it, with Salvador P. Lopez as the leading voice against Villa’s view of literature. In Literature and Society, 1940, which won at the Commonwealth Literary Contest, Lopez called for a literature that was socially and politically relevant. He advocated social consciousness in literature and the engagement of writers with their audience.

Meanwhile, oblivious of the debate, the mass audience carried on reading popular fare, mainly the fiction featured in the magazines published in various Philippine languages. The literary establishment found such material escapist, formulaic, melodramatic—in essence, unartistic. But it was what the general public could and chose to engage with. Magazines were bought because of the featured fiction, and magazines sold in massive numbers weekly throughout the country. After World War II, it was the komiks or comic book that became the mass audience’s favorite source of entertaining reading. The komiks featured illustrated short stories and serialized novels in every possible subgenre imaginable: from fantasy to love story, from historical drama to family saga, from detective and crime fiction to science fiction. All the komiks publications were in Tagalog; yet people from all over the country read them. The publications even served as an alternative source of language instruction for the non-Tagalog. The komiks were phenomenally popular, and their appeal lasted for decades. It was estimated that, in the 1980s, komiks were read every week by some 15-18 million Filipinos or around one-third of the Philippine population.

The popular magazines and the komiks encouraged reader participation by way of its letters-to-the-editor section. Letters could significantly determine the direction that Philippine literature would take. In the early 1950s, for instance, there was a brief attempt by magazine writers to experiment with local fiction by adding touches deriving from Western modernism. Coming from a background of James Joyce and Ernest Hemingway, many writers of this period deliberately tried to infuse angst and ennui in the native experience. However, although such stories were replete with details of local color, such as bagoong (fermented shrimp paste), tinapa (smoked fish), and tuba (coconut wine), the readers complained in their letters that the characters’ fictive experiences were alien to them. One reader lamented of one such story that it was “wa man gayuy lami” (quite dry). Another complained that the story bored him and gave him a headache, instead of exciting him. The editor of that magazine soon afterward decided to revive more of the stock adventure, sentimental, and detective stories.

The production of popular literature necessarily if not naturally involves making such concessions to the tastes and temperaments of the readers, not unlike how the storytellers of precolonial times modified their narratives to better appeal to their audience. To that same end, writers adjust elements in their works, be it in the development of the characters or the pace of the plot or even the conclusion itself. Some writers also take up writing in the popular forms of the day to reach a wider audience. In the early 20th century, for instance, journalists, poets, and writers of traditional literary forms shifted to writing novels, as the new genre was eagerly received by the mass audience and gaining a strong following among them. This was the case, too, with novelists who pursued writing for the komiks, such as Gregorio C. Coching and Clodualdo del Mundo, when the demand for the form was growing in the early 1950s. Later in the century, some komiks writers would likewise shift to writing Tagalog romance novels, which were the bestsellers of the day. Among them were Nerissa Cabral and Helen Meriz.

On the other hand, there were writers of social realist fiction, such as those now identified with the group called the “Agos sa Disyerto” and individual writers like Genoveva Edroza-Matute and Lualhati Bautista, who were writing for the audience of the mass-circulation Liwayway magazine. A heightened political consciousness caused a shift from English to the local language, Pilipino in particular, though the authors and their readers were based in the academe. Rolando S. Tinio, Jose F. Lacaba, and Gelacio Guillermo exemplified this shift.

During the martial law years (1972-81), the publishing of literary works was limited by the economic difficulties of the time and the censorship enforced by the Marcos dictatorship. It was radio that was the leading source nationwide of information and entertainment. Evidently, even in the 20th century, oral tradition continued to hold sway over the Philippine audience. This tradition, though, had evolved with the times with the use of modern technology.

After the EDSA Revolt of 1986, with the renewal of the freedom of the press and speech, and the revived nationalism and optimism among Filipinos, there was a burst of literary activity and an ensuing steady growth in publishing. In 1986, for instance, the total number of books published in the Philippines was at 804 titles. By 1995, this figure had risen to 1,229, of which 199 were literary titles. In literature, it was the genres of the essay and the novel that saw numerous new books produced by both established and up-and-coming authors. Significant as the growth in book publishing was, however, the total number of titles in 1995 is actually quite paltry considering that the population at that time was at around 70 million, and the literacy rate was at 94.5 percent. The reality was that the audience generally still preferred to listen to the radio and, more increasingly, watch television rather than read books or other printed matter. In stark contrast to 1,229 books published in 1995 is the number of television sets owned by Filipinos at the time, which was at 3.3 million units.

Electronic media not only challenged print publications in terms of being preferred by the audience, but it also changed written literature in itself as far as oral and visual elements were concerned. With their sensibilities transformed by television and film, the audience responded better to literary works that had an oral quality and a visual impact. This required literary writers to employ sharper and more dramatic devices in composing dialogue, describing place, and handling time. Writers knew well that electronic media had a wider reach than print both geographically and demographically. Thus some of them also wrote for television and film, aside from continuing to author works for print publication. Among those were Jose Dalisay Jr, who is primarily a fictionist but has also written screenplays for movies; Rene O. Villanueva, who wrote children’s literature but also authored scripts for television; and Lualhati Bautista, who writes fiction as well as movie and television scripts. Some writers shifted altogether to careers in film, such as Carlo J. Caparas who became a movie director, producer, and scriptwriter.

In more recent years, a new form of technology has been reshaping the communication landscape. Introduced in the Philippines in the 1990s and developing rapidly since, the Internet is changing the way literature is presented to and received by the audience. Online technology is allowing authors an immediacy in disseminating their works and a potential to reach a wider audience. Publishing online bypasses the constraints of deadlines and distribution, often lengthy and limited, involved in print publishing. Furthermore, blogs and social networking sites—with their capacity to generate feedback in the form of comments, likes, or posts—enable author and audience to interact and even inter-create in real time, as they once did in traditional oral literature. It might well be said that the Internet is democratizing contemporary literature by providing a medium for authors and audiences from all over the country to engage in the production and consumption of literature. This trend is thus decentralizing publishing, which has been traditionally concentrated in Metro Manila and undertaken by institutions connected with if not actually of the literary establishment. Or at least the Internet has the potential for such democratization. Access to online technology is still largely limited to urban areas and to the higher classes of society who have the educational background and economic means to use the technology. It is early days yet to determine the actual and lasting impact of the Internet on Philippine literature, but that it is transforming authors and audiences is inarguable.

Meanwhile, book publishing has stood its ground with the coming of the Internet. In fact, it has continued to grow, with 5,518 titles produced nationwide in 2007. Yet readership has been on the decline. Readership surveys conducted by the National Book Development Board reveal that the readership of books, newspapers, magazines, and comics among Filipino adults steadily declined from 94 percent in 2003, to 92 percent in 2007, to 88 percent in 2012. However, the 2012 survey also showed that people exposed to such stimuli as the television, malls, and the Internet were more likely to read non-schoolbooks than those who were not. Also, the surveys showed that more Filipino children were beginning to read at an earlier age: the figures of those who began reading non-schoolbooks at age six and below rose by 3 percent in 2003, 4 percent in 2007, and 9 percent in 2012.

The nature of readership today is changing according to the cultural, social, and technological circumstances of the times. But then transformation indeed marks the nature and history of the Philippine audience. Throughout the centuries, it has adapted and adjusted to its milieu; it has been affected by and has affected the literature that it calls its own.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo, updated by Patricia May Jurilla
