Sections

Critics’s Choices
State Awards
Magazine Contests
Government Cultural Institutions
Other Institutions
Writers’s Groups
Writers’s Organizations
Grants and Fellowships
Conclusion

 

Awards are financial or honorific prizes given to writers in recognition of an outstanding work or works, or for lifetime achievement in literature. Grants are cash subsidies given to individual writers to help them create more and better literary works, or the free use of venues given to writers’ organizations for meetings or workshops related to the writing of literature.

In the Philippines, where readership of literary works has remained small, the practice of bestowing literary prizes has been credited for the increase in production, the improvement of writers’ craft, and, in some cases, the revival of an entire tradition of writing. Contests can be “heaven-sent boons” for writers, offering not only recognition and acclaim but financial rewards that encourage literary production (Groyon 2001).

However, it has been noted that any institutionalized system of awards and grants is bound to be “contaminated by national politics, the formation of literary cliques … and the ideologies of the period” (Anderson 2013). In the Philippines, charges of patronage, cliquism, and parochialism remain common and persistent (Santiago 2012, 52-53). The impression that literary awards privilege friendships and personalities rather than merit became more pronounced and entrenched in the 1990s, as writers became inextricably tied to universities and institutions while becoming further isolated from the rest of society.

Even so, at their best, awards like those annually given by the Carlos Palanca Foundation and grants from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) help sustain writing activity in the country by rewarding quality work and financing worthwhile literary efforts, like workshops.

The first recorded literary contest in the Philippines was launched by the Liceo Artistico-Literario in 1879. It had two categories, one for peninsulares (Spaniards born in Spain) and insulares (Spaniards born in the Philippines), and another for mestizos and natives. The competition was for prose and poetry. “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth), a poem by then 18-year-old Jose Rizal, won first prize. He was awarded a silver quill. In 1880, according to his diploma, Rizal was again awarded the first prize for his play El Consejo de los Dioses (The Council of the Gods).

 

Critics’s Choices

One form of literary recognition was the critic’s list. One of the earliest is Jose Garcia Villa’s “honor roll” of what he thought were the best Filipino short stories written in English, which were then being published in magazines, such as the Philippines Free Press, and weekend supplements of newspapers such as the Philippines Herald and the Tribune. Villa began his annual selections in 1926, although the first of his lists to be published was that for 1927. Inclusion in Villa’s list was said to constitute an announcement of a writer’s “arrival” in Philippine literature.

A move to identify the best Tagalog short stories began in 1927 by Clodualdo del Mundo in his column Ang Tao sa Parolang Ginto (The Person in the Golden Lighthouse). In 1932, Alejandro G. Abadilla, in his column Mga Talaang Bughaw (Blue Lists), started his own lists of what he judged to be the best stories of the year.

 

State Awards

Both Villa and Abadilla championed aestheticism and the avant-garde. State-sponsored awards, in contrast, seem to operate on a different set of criteria. A counterpoint to Villa and Abadilla was the Commonwealth Literary Contests, aka Commonwealth Literary Awards, in 1940, which rewarded works that “deal with the social and economic problems of the individual and of society over and above those that are merely concerned with fantasy or mysticism or vain speculation” (Arguilla, Nedruda, and Agoncillo 1940, 128). According to the published rules, preferred were entries “with native characters, utilizing native settings, customs, traditions” (130). It was proposed by the Philippine Writers League, which was established in 1939 (Ordoñez 1989, 31). Then Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon, supposedly enticed by the idea of a literary competition “heralding the beginning of the project of nation” (Laurel 2003, 602), took up the suggestion.

Because of this nationalist rhetoric, the awards were swept by works that could be described as socially conscious in orientation and patriotic in theme. In the English division, the award for poetry was won by R. Zulueta da Costa for the collection “Like the Molave.” The title poem was inspired by a speech of Quezon’s, where he envisioned a people growing like the Philippine hardwood molave, “strong and resilient, rising on the hillside, unafraid of the raging flood, the lightning or the storm, confident of its own strength” (Ordoñez 1989, 25). Villa’s apolitical collection “Poems by Doveglion” won only an honorable mention.

Similarly, the top prize for the novel went to Juan C. Laya’s His Native Soil, whose theme is cultural conflict. Winning an honorable mention was N. V. M. Gonzalez’s “The Winds of April,” which offers a glimpse of how peddlers, immigrant workers, and homesteaders lived in the country’s hinterlands.

 

Manuel Arguilla’s How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife, 1940, won the prize for the short story. Portraits of the troubled social landscape of the time, some of Arguilla’s works went beyond depicting local color; his characters included peasant organizers moving among the grassroots and strikers in the city.

The award for the essay went to Salvador P. Lopez for Literature and Society, 1940. His essay “Proletarian Literature: A Definition,” a pioneering work in Philippine literary theory, helped spark the enduring debate on the social function of art and literature in Philippine society.

In the Tagalog division, none of the eight novels entered was awarded the top prize. Honorable mention was given to the following novelists: Lazaro Francisco for Singsing na Pangkasal (Wedding Ring), which was cited for its narrative style and for going beyond the melodramas of the period; Rosalia Aguinaldo for Kalayaan (Freedom); and Antonio Sempio for Nayong Manggagawa (Workers’ Village), which was a love story set amidst the harassment and eviction of the urban poor.

In the Spanish division, the winners were as follows: for the novel, Antonio M. Abad’s El Campeon (The Champion); for the essay, Abad’s “De la Hora Transeunte” (Of the Temporary Hour) and Pedro Aunario’s “Pugna de Lenguas” (The Battle of Languages); for poetry, Jesus Balmori’s Mi Casa de Nipa (My Nipa House); for the drama, Abad’s Dagohoy.

The works awarded “tried to distance themselves from the colonizer and seek a road independent of the United States” (Laurel 2003, 629). Their winning reflected the approval of the government in forwarding this gesture of independence. This similar dynamic would be seen again in the Centennial Literary Prize in 1998, to mark the centenary of the country’s independence from Spanish colonial rule.

The Philippine Commonwealth had earlier launched a national biography contest on Jose Rizal in 1938. Of the 12 entries submitted, only one was in Spanish, Biografia de Rizal (Biography of Rizal) by Rafael Palma, which won first prize.

After World War II, two other state-sponsored awards for literature were established. These awards, too, were tied to national goals. The Pro Patria Awards for Literature was given in 1961 on the centenary of Jose Rizal to honor those who promote and advance “national progress” and “love of country and civic citizenship responsibility” (Florentino 1963, 74). It consisted of presidential citations, given to N. V. M. Gonzalez, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, and Jose Garcia Villa, for their overall contributions, and a literary contest, in which Leopoldo Yabes and Ricaredo Demetillo won second and third prizes, respectively. No first prize was awarded.

The Republic Cultural Heritage Award was the “counterpart to the prewar Commonwealth Literary Awards” (Florentino 1963, 77). Whereas the drive behind the Commonwealth Literary Contests was independence, the Republic Cultural Heritage Awards was linked to economic development. The works awarded were N. V. M. Gonzalez’s The Bamboo Dancers, 1960; Nick Joaquin’s The Woman Who Had Two Navels, 1961; Jose Garcia Villa’s Poems 55, 1962; and Kerima Polotan’s The Hand of the Enemy, 1963.

Just a few months after the declaration of martial law, Pres Ferdinand Marcos signed Proclamation 1001 on 27 Apr 1972 creating the category of National Artist, the highest state award and decoration for an artist, first given to Fernando Amorsolo. On 15 May 1973, the proclamation was amended by Proclamation 1144 which provided for the creation of a National Artists Awards Committee mandated to draft the guidelines in choosing awardees and to administer the conferment of the awards. The signing of the second proclamation also declared two literary writers as National Artists: Amado V. Hernandez and Jose Garcia Villa. Hernandez and Villa were awarded with Francisca Reyes Aquino, Carlos V. Francisco, Antonio J. Molina, Juan F. Nakpil, and Guillermo E. Tolentino. On 19 Sep 2003, Executive Order 236, also known as Honors Code of the Philippines, gave additional distinction to the award by elevating it to a Cultural Order, which is among the highest honors of the Philippines equivalent to the Order of National Scientists and the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan. The Honors Code renamed the award as Orden ng mga Pambansang Alagad ng Sining (Order of National Artists).

By 2014, Malacañan had declared 13 National Artists for literature. Completing the list from 1973 to 2014 are Nicomedes “Nick” Marquez Joaquin, 1976; Carlos P. Romulo, 1982; Francisco Q. Arcellana, 1990; Nestor Vicente Madali “N. V. M.” Gonzalez, 1997; Edith L. Tiempo, 1999; F. Sionil Jose, 2001; Virgilio S. Almario, 2003; Alejandro R. Roces, 2003; Bienvenido Lumbera, 2006; Lazaro A. Francisco, 2009; and Cirilo F. Bautista, 2014. In 1997, Levi Celerio was declared National Artist for both music and literature, and Rolando S. Tinio, for both literature and theater.

 
 

The Centennial Literary Prize in 1998 was the only other award comparable to the scale, ambition, and state support of the Commonwealth Literary Contests more than 50 years earlier. Since the time of Quezon, there has not been “any single event in Philippine history … when the state has shown itself to be taking literature seriously” than with the launch of the contest by the National Centennial Commission (Laurel 2003, 602). Opened to all nationals from Southeast Asia, the contest offered generous prize money at one million pesos for the grand winner, and 750,000 pesos and 500,000 pesos for the second and third placers, respectively. The categories’ emphasis on length also echoed the ambition of the Commonwealth contest: novel (at least 250 pages), epic poetry (at least 1,000 lines), full-length drama in the sarsuwela genre (at least three acts), essay (at least 250 pages), and screenplay (at least 105 minutes running time).

The theme—“ideas and events of the 1896 Philippine Revolution”—also harkened back to the Commonwealth Literary Contests’ nationalist imperative, enacted at a momentous point in the country’s history. The three winners in the English novel, Eric Gamalinda’s My Sad Republic, Charlson Ong’s An Embarrassment of Riches, and Alfred A. Yuson’s Voyeurs and Savages, notably addressed the country’s colonial history in their respective constructs of the nation. These were published in 2000, 2000, and 1998, respectively.

 

Magazine Contests

Publication in a magazine may be said to constitute recognition in itself, but magazines such as the Philippines Free Press, Graphic, and Focus have also held literary contests, awarding the best pieces published on their pages. While the pieces published in the magazines might be generally influenced by the aesthetics of the incumbent literary editor and therefore those in contention for the prizes, a panel, usually made up of veteran writers, is constituted to determine the outcome of the contest.

The annual short story contest of the Philippines Free Press can be traced back to 1929, when it named Jose Garcia Villa’s “Mir-i-nisa” as the best short story of the year. It revived the annual short story competition in 1949, and until 1971, it drew entries from the country’s leading writers in English. Among the winners are “Guardia de Honor” by Nick Joaquin, 1949; “A Wind over the Earth” by Gregorio Brillantes, 1954; “The Day the Dancers Came” by Bienvenido Santos, 1960; “The Last Caucus” by Wilfrido Nolledo, 1963; “Serenade” by N. V. M. Gonzalez, 1964; “In the Convent” by Ninotchka Rosca, 1966; “Ark” by Resil Mojares, 1969; and “Segkopoulus” by Federico Licsi Espino Jr, 1971. The contest was revived in 1992 and was renamed Free Press Literary Awards. A poetry category was introduced in 1992, and an award for the essay, in 1993. Winners include Charlson Ong, Lina Espina-Moore, Ramon Bautista, Menchu Aquino-Sarmiento, and Rosario Cruz-Lucero for the short story; Ramon Sunico, Ruel de Vera, J. Neil Garcia, Luisa Igloria, John Labella, L. Lacambra Ypil, and Sid Gomez Hildawa for poetry; Arnold Azurin, Gemino Abad, Maria L. M. Fres-Felix, and Timothy Montes for the essay. Prior to the magazine’s folding in 2012, the Free Press Literary Awards had been widely sought-after, second only to the Palanca in prestige and unmatched for prize money.

During martial law, Focus was the only magazine publishing literary works. It attracted writers to its short story, poetry, and essay competitions, which ran from 1973 to 1983. Among the winners are Isagani Martin and Susan S. Lara for the short story; Benjamin Villalva and Rosario Cruz-Lucero for the essay; and Marjorie Evasco for poetry.

The Graphic’s first short story contest began in 1970. Resil Mojares won for “A Sickness in the Town,” 1970, and Federico Licsi Espino Jr for “Bituin sa Palasingsingan” (Star on the Ring Finger), 1971. The magazine was closed when martial law was declared in 1972, with its editors hauled to jail. Reformatted as the Philippines Graphic, the magazine revived the award in 1990. It was renamed the Nick Joaquin Literary Awards in 2004, the year of Joaquin’s death. Joaquin had been its literary editor. It began to name a “Poet of the Year” in 2013. The Philippines Graphic is the only venue that regularly publishes short stories and poems in English

In the 1960s, the Ilocano weekly magazine Bannawag sponsored an annual short story contest. The winning entries were put together in anthologies published by the Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilocano (GUMIL), the biggest organization of Ilocano writers, with chapters in Philippine communities abroad.

 

Government Cultural Institutions

Upon the suggestion of Abadilla, the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa or the Institute of National Language, now called the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, or the Commission on the Filipino Language, established an annual competition for poets in Tagalog in 1963. Two committees were formed: one to choose the board of judges and the other to organize the awards ceremonies. It was decided that the ceremonies be held on 2 Apr, or Balagtas Day.

The winning works were chosen from poems published in magazines and newspapers. The writer of the first-prize-winning poem was proclaimed Makata ng Taon or Poet of the Year.

The contest is known as the Talaang Ginto: Gawad Surian sa Tula. In 1984, however, the award was also called the Gantimpalang Collantes, in honor of Manuel Collantes, formerly of the Department of Foreign Affairs, who donated the prize money for the contest. In 2009, the Tamayo Foundation took over, and the award was renamed Gantimpalang Tamayo.

Among those who were conferred the title Makata ng Taon are Bienvenido Ramos, 1963; Federico Licsi Espino Jr, 1966; Rogelio Mangahas, 1969; Romulo Sandoval, 1975; Teo Antonio, 1976; Jesus Manuel Santiago, 1978; Lamberto Antonio, 1980; Virgilio S. Almario, 1984; Mike Bigornia, 1986; Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, 1989; Cirilo F. Bautista, 1993; Tomas Agulto, 1997 and 1999; Reynaldo Duque, 1998; Eugene Evasco, 2000; Jerry Gracio, 2005; and Reuel Aguila, 2008.

The Linangan ng mga Wika sa Pilipinas also instituted the Gawad Collantes for the essay. Intended to encourage the reflection on themes relevant to the development of Philippine language and literature, such as the works of Balagtas, the Philippine epics, and use of Filipino in the social sciences, the award has been given to Rosario Torres-Yu, 1979; Pedro Ricarte, 1988; Loline Antillon, 1989; and Joi Barrios, 1990.

Winners of the Talaang Ginto receive cash prizes, trophies, and certificates. Talaang Ginto sa Tula 1963-1969 (Golden List in Poetry 1963-1969), 1971, and Talaang Ginto sa Tula 1972-1979 (Golden List in Poetry 1972-1979), 1980, are two anthologies of the winning entries published by the Linangan ng mga Wika sa Pilipinas. Mga Sanaysay sa Alaala ni Lope K. Santos sa Kanyang Ika-100 Taon (Essays in Memory of Lope K. Santos on His Centennial), 1980, Panunuring Pampanitikan I (Literary Criticism I), 1984, Panunuring Pampanitikan II, 1988, and Gawad Surian sa Sanaysay: Gantimpalang Collantes 1989-1991 (Surian Award for the Essay: Collantes Prize 1989-1991), 1991, are four anthologies of Gawad Collantes-winning works.

In 1969, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) began sponsoring a playwriting contest in both English and Filipino. In 1973, a verse writing category was added. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino Jr for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Dr Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Orchard), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for “Doktrinang Anakpawis” (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The 1974 contest saw the addition of the following categories: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel won by Benjamin Pascual for Utos ng Hari (The King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age).

In 1979, a biography category was added. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980, in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize in 1984 when the award for the category was resumed for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith L. Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

 

In 1984, a new category was added, criticism. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP para sa Panitikan, and came under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The English category was dropped, and an all-Filipino rule was adopted. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamu-gamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly about Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP para sa Panitikan have been published in Ani, the Cultural Center’s literary journal, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP para sa Panitikan was revived in 2008 after being discontinued in 1990.

The Gawad CCP para sa Sining, which is the “highest award given by the CCP to Filipino artists and cultural workers” for a lifetime’s achievement, also awards writers (Alba 2004). First given in 1977, it was given yearly until 1994. It was revived 10 years later in 2004, and in 1996 became the Gawad CCP para sa Sining Pantanghalan to reflect the CCP’s “new thrust” as a center for the performing arts rather than a coordinating center for all arts. Awardees in literature fall under three categories—namely, writers or groups who have differentiated themselves in the art form, those who have made exceptional contributions to the culture of their regions, and cultural workers who helped spur and enrich art forms or Philippine culture in general. Over the years, awardees include N. V. M. Gonzalez, F. Sionil Jose, Rene O. Villanueva, Doreen Fernandez, and Gilda Cordero-Fernando.

 

Other Institutions

Literary awards have also been given by private entities, schools and universities, and organizations that are not necessarily directly linked to literature or publishing. In the 20th century, the earliest literary prize established was the Premio Zobel, instituted on 22 Jul 1920 to promote the study of the Spanish language and creative writing in Spanish on literature, science, and history. Established by Don Enrique Zobel de Ayala, the award is administered by the Academia Filipina. From 1985 until its expiration in 2001, it was sponsored by Ayala’s grandchildren Georgina and Alejandro Padilla y Zobel and, later, great-grandchild Diana MacCrohon y Padilla. In its 81-year existence, the award was only temporarily suspended from 1942 to 1951 and from 1967 to 1973.

The history of the Premio Zobel is recounted by Lourdes Brillantes in 80 Años del Premio Zobel (80 Years of the Premio Zobel), 2000, and its expanded English edition 81 Years of the Premio Zobel, 2006. The books feature biographical notes on the winners and excerpts from their works. At first, the Premio Zobel was a purely literary contest, writers being awarded for specific works. From 1975 on, however, it was awarded to Filipinos, whether writers, historians, teachers, publishers, or statesmen, for a lifetime’s work of contributing to or enhancing Filipino-Spanish culture. The awardees were given, aside from the cash prizes, a bronze medal with the founder’s image, and a certificate.

The Spanish Embassy launched in 1985 the Premio Manuel Bernabe to drum up interest in research and creative writing on Filipino-Spanish topics. Works in Spanish that won first prize were “Raices Hispanicas de la Cocina Filipina” (Hispanic Roots of the Filipino Cuisine), 1985, by Francisco Castillo; “Los Colonizadores de Filipinas ante los Ojos de Claro M. Recto y Manuel Bernabe” (The Colonizers of the Philippines before the Eyes of Claro M. Recto and Manuel Bernabe), 1990, by Edgardo Tiamson; and Filipinas a Cristobal Colon (The Philippines to Cristobal Colon), 1992, by E. Tiamson. The award no longer exists.

The most prestigious literary award at present is the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, established in 1950 and sponsored by the Carlos Palanca Foundation. This award is eagerly sought by writers, both veterans and newcomers, because it supposedly represents recognition of literary skill and merit by established writers and the critics or scholars who comprise the various panels of judges. Also, in view of the periodic dearth of publishing outlets for written works in this country, the cash awards provide an added incentive. It continues to enjoy increasing popularity, the number of entries submitted for competition increasing year after year. The short story and poetry categories attract the lion’s share of entries.

There were two divisions (English and Tagalog) and one category (short story) in 1950. The following categories were subsequently added to both divisions: the one-act play in 1954; poetry in 1963; the essay in 1979; the novel in 1980. More categories were introduced later: the children’s story in English and Tagalog in 1989; the teleplay in English and Tagalog in 1990; the screenplay in English and Tagalog in 1994; the Kabataan essay in English and Tagalog in 1998; futuristic fiction in English and Filipino in 2000; and poetry for children in English and Filipino in 2009. In 1997, Ilocano, Cebuano, and Hiligaynon divisions were introduced, but with each having only the short story category.

The competition in the novel category took place once every three years and, later, once every two years. The Palanca Hall of Fame was instituted in 1995. It is given to writers who have won five first prizes. The annual awarding ceremony is held on the first of September. Winners receive cash prizes and certificates.

Some of the winning works are the following: the short stories “Clay” by Juan T. Gatbonton and “Ang Kuwento ni Mabuti” (The Story of Mabuti) by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, 1951; the poetry collections A Stun of Jewels by Carlos Angeles and “Alamat ng Pasig” (Legend of Pasig) by Fernando B. Monleon, 1963; the essays “This City is in the Heart” by Anacleta Encarnacion and “Mga Talinhaga sa Panahon ng Krisis” (Metaphor in a Time of Crisis) by Virgilio S. Almario, 1979; the novels Silapulapu and the Zebut Brothers by Lemmie Suaco-Brillo and Gapo (Olongapo) by Lualhati Bautista, 1980; and the short stories for children “The Great Green Grove of Ato” by Gretchen B. Ira and “Pamana ng Bundok” (The Mountain’s Legacy) by Edgardo B. Maranan, 1989.

The Palanca has had a positive impact on the overall literary publishing landscape in the country. The awarded works are anthologized by the Carlos Palanca Foundation. Aside from this, more than 500 works that have won a Palanca have been published by academic and commercial presses. Specifically, its addition of the novel category in 1980 “had an effect on the production of novels (in Filipino and English) … [which] served as a new incentive for authors to produce full-length fiction (Jurilla 2011, 11, 15).

However, despite its stature, it is widely believed that winning the Palanca is rarely, if ever, based on merit alone (Palanca 2013, 86). Seen as a rite of passage for young writers, the awards are said to “exist in order to make writers,” not necessarily to recognize the best work submitted that year. This has mainly been attributed to the judging system, described as “flawed” and arbitrary, prone to the kind of literary patronage that the awards are themselves charged with cultivating, given the country’s small, tight-knit community of writers (87). Its limited and largely local importance has also been noted, as it carries very little weight outside the Philippines.

Even so, the Palanca continues to retain prestige even if other awards of comparable scope, like the Free Press Literary Awards and the Nick Joaquin Literary Awards, have handed out bigger monetary incentives.

The Southeast Asian Writers Award, or S.E.A. Write Award, was established in 1979 to give recognition to writers from ASEAN. Based in Thailand and organized by the Mandarin Oriental, Thai Airways International Public Co. Ltd, and the Italthai Group of Companies, it is presided over by the Thai royalty. Among the Filipino recipients of the award are Jolico Cuadra, 1979; Nick Joaquin, 1980; Gregorio Brillantes, 1981; Adrian Cristobal, 1982; Edilberto Tiempo, 1983; Virginia Moreno, 1984; Ricaredo Demetillo, 1985; Jose Ma. Sison, 1986; Bienvenido Santos, 1987; Virgilio S. Almario, 1988; Lina Espina Moore, 1989; Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, 1990; Ophelia Dimalanta, 1999; Cesar Ruiz Aquino, 2004; and Charlson Ong, 2012.

In the late 1980s, two institutions, the Amado V. Hernandez Resource Center (AVHRC) and the Gapas Foundation Inc (GPI), began sponsoring literary contests to encourage writing from the grassroots. The AVHRC is an institution devoted to workers’ issues, whereas the GPI is oriented toward the peasantry. The awards in their literary competitions are called Gawad Amado V. Hernandez and the Gantimpalang Ani, respectively.

The Gawad Amado V. Hernandez, named after the person who was both a literary figure and a working-class hero in his time, has two categories: one for manggagawa (workers) and the other for makamanggagawa (pro-worker writers), who are usually middle-class or urban Filipinos having worker sympathies. Works submitted are expected to reflect the problems and struggles, the demands and aspirations of the Filipino working class, expressed in poetry, short story, essay, and skit or short play.

The Gantimpalang Ani was initiated in 1987. Its aim is to encourage creative or imaginative writing among the peasants in the Philippine rural areas and also among the advocates working for peasant concerns. There are two categories: one for the magbubukid (peasant writers) and another for the makamagbubukid (pro-peasant writers). To encourage new writers to join, veterans who have won national literary or music awards are disqualified from competing. The genres in the Gantimpalang Ani are poetry, essay, short story, songwriting, and drama.

In the poetry category, first division, the earliest winners of the Gantimpalang Ani were Lorenzo Quilit Sr for “Bigkis ay Lakas at Iba Pang Tula” (Unity is Strength and Other Poems), first prize; Rolando Murillo for “Dalawang Tula” (Two Poems), second prize; and Gregorio Urian for “Kaming Magsasaka at Iba Pang Tula” (We Farmers and Other Poems), third prize. Winners in the second divison were Edgar Agunday for “Tanikala at Iba Pang Tula” (Chains and Other Poems), first prize; Rowena Festin for “Mga Talatang Hinango mula sa Pinitak at Pilapil” (Paragraphs Taken from the Canal and Dike), second prize; and Desiderio Mondelo for “Mga Tula ng Paggunita” (Poems of Reminiscences). Honorable mention went to Noel Dumlao for “Angil ng Gapas at Iba Pang Tula” (Growl of the Cutter and Other Poems), Rolendes Fabi for “Marami Pang Hahawanin, Ka Juan at Iba Pang Tula” (There Is More to Clear, Ka Juan and Other Poems), and Jimmuel Costelo Naval for “Limang Tula para sa Tumana” (Five Poems for the Highland).

There were no winners in the short story category, first division. The second division winners were Bernardo Bernardino for “Isang Mahal na Araw” (One Holiday), first prize; and Ruth Lopez for “Uha! Uha! Uha!,” second prize.

For the essay, first division, the prize was shared by Mario Marten for “Hindi Lahat ng Pangarap ay Kabiguan ang Hinaharap” (Not All Dreams Meet Disappointment), Annie Parro for “Dahil sa Pagkakaisa” (Because of Unity), and Jaime Triunfante for “Ang Pakikibaka ni Mang Simeon” (Mang Simeon’s Battles). The second division co-winners were Merla Ferreras for “Hindi pa rin Matubos ng Dugo, Luha at Pawis” (Blood, Tears, and Sweat Cannot Be Redeemed) and Bernadette Oblena for “Dugong Buhay” (Living Blood).

The prizes for song were given only to the second division writers. These were Fred Villareal and Fiel for “Butong Binhi” (Seed), first prize; Mon Ayco for “Habilin” (Things Entrusted), second prize; and Mon Ayco for “Nasaan Kayo?” (Where Are You?), third prize. Honorable mention went to Mon Ayco for “Maliliit na mga Langgam” (Tiny Ants), Mon Ayco for “Tayo nang Maglakbay” (Let’s Go and Travel), and Hilarion Gallaron, Rannie Reyes, and Felipe Rondina Jr. for “Hinukay na Lupa” (Excavated Earth). A prize for an organization or group was given to KADENA. Bigkis: Mga Piling Akda (Bound: Selected Works), 1994, collects the winning works from 1987 to 1991.

A one-time contest, sponsored by the University of the Philippines (UP), was the Gawad Likhaan: The UP Centennial Literary Prize in 2008, commemorating the centenary of the university and highlighting its contribution to Philippine letters. There were six categories: poetry, novel or short story, and essay in English and Filipino, and drama or film script in Filipino. The top prize per category was 200,000 pesos.

UP, through its Institute of Creative Writing, also annually hands out the Madrigal-Gonzalez Best First Book Award to books of first-time authors published within a two-year period. It alternates between English and Filipino works. The 50,000-peso prize money is provided by the Madrigal Gonzalez family. The institute also gave out the N. V. M. Gonzalez Short Story Award from 2000 to 2005. Works published within the preceding year were eligible, and the grand prize was awarded 50,000 pesos. Its first winner was Carmen Aquino Sarmiento’s Good Intentions 101: SY 72-73.

Outside Manila, competitions that gave out awards were started by organizations, schools, and other institutions that aim to reinvigorate writing in the regions. In some cases, they helped sustain what grants from the CCP and the NCCA started in the late 1980s. These include the following: in Bicol, the Premio Tomas Arejola; in Eastern Visayas, the NCCA-funded Eduardo Makabenta Sr. Poetry Contest of Leyte Normal University, the DYVL Siday Contest sponsored by a radio station, the Chito S. Roño Writing Contest in poetry, drama, and short story in Waray and Inabaknon, and the Premyo Casiano Trinchera for Waray poetry in UP Tacloban; in Western Visayas, the Padya Iyas Literary Prize for Hiligaynon; and in Mindanao, the Satur Apoyon Tigi sa Bubong Sugilanon and the annual Bathalad-Mindanao competition in balak (poetry), sugilanon (short story), and gumalaysay (essay).

 

Writers’s Groups

Book awards are given yearly by the Book Development Association of the Philippines (BDAP) and the Manila Critics Circle (MCC). The BDAP confers the Gintong Aklat award for outstanding published works in literature, criticism, and literary history. Among the winners are Kapampangan Literature: A Historical Survey and Anthology, 1981, by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Maganda Pa ang Daigdig (The World Be Lovely Still), 1982, by Lazaro Francisco; and Society in Theater, Theater in Society: Social History of a Cebuano Village 1840-1940, 1985, by Resil Mojares.

The National Book Awards, established in 1981 by the Manila Critics Circle, are given annually to the year’s outstanding authors and publishers. Winners of the National Book Awards in literature-related categories include Prison and Beyond, 1984, a book of poems by Jose Ma. Sison; Men of the East and Other Stories, 1990, by Charlson Ong; Herstory, 1990, by Rosario Cruz-Lucero; Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader), 1988, introduced, annotated, and translated by Rene Javellana,SJ; Man of Earth: An Anthology of Filipino Poetry and Verse from English, 1905 to the Mid-50’s, 1989, edited by Gemino Abad and Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Taga sa Bato: Mga Piling Tula 1973-1988 (Inscribed in Stone: Selected Poems 1973-1988), 1991, by Teo Antonio; and The Smile on Smokey Mountain and Other Poems, 1992, by Emmanuel Torres. In 1985, the MCC gave citations to the publishers of romance novels.

In 1998, the National Book Development Board (NBDB) began to administer the National Book Awards jointly with the Manila Critics Circle. Winners since then include Sunlight on Broken Stones: The Last in the Trilogy of Saint Lazarus, 1998, by Cirilo F. Bautista; the comic books The Mythology Class, 1999, and Trip to Tagaytay, 2000, both by Arnold Arre; Etsa-Puwera, 2000, by Jun Cruz Reyes; History and Society in the Novels of Ramon Muzones, 2001, by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava; The Sky over Dimas, 2003, by Vicente Garcia Groyon; Dark Hours, 2005, by Conchitina Cruz; Mga Gerilya sa Powell Street (The Guerrillas of Powell Street), 2007, by Benjamin Pimentel; and If I Write You This Poem, Will You Make It Fly, 2010, by Simeon Dumdum Jr. In 2012, a separate category for electronic books, or e-books, was opened for publications solely available in digital format.

 

Writers’s Organizations

In 1988, the Writers’ Union of the Philippines, aka Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas or UMPIL, initiated the Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas, an award for lifetime achievement in literature. This award is co-sponsored by the Balagtas Bicentennial Commission. The awardees are chosen through a nomination process involving other writers, writers’ organizations, and institutions. Recipients of the award receive a trophy called “Ang Manunulat,” designed and carved by Manuel Baldemor, a Filipino artist.

Among the awardees are the following: Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil for the essay in English, Francisco Arcellana for fiction in English, Liwayway Arceo for fiction in Filipino, Teo Baylen for poetry in Filipino, Genoveva Edroza-Matute for the short story in Filipino, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero for drama in Filipino, Ramon Muzones for fiction in Ilonggo, Godofredo S. Reyes for poetry in Ilocano, Edilberto Tiempo for fiction in English, and Edith L. Tiempo for poetry and fiction in English.

 
 

 

The Galian sa Arte at Tula or GAT, an organization composed of Tagalog poets, sponsors the Gawad Galian. Qualified to join in this poetry competition are participants in the organization’s poetry workshop called “Hasaan” (Whetstone) and writers who have not yet won in any national poetry competition. Among the winners of the Gawad Galian are Rofel Brion, Donato Mejia Alvarez, Danton Remoto, Luz B. Maranan, Ana Maria Gonzales, and Perfecto Caparas II.

Ilocano writers, institutions, and literary organizations have been among the most active in the field of literary competitions. In the mid-1970s, GUMIL solicited the help of Ilocano entrepreneurs, politicians, and overseas workers for the sponsorship of literary contests. GUMIL-Hawaii has been holding an annual short story and poetry writing contest, and publishes the winners in anthologies. It began giving the Pedro Bucaneg Award in 1978 to any male Ilocano writer who has made a significant contribution to Ilocano literature. The Governor Roquito Ablan Awards for Iloko Literature (GRAAFIL) are given yearly to winners of a poetry and short story competition. A private business organization, the Economy Tourist and Travel Inc, owned by Ilocano couple Mr and Mrs Rene Ragunton, began sponsoring an annual short story and poetry writing contest, adding the novel as a category in 1991. A group of Ilocano friends living in the United States pooled resources to sponsor a poetry writing contest for amateur writers. The winners are bestowed the Tumbaga-Galizia-Tadena Awards.

 

Grants and Fellowships

Writing grants were instituted in the late 1980s to encourage writers to finish works in progress, in their language of competence.

In 1961 and 1962, the Stonehill Fellowship for the Filipino Novel in English, administered by the Philippine Center of International PEN and funded by Harry Stonehill, awarded a cash prize for a novel or a novel in progress. The recipients were Nick Joaquin for The Woman Who Had Two Navels, 1961, and Kerima Polotan for The Hand of the Enemy, 1962.

In 1980, the Philippine Writers’ Foundation (PWF) chose 21 grant applications from a field of 131. The total amount involved was 149,000 pesos. The first recipients of the PWF writing grants include Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for The Birthing of Hannibal Valdez, novel, published in 1984; Nazario Bas for “Ang Nahanaw sa Kampilan” (Those Who Died by the Cutlass), novel; Bonifacio Ilagan for “Ang Kasaysayan bilang Kathang Isip” (History as Fiction), essay; Juanito Marcella for 10 short stories in Hiligaynon; Pedro Ricarte for “Limampung Maikling Tulang Liriko” (Fifty Short Lyric Poems); Agustin Pagusara for “The Filipino Soul,” essay; Reynaldo Duque for “Candon,” essay; Soledad Reyes for “Philippine Literature in Pilipino: Popular Not Elitist,” essay; Isagani R. Cruz for "Beyond Futility: The Filipino as Critic", essay; and Patricia Melendrez-Cruz for “The Concept of Society in Socially Conscious Stories 1958-1972,” essay.

As major grant-giving institutions, the CCP and, later, the NCCA became instrumental in boosting production and, in the regions outside Manila, reviving writing in the local languages. Starting with grants awarded to writers in Filipino and English, the CCP has expanded the program to writers from the regions writing in various Philippine languages, as well as those writing in Filipino, the developing and evolving national language that is still largely based on Filipino or Tagalog. The main objective has been to promote the development of regional literatures in Cebuano, Ilocano, Ilonggo, Karay-a, and in other languages, while not neglecting support and encouragement of writers in Filipino and English.

The grants are in several categories: poetry, short story, full-length play, and novel. Unlike the literary competition, however, the grants program requires only that the applicants initially submit the equivalent of one-third of the projected output: one-third of a novel, two essays out of five, six poems out of eighteen, two stories out of five, or one act from a three-act play. The applications are accompanied by a concept paper explaining the background, rationale, substance, and significance of the envisioned collection or single work.

Writers’ organizations have also benefited by way of venue grants, which enable them to hold workshops at the CCP’s National Arts Center on Mount Makiling. Grants such as these pave the way for the formation of literary organizations in the regions, which in turn published the work of their members and allow them to serve as models for young writers, a situation that attests to the multiplier effect of the grants. Fellowships in writing workshops are another form of grants. They typically cover board and lodging, a modest stipend, and transportation costs. Applicants, who are often young writers, submit samples of their works and fellowships are awarded competitively, based on the works’ promise. The University of the Philippines, Silliman University, Ateneo de Manila University, De La Salle University, and Mindanao State University annually host workshops, often with funding from the NCCA.

The NCCA also encourages the establishments of local arts councils and subsidized conferences and workshops. Other workshops that give out fellowships include the UP Visayas Summer Writers’ Workshop in the 1990s, the Cornelio F. Faigao Writers Workshop in Cebu, the Lamiraw Creative Writing Workshop in Samar and Leyte, the San Agustin Regional Writers Workshop (later renamed Fray Luis de Leon Creative Writing Workshop) in Iloilo, the Panagsugat All Visayas Creative Writing Workshop, the Cordillera Creative Writing Workshop in Baguio City, the Arejola Workshop in Camarines Norte, and the Davao Writers Workshop.

Other institutions that give out writing grants in the regions include the Dungog Kiniray-a Foundation and the Peter Solis Neri Foundation for Hiligaynon Literature and Arts.

For more senior writers, the UP Institute of Creative Writing, formerly the UP Creative Writing Center, awards national and regional fellowships who are chosen by a jury based on the quality and consistency of their works. They enjoy a one-year fellowship, which entails the honorific title of National or Regional Fellow and a monthly stipend. They are then required to make a public presentation of the work completed during their tenure. Fellowships are awarded in the following genres: poetry, essay, fiction, drama, and criticism.

The De La Salle University Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center also grants one-year fellowships to Lasallian faculty and staff who are completing works of fiction, poetry, and criticism. The school’s College of Liberal Arts also gives out mini-grants, the subject of which must be completed within a year from receipt of the grant.

In 2011, the NBDB began giving out grants worth 200,000 pesos from the “Filipino Authors’ Trust Fund,” set up in accordance with Republic Act 9521, envisioned to “promote the continuing development of book publishing industry in all regions.” Every year, the board identifies “topics” in which there is a dearth of published titles, under which proposals must fall. At the time of the application, the manuscript must be complete. On its first year, one of the categories was the English translation of a novel originally written in at least 25 percent of a regional language or a novel in English by an author from outside Metro Manila. It was won by Zamboanga-based novelist Antonio Enriquez for the manuscript of his novel The Siege of Fort Pilar.

 

Conclusion

Literary awards, grants, and fellowships have been useful in boosting the writing careers of many Filipino writers. The lack of outlets, the poor income from creative writing, and the relatively low priority given to literature and cultural production in an economically underdeveloped country are some of the reasons given for sustaining literary competitions and grant programs. But the most important reason for Filipino writers seems to be the need for recognition and acceptance of their works by society’s established writers, as well as by their own peers in the writing profession. This has been helpful to many writers. Still, a basic problem has persisted over the years: how to gain the acceptance and acclaim of the bigger audience (and jury) of readers among the people, who are after all the ultimate arbiters of the success or failure of the literary product.  Written by Joi Barrios, Rolando B. Tolentino, Edgardo Tiamson, and Edgardo Maranan, updated by Glenn Diaz, with notes from Angelo Lacuesta, Joel Toledo, Paolo Manalo, Charmaine Carreon, Eduardo Uy, and John Bengan

Conclusion

Awards are financial or honorific prizes given to writers in recognition of an outstanding work or works, or for lifetime achievement in literature. Grants are cash subsidies given to individual writers to help them create more and better literary works, or the free use of venues given to writers’ organizations for meetings or workshops related to the writing of literature.

In the Philippines, where readership of literary works has remained small, the practice of bestowing literary prizes has been credited for the increase in production, the improvement of writers’ craft, and, in some cases, the revival of an entire tradition of writing. Contests can be “heaven-sent boons” for writers, offering not only recognition and acclaim but financial rewards that encourage literary production (Groyon 2001).

However, it has been noted that any institutionalized system of awards and grants is bound to be “contaminated by national politics, the formation of literary cliques … and the ideologies of the period” (Anderson 2013). In the Philippines, charges of patronage, cliquism, and parochialism remain common and persistent (Santiago 2012, 52-53). The impression that literary awards privilege friendships and personalities rather than merit became more pronounced and entrenched in the 1990s, as writers became inextricably tied to universities and institutions while becoming further isolated from the rest of society.

Even so, at their best, awards like those annually given by the Carlos Palanca Foundation and grants from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) help sustain writing activity in the country by rewarding quality work and financing worthwhile literary efforts, like workshops.

The first recorded literary contest in the Philippines was launched by the Liceo Artistico-Literario in 1879. It had two categories, one for peninsulares (Spaniards born in Spain) and insulares (Spaniards born in the Philippines), and another for mestizos and natives. The competition was for prose and poetry. “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth), a poem by then 18-year-old Jose Rizal, won first prize. He was awarded a silver quill. In 1880, according to his diploma, Rizal was again awarded the first prize for his play El Consejo de los Dioses (The Council of the Gods).
Critics’s Choices

One form of literary recognition was the critic’s list. One of the earliest is Jose Garcia Villa’s “honor roll” of what he thought were the best Filipino short stories written in English, which were then being published in magazines, such as the Philippines Free Press, and weekend supplements of newspapers such as the Philippines Herald and the Tribune. Villa began his annual selections in 1926, although the first of his lists to be published was that for 1927. Inclusion in Villa’s list was said to constitute an announcement of a writer’s “arrival” in Philippine literature.

A move to identify the best Tagalog short stories began in 1927 by Clodualdo del Mundo in his column Ang Tao sa Parolang Ginto (The Person in the Golden Lighthouse). In 1932, Alejandro G. Abadilla, in his column Mga Talaang Bughaw (Blue Lists), started his own lists of what he judged to be the best stories of the year.
State Awards

Both Villa and Abadilla championed aestheticism and the avant-garde. State-sponsored awards, in contrast, seem to operate on a different set of criteria. A counterpoint to Villa and Abadilla was the Commonwealth Literary Contests, aka Commonwealth Literary Awards, in 1940, which rewarded works that “deal with the social and economic problems of the individual and of society over and above those that are merely concerned with fantasy or mysticism or vain speculation” (Arguilla, Nedruda, and Agoncillo 1940, 128). According to the published rules, preferred were entries “with native characters, utilizing native settings, customs, traditions” (130). It was proposed by the Philippine Writers League, which was established in 1939 (Ordoñez 1989, 31). Then Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon, supposedly enticed by the idea of a literary competition “heralding the beginning of the project of nation” (Laurel 2003, 602), took up the suggestion.

Because of this nationalist rhetoric, the awards were swept by works that could be described as socially conscious in orientation and patriotic in theme. In the English division, the award for poetry was won by R. Zulueta da Costa for the collection “Like the Molave.” The title poem was inspired by a speech of Quezon’s, where he envisioned a people growing like the Philippine hardwood molave, “strong and resilient, rising on the hillside, unafraid of the raging flood, the lightning or the storm, confident of its own strength” (Ordoñez 1989, 25). Villa’s apolitical collection “Poems by Doveglion” won only an honorable mention.

Similarly, the top prize for the novel went to Juan C. Laya’s His Native Soil, whose theme is cultural conflict. Winning an honorable mention was N. V. M. Gonzalez’s “The Winds of April,” which offers a glimpse of how peddlers, immigrant workers, and homesteaders lived in the country’s hinterlands.

article.value: Manuel Arguilla’s How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife, 1940, won the prize for the short story. Portraits of the troubled social landscape of the time, some of Arguilla’s works went beyond depicting local color; his characters included peasant organizers moving among the grassroots and strikers in the city.

The award for the essay went to Salvador P. Lopez for Literature and Society, 1940. His essay “Proletarian Literature: A Definition,” a pioneering work in Philippine literary theory, helped spark the enduring debate on the social function of art and literature in Philippine society.

In the Tagalog division, none of the eight novels entered was awarded the top prize. Honorable mention was given to the following novelists: Lazaro Francisco for Singsing na Pangkasal (Wedding Ring), which was cited for its narrative style and for going beyond the melodramas of the period; Rosalia Aguinaldo for Kalayaan (Freedom); and Antonio Sempio for Nayong Manggagawa (Workers’ Village), which was a love story set amidst the harassment and eviction of the urban poor.

In the Spanish division, the winners were as follows: for the novel, Antonio M. Abad’s El Campeon (The Champion); for the essay, Abad’s “De la Hora Transeunte” (Of the Temporary Hour) and Pedro Aunario’s “Pugna de Lenguas” (The Battle of Languages); for poetry, Jesus Balmori’s Mi Casa de Nipa (My Nipa House); for the drama, Abad’s Dagohoy.

The works awarded “tried to distance themselves from the colonizer and seek a road independent of the United States” (Laurel 2003, 629). Their winning reflected the approval of the government in forwarding this gesture of independence. This similar dynamic would be seen again in the Centennial Literary Prize in 1998, to mark the centenary of the country’s independence from Spanish colonial rule.

The Philippine Commonwealth had earlier launched a national biography contest on Jose Rizal in 1938. Of the 12 entries submitted, only one was in Spanish, Biografia de Rizal (Biography of Rizal) by Rafael Palma, which won first prize.

After World War II, two other state-sponsored awards for literature were established. These awards, too, were tied to national goals. The Pro Patria Awards for Literature was given in 1961 on the centenary of Jose Rizal to honor those who promote and advance “national progress” and “love of country and civic citizenship responsibility” (Florentino 1963, 74). It consisted of presidential citations, given to N. V. M. Gonzalez, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, and Jose Garcia Villa, for their overall contributions, and a literary contest, in which Leopoldo Yabes and Ricaredo Demetillo won second and third prizes, respectively. No first prize was awarded.

The Republic Cultural Heritage Award was the “counterpart to the prewar Commonwealth Literary Awards” (Florentino 1963, 77). Whereas the drive behind the Commonwealth Literary Contests was independence, the Republic Cultural Heritage Awards was linked to economic development. The works awarded were N. V. M. Gonzalez’s The Bamboo Dancers, 1960; Nick Joaquin’s The Woman Who Had Two Navels, 1961; Jose Garcia Villa’s Poems 55, 1962; and Kerima Polotan’s The Hand of the Enemy, 1963.

Just a few months after the declaration of martial law, Pres Ferdinand Marcos signed Proclamation 1001 on 27 Apr 1972 creating the category of National Artist, the highest state award and decoration for an artist, first given to Fernando Amorsolo. On 15 May 1973, the proclamation was amended by Proclamation 1144 which provided for the creation of a National Artists Awards Committee mandated to draft the guidelines in choosing awardees and to administer the conferment of the awards. The signing of the second proclamation also declared two literary writers as National Artists: Amado V. Hernandez and Jose Garcia Villa. Hernandez and Villa were awarded with Francisca Reyes Aquino, Carlos V. Francisco, Antonio J. Molina, Juan F. Nakpil, and Guillermo E. Tolentino. On 19 Sep 2003, Executive Order 236, also known as Honors Code of the Philippines, gave additional distinction to the award by elevating it to a Cultural Order, which is among the highest honors of the Philippines equivalent to the Order of National Scientists and the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan. The Honors Code renamed the award as Orden ng mga Pambansang Alagad ng Sining (Order of National Artists).

By 2014, Malacañan had declared 13 National Artists for literature. Completing the list from 1973 to 2014 are Nicomedes “Nick” Marquez Joaquin, 1976; Carlos P. Romulo, 1982; Francisco Q. Arcellana, 1990; Nestor Vicente Madali “N. V. M.” Gonzalez, 1997; Edith L. Tiempo, 1999; F. Sionil Jose, 2001; Virgilio S. Almario, 2003; Alejandro R. Roces, 2003; Bienvenido Lumbera, 2006; Lazaro A. Francisco, 2009; and Cirilo F. Bautista, 2014. In 1997, Levi Celerio was declared National Artist for both music and literature, and Rolando S. Tinio, for both literature and theater.

article.value: The Centennial Literary Prize in 1998 was the only other award comparable to the scale, ambition, and state support of the Commonwealth Literary Contests more than 50 years earlier. Since the time of Quezon, there has not been “any single event in Philippine history … when the state has shown itself to be taking literature seriously” than with the launch of the contest by the National Centennial Commission (Laurel 2003, 602). Opened to all nationals from Southeast Asia, the contest offered generous prize money at one million pesos for the grand winner, and 750,000 pesos and 500,000 pesos for the second and third placers, respectively. The categories’ emphasis on length also echoed the ambition of the Commonwealth contest: novel (at least 250 pages), epic poetry (at least 1,000 lines), full-length drama in the sarsuwela genre (at least three acts), essay (at least 250 pages), and screenplay (at least 105 minutes running time).

The theme—“ideas and events of the 1896 Philippine Revolution”—also harkened back to the Commonwealth Literary Contests’ nationalist imperative, enacted at a momentous point in the country’s history. The three winners in the English novel, Eric Gamalinda’s My Sad Republic, Charlson Ong’s An Embarrassment of Riches, and Alfred A. Yuson’s Voyeurs and Savages, notably addressed the country’s colonial history in their respective constructs of the nation. These were published in 2000, 2000, and 1998, respectively.
Magazine Contests

Publication in a magazine may be said to constitute recognition in itself, but magazines such as the Philippines Free Press, Graphic, and Focus have also held literary contests, awarding the best pieces published on their pages. While the pieces published in the magazines might be generally influenced by the aesthetics of the incumbent literary editor and therefore those in contention for the prizes, a panel, usually made up of veteran writers, is constituted to determine the outcome of the contest.

The annual short story contest of the Philippines Free Press can be traced back to 1929, when it named Jose Garcia Villa’s “Mir-i-nisa” as the best short story of the year. It revived the annual short story competition in 1949, and until 1971, it drew entries from the country’s leading writers in English. Among the winners are “Guardia de Honor” by Nick Joaquin, 1949; “A Wind over the Earth” by Gregorio Brillantes, 1954; “The Day the Dancers Came” by Bienvenido Santos, 1960; “The Last Caucus” by Wilfrido Nolledo, 1963; “Serenade” by N. V. M. Gonzalez, 1964; “In the Convent” by Ninotchka Rosca, 1966; “Ark” by Resil Mojares, 1969; and “Segkopoulus” by Federico Licsi Espino Jr, 1971. The contest was revived in 1992 and was renamed Free Press Literary Awards. A poetry category was introduced in 1992, and an award for the essay, in 1993. Winners include Charlson Ong, Lina Espina-Moore, Ramon Bautista, Menchu Aquino-Sarmiento, and Rosario Cruz-Lucero for the short story; Ramon Sunico, Ruel de Vera, J. Neil Garcia, Luisa Igloria, John Labella, L. Lacambra Ypil, and Sid Gomez Hildawa for poetry; Arnold Azurin, Gemino Abad, Maria L. M. Fres-Felix, and Timothy Montes for the essay. Prior to the magazine’s folding in 2012, the Free Press Literary Awards had been widely sought-after, second only to the Palanca in prestige and unmatched for prize money.

During martial law, Focus was the only magazine publishing literary works. It attracted writers to its short story, poetry, and essay competitions, which ran from 1973 to 1983. Among the winners are Isagani Martin and Susan S. Lara for the short story; Benjamin Villalva and Rosario Cruz-Lucero for the essay; and Marjorie Evasco for poetry.

The Graphic’s first short story contest began in 1970. Resil Mojares won for “A Sickness in the Town,” 1970, and Federico Licsi Espino Jr for “Bituin sa Palasingsingan” (Star on the Ring Finger), 1971. The magazine was closed when martial law was declared in 1972, with its editors hauled to jail. Reformatted as the Philippines Graphic, the magazine revived the award in 1990. It was renamed the Nick Joaquin Literary Awards in 2004, the year of Joaquin’s death. Joaquin had been its literary editor. It began to name a “Poet of the Year” in 2013. The Philippines Graphic is the only venue that regularly publishes short stories and poems in English

In the 1960s, the Ilocano weekly magazine Bannawag sponsored an annual short story contest. The winning entries were put together in anthologies published by the Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilocano (GUMIL), the biggest organization of Ilocano writers, with chapters in Philippine communities abroad.
Government Cultural Institutions

Upon the suggestion of Abadilla, the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa or the Institute of National Language, now called the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, or the Commission on the Filipino Language, established an annual competition for poets in Tagalog in 1963. Two committees were formed: one to choose the board of judges and the other to organize the awards ceremonies. It was decided that the ceremonies be held on 2 Apr, or Balagtas Day.
The winning works were chosen from poems published in magazines and newspapers. The writer of the first-prize-winning poem was proclaimed Makata ng Taon or Poet of the Year.

The contest is known as the Talaang Ginto: Gawad Surian sa Tula. In 1984, however, the award was also called the Gantimpalang Collantes, in honor of Manuel Collantes, formerly of the Department of Foreign Affairs, who donated the prize money for the contest. In 2009, the Tamayo Foundation took over, and the award was renamed Gantimpalang Tamayo.

Among those who were conferred the title Makata ng Taon are Bienvenido Ramos, 1963; Federico Licsi Espino Jr, 1966; Rogelio Mangahas, 1969; Romulo Sandoval, 1975; Teo Antonio, 1976; Jesus Manuel Santiago, 1978; Lamberto Antonio, 1980; Virgilio S. Almario, 1984; Mike Bigornia, 1986; Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, 1989; Cirilo F. Bautista, 1993; Tomas Agulto, 1997 and 1999; Reynaldo Duque, 1998; Eugene Evasco, 2000; Jerry Gracio, 2005; and Reuel Aguila, 2008.

The Linangan ng mga Wika sa Pilipinas also instituted the Gawad Collantes for the essay. Intended to encourage the reflection on themes relevant to the development of Philippine language and literature, such as the works of Balagtas, the Philippine epics, and use of Filipino in the social sciences, the award has been given to Rosario Torres-Yu, 1979; Pedro Ricarte, 1988; Loline Antillon, 1989; and Joi Barrios, 1990.

Winners of the Talaang Ginto receive cash prizes, trophies, and certificates. Talaang Ginto sa Tula 1963-1969 (Golden List in Poetry 1963-1969), 1971, and Talaang Ginto sa Tula 1972-1979 (Golden List in Poetry 1972-1979), 1980, are two anthologies of the winning entries published by the Linangan ng mga Wika sa Pilipinas. Mga Sanaysay sa Alaala ni Lope K. Santos sa Kanyang Ika-100 Taon (Essays in Memory of Lope K. Santos on His Centennial), 1980, Panunuring Pampanitikan I (Literary Criticism I), 1984, Panunuring Pampanitikan II, 1988, and Gawad Surian sa Sanaysay: Gantimpalang Collantes 1989-1991 (Surian Award for the Essay: Collantes Prize 1989-1991), 1991, are four anthologies of Gawad Collantes-winning works.

In 1969, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) began sponsoring a playwriting contest in both English and Filipino. In 1973, a verse writing category was added. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino Jr for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Dr Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Orchard), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for “Doktrinang Anakpawis” (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The 1974 contest saw the addition of the following categories: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel won by Benjamin Pascual for Utos ng Hari (The King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age).

In 1979, a biography category was added. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980, in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize in 1984 when the award for the category was resumed for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith L. Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).
