The intellectual ferment that was brewing in Europe and the United States in literary theory started to shape the terms of engagement in the Philippines in the mid-1980s. It was a time for learning what semiotics, structuralism, poststructuralism, modernism, and postmodernism, feminism, reception theory, and other conceptual systems were all about. This uncertainty was reflected in the articles written during this period where the Filipino writers still found themselves grappling with the complex ideas of Anglo-American and European scholars as Jacques Lacan, Jacques Derrida, Terry Eagleton, Julia Kristeva, Helene Cixous, Fredric Jameson, Pierre Macherey, Raymond Williams, Michel Foucault, Paul de Man, and other Western leading lights of new theory.

 

Since EDSA (1986 Onward)

The fall of the Marcos dictatorship led to a resurgence in publishing on all fronts. At the same time, with the opening up of the public sphere, the academe, the primary locus of critical and scholarly production in the country, found itself reorienting in new ways to society, the state, and to global market forces.

The Marxist tradition in Philippine criticism was most affected by these changing developments. Ironically, the collapse of the dictatorship and the growth of the public sphere simultaneously opened up more avenues for the publication of critical studies, while simultaneously de-emphasizing the need for such (social) criticism at all. This would further be compounded by what was seen by many as the global “collapse” of the Left. Internationally, this was rooted in the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991. Locally, this was seen in the re-criminalization of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) under the Aquino administration, and the subsequent internal purges and eventual spilt of the CPP itself in the latter half of the 1980s and during the early 1990s.

This period also witnessed the increasing liberalization of the Philippine economy, especially during a string of deregularization and privatization policies under Pres Fidel V. Ramos. This push to make the Philippine economy compatible with policies of the international community—as advocated by bodies like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Trade Organization—was itself reflected in the steady integration of the Philippine academe into global academic economies, primarily, though far from only, in the Western world and in East and Southeast Asia. The resulting integration led to greater exposure to new critical theories in the mid-1980s and 1990s, like feminism, poststructuralism, and postcolonialism, which led to an explosion of critical and scholarly production in the Philippines. It also led to greater influences from new methodologies like cultural studies, which have broadened the horizon of acceptable objects of study from literary texts to the living text of the entire culture.

Meanwhile, increased participation in both local and international conferences has facilitated closer and more heated conversations between Filipinos and academics abroad. Owing in part to the increasing supply of available grants and scholarships, more and more Filipinos academics have been able to study in universities abroad and have often afterward chosen to settle there.

Important campus-based journals include Likhaan, Humanities Diliman, and the Diliman Review, UP Diliman; Kritika Kultura and Philippine Studies, Ateneo de Manila University; Dagmay, UP Mindanao; Mindanao Journal, Mindanao State University; Tambara, Ateneo de Davao University; and Kinaadman, Xavier University. These provide space for criticism. However, the standardization of international policies within the academe, such as in the strengthening of “publish or perish,” has changed the way in which critical and scholarly work is being published in journals and university and commercial presses. Internationalization has led to a greater call for journals and publications that meet “international standards.” This manifests most explicitly in the attempt of Philippine journals to gain certification from the Institute for Scientific Information, as well as the high demand among academicians to be published in said journals. While this ostensibly allows for greater recognition and interaction with international communities, the uncritical adoption of these academic trends has a number of problematic effects, including the privileging of English language texts, and the risk of subsuming Philippine intellectual production into the markets of Anglo-American academic publishing (Guillermo 2013, 508).

Another development affecting the production of criticism in the Philippines is the rise of the World Wide Web. The Internet has made the circulation of knowledge cheaper, faster, and wider and has become an avenue for international cooperation and coordination among scholars. Many journals are uploaded online, and some like Kritika Kultura are available exclusively online.

Significant as they are, of course, the international cooperation of diasporic critics is but a symptom of a greater phenomenon. In spite of the push for internationalization, as well as the continued deprioritizing of the humanities, one of the effects of these various trends has been the strengthening of a sense of a community of Filipino critics working within a tradition of Philippine criticism and scholarship. In recent years, this affect has been institutionalized in the creation of criticism workshops, such as the UST J. Elizalde Navarro Workshop in Criticism, the IYAS criticism workshop, and the Kritika Kultura Criticism Workshop. Like the creative writing workshops on which they are based, the aim of these criticism workshops is networking and mentoring. The workshops attempt to consolidate a Philippine critical community along both vertical (intergenerational) and horizontal (intra-generational) axes.

There has never been more diversity in Philippine criticism and scholarship. This is best seen perhaps in the various attempts at construing a “national” canon, as well as the numerous reactions to it. The most common conflict in this debate concerns the categorization of “national” and “regional.” The realization in the 1970s of the need to focus on regions apart from Manila has led to the slow but increasing support for regional literatures. This has led in turn to problematizing the place of regional traditions vis-à-vis the “national.” In “Harnessing Regional Literature for National Literature,” Bienvenido Lumbera defines national literature as a body of work that invokes and projects the imagined community of the Filipino nation. He points out, however, that the traditional classification of national literature has been filtered through both class as well as language, with “regional” literature being comprised of the tradition written in the local languages, and “national” literature being written in Spanish, English, and Tagalog. Both filters were a product of an elite and colonial educational system, with the mistaken belief that what they had construed as “national” was superior to everything else. In the end, however, Lumbera maintains the categories of “regional” and “national,” by which he means works that are focused on narrower local settings versus works that grapple with bigger perspectives of nationhood. He charges that more works from the regions need to be translated into Filipino so as to be able to find which of them belong to “national” literature, so as to have a more representative example of the concept of the Philippine nation.

This division has received criticism from various fronts. Merlie Alunan, who addresses Lumbera’s criteria directly in “Latitudes of Intimacy: New Waray Writing and National Literature,” argues that all literature necessarily works with both particulars and universals, the latter being found precisely in the exploration of the former. Thus, a truly encompassing national literature does not exclude the local (or the “vernacular”) but is precisely the conglomeration of all these parts. Other reactions to both Lumbera’s concept of “national” and the idea of national literature are expressed in Many Voices: Towards a National Literature, 1995, which contains the views of Edelberto Garcellano, J. Neil Garcia, Leoncio Deriada, Victor Sugbo, Aida Rivera-Ford, Christine Godinez-Ortega, and Jose A. Bragado, who collectively represent various interests.

An analogous collection is Nationalist Literature: A Centennial Forum, 1995, which collected essays in a conference for the 1896 Centennial. As noted by editor Elmer Ordoñez, the nationalist tradition is marked by the continuance of the spirit of 1896, the end goal of which is “the realization of a truly sovereign and just society for the broad mass of the Filipino people” (ix). The book contains essays by important critics associated with the Philippine Left and the national democratic struggle, such as Salvador P. Lopez, Bienvenido Lumbera, Petronilo Daroy, and Alice Guillermo, among many others. Meanwhile, the content ranges from readings and rereadings of literary texts to literary theorizing to surveys of literary production.

Much of the debate on national literature has influenced and has been influenced by the surge of scholarship on literary and cultural materials from across the Philippines. In contrast (or perhaps in tandem) with the forces of globalization, the turn of the millennium has seen a resurgence in interest for the local literary traditions, both for writers and critics alike. Continuing the developments in Philippine studies in the 1970s, scholars are still recording, examining, and disseminating much of the cultural material across the archipelago. A large number of the books produced by scholars are surveys and/or anthologies of the said materials with historical contexts that tackle the development of, say, a local literary form. On the other hand, other critical works are dissections of Philippines cultural texts through a combination of empirical data and various strategies culled from different critical traditions and methodologies, especially Marxism, cultural (and historical) materialism, feminism, postcolonialism, and cultural studies. Generally, these strategies and theories are not imposed on the data but are instead used as flexible frameworks for a primarily inductive analysis. In doing so, the reconfiguration of these frameworks yields a greater understanding of both Philippine culture and the theories.

An example of that tendency is Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s Ang Bayan sa Labas ng Maynila / The Nation beyond Manila, 2007, which collects 12 essays critiquing cultural material from around the country. In “Judas and His Phallus: The Carnivalesque Narratives of Holy Week,” for example, Lucero looks into the various national, sexual, and folk discourses that circulate in a Judas-Iscariot-centered fiesta in Antique. Other essays include an analysis of the images of the 1896 Revolution in Ilonggo literature in the first half of the American era, and study on the concepts of time and space in the narrative chants of the Dulangan Manobo using a mix of historical, economic, sociopolitical, and textual analyses.

Like Lucero, Isidoro Cruz combines multiple critical strategies in his readings of Visayan literature and popular culture in his book Pungsod: Damming the Nation; Region/Nation and the Global Order in Contemporary West Visayan Literature, 2009. His earlier Cultural Fictions: Narratives on Philippine Popular Culture, Politics, and Literature, 2004, collects essays that are also “critical narratives” or “fictions,” within which Cruz sets a semiotician’s scalpel upon various layers of Philippine culture. Apart from traditional literary products, Cruz also analyzes the kinds of social and ideological reproduction found in everyday cultural texts like English language drills and street signs.

Scholarship in Western Visayan literature includes Siday: Mga Tulang Bayan ng Panay at Negros (Siday: Folk Poetry of Panay and Negros), 1997, an anthology edited by Corazon Villareal of poetic forms from Hiligaynon, Karay-a, and Aklanon, with notes on the formal features of every genre and translations of sample texts, including an excerpt from the epic Hinilawod, and Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava’s History and Society in the Novels of Ramon Muzones, 2001, which looks into the interplay of biography, popular culture, sociopolitical currents, and the history and traditions of Hiligaynon literature in the novels of the writer named by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts as the “Most Outstanding Hiligaynon Writer of the Century.”

A number of critics and scholars have looked into Waray literature—specifically, the development of its poetry. In “Locating the Voice in Waray Poetry,” Merlie Alunan critiques the homogeneity of the persona’s voice behind the radio-performed siday, a homogeneity rooted in the collective assumption of a public poetic persona. Panulaan at Dulaang Leytenhon-Samarnon (Leyte-Samar Poetry and Drama), 1994, edited by Jaime Biron Polo, collects and translates almost 80 years of Waray poetry and drama. Biron historicizes the development of Waray poetry vis-à-vis the clash between tradition and asymetric modernization brought about by centuries of colonialism, which led to a split between poems that were “taga-huron” (from the countryside) and “taga-sawang” (from the city). Jose Duke Bagulaya uses a Marxist / historical materialist framework in Writing Literary History: Mode of Economic Production and Twentieth Century Waray Poetry, 2006, which traces the development of different strains of Waray poetry to the economic conditions that held sway in Samar and Leyte over the past century. The second half of Bagulaya’s book is a bilingual anthology of samples of each of the genres he examines, thus also providing a much-needed anthology of Waray poetry to non-Waray speakers.

In Bikol literature, Maria Lilia F. Realubit’s Bikols of the Philippines, 1983, gives a history of Bikol literature from the Ibalon epic to the Golden Age of Bikol literary production in the early 20th century. Meanwhile, Jose Jason Chancoco’s Pagsasatubuanan: Poetikang Bikolnon (Pagsasatubuanan: Bikol Poetics), 2008, studies the formal elements of traditional Bikol poetry.

 

Studies in Ilocano literature are undertaken by Roderick Galam. Among other topics, his The Promise of the Nation: Gender, History, and Nationalism in Contemporary Ilokano Literature, 2008, takes up the Ilocano writers’ representation of martial law. Galam shows how the loyalist position of Ilocano writers has been challenged by younger writers like Clesencio Rambaud, whose work simultaneously supports benevolent militarization while critiquing the Marcos regime’s ineffectiveness at achieving that goal.

An interesting dual study of language and literature is Emmanuel Luis Romanillos’s Chabacano Studies, Essays on Cavite’s Chabacano Language and Literature, 2006. Romanillos presents the formal characteristics of Chabacano before discussing various Chabacano folk songs, riddles, and poems.

In Cebuano literature, the two-volume anthology Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak, 1988, has been supplemented by the two-volume collection Cebuano Fiction / Sugilanong Sugbuanon. The bilingual collections begin with introductions by Resil Mojares, who traces the development of Cebuano poetry and fiction from the folk tradition and early literary production in the Spanish era to the golden age of Cebuano literature under the American occupation and its subsequent decline and marginalization after World War II and the imposition of Tagalog. Mojares notes the strong influence of journalism in early 20th-century Cebuano literature and of the effect of cinema on the short story.

A number of studies have been done on early Tagalog literature and literary forms. In May Gawa na Kaming Natapus Dini: Si Rizal at ang Wikang Tagalog (We’ve Finished Some Activity Here: Rizal and the Tagalog Language), 2002, Nilo Ocampo collects and comments on Rizal’s different writings on the Tagalog language, including his letters to Blumentritt, his translation of Schiller’s Guillermo Tell, and his unfinished novel Makamisa. Studies on literary forms include Galileo Zafra’s Balagtasan: Kasaysayan at Antholohiya (Balagtasan: History and Anthology), 1999, which looks at the historical development of the once-popular literary form, positing that the  both preserved native cultural traditions and served as a challenge and critique of colonial powers. In Ang Dagling Tagalog: 1903-1936 (The Tagalog Dagli: 1903-1936), 2007, editors Rolando B. Tolentino and Aristotle Atienza collect nearly a hundred dagli (vignettes), which are then classified into five categories. The introduction discusses the dagli as the product of conditions during the American colonial period.

The postmodern breakdown of high and low culture has led to more intense scholarship and criticism in once-ignored and derided popular literature. This shift is perceptible in Soledad S. Reyes’s Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular: Piling Sanaysay, 1976-1996 (Reading Literature and Popular Culture: Selected Essays, 1976-1996), 1997. Reyes’s interest in popular texts is reflected in her other collections of criticism: A Dark Tinge to the World, 2007; From Darna to Zsazsa Zaturnnah: Desire and Fantasy, 2009; and Narratives of Note, 2012. These studies cover the influence of popular magazine Liwayway on the development of Tagalog literature, the elements of komiks as extensions of folk tradition, the confluence of celebrity culture and politics, the experiences of AM radio commentators, among other aspects of Philippine popular culture.

Other studies on popular culture include Emil Flores’s “Comics Crash: A Survey of Filipino Comics and Its Quest for Cultural Legitimacy,” 2004, published in the Journal of English Studies and Comparative Literature, and Erlinda K. Alburo’s “History and the Prewar Cebuano Novel,” 2007, published in the journal Philippine Studies, which looks at how three popular historical novels from before World War II successfully engage their public in considering the heroism of their past en route to an independent future.

The history of the book in the Philippines itself is treated in Patricia May Jurilla’s Tagalog Bestsellers of the Twentieth Century, 2004, the first of its kind in the Philippines. Jurilla focuses on popular Tagalog literature to literary publishing in the Philippines, highlighting not only the forms of the works themselves but also the conditions of their production and their subsequent impact on culture and history.

 

In Philippine literature in English, the work has consisted of anthologizing or editing of collected works. Gemino Abad’s anthologies Man of Earth, 1988, A Native Clearing, 1996, and A Habit of Shores chart the first century of Philippine poetry in English and demonstrate Abad’s thesis, given fuller treatment in Our Scene So Fair: Filipino Poetry in English 1905-1955, 2008, that Filipino poets have come to “write from,” not “write in,” English, the colonizer’s language becoming a tool instead of a prison house. Abad has made a counterpart set of anthologies of Philippine fiction in English: Upon Our Own Ground, 2008; Underground Spirit, 2010; and Hoard of Thunder, 2012.

Editions of collected works with critical introductions include The Complete Poems of Angela Manalang Gloria, 1993, Austregelina: A Story of Lina Espina Moore’s Life and Selected Works, 2000, and Harvest and Other Stories by Loreto Paras Sulit, 2001, all edited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Desire and Other Stories by Paz Latorena, 2000, edited by Eva Kalaw; and The Critical Villa: Essays in Literary Criticism by Jose Garcia Villa, 2002, edited by Jonathan Chua. Another work in this vein is The Epistolary Criticism of Manuel A. Viray: In Memoriam, collected by L. M. Grow, which presents a selection from 40 years’ worth of Viray’s letters, in which he comments on the works of fellow Filipino writers in English like Alejandro Hufana and Gregorio Brillantes. Foreign critics who have studied Philippine literature in English include Gerald Burns, Roger J. Bresnahan, and Leonard Casper, whose work has continued into the 2000s. A recent work is Jennifer McMahon’s Dead Stars: American and Philippine Literary Perspectives on the American Colonization of the Philippines, 2011, which looks into the tensions and interrelations of three groups of personages: the American anti-imperialist writers, the American educators in the Philippines, and the Filipino writers who were students of the American-designed curriculum.

Oral traditions are examined in essays like Alicia Magos’s “The Epic in Pre-Hispanic Panay,” which links the epic to social structures and religious worldviews of Visayans in Panay, and Christine Godinez-Ortega’s “The Epics of Mindanao,” which surveys common themes and motifs among the various Mindanaoan epics. Both of these are collected in Tinuha: History in Philippine Literary Texts, 2003, edited by Victor Sugbo. Meanwhile, Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s “Voices from the Mountains: Folk Literature as Print and Performance Art,” included in Ang Bayan sa Labas ng Maynila / The Nation beyond Manila, reviews the literature on oral literature, which she notes has moved from presenting folk texts as written literature (for they have to be written to be disseminated) to emphasizing (and so preserving) the performative aspects of oral tradition. Another essay is Raniela Barbaza’s “Ang Bayan bilang Kapwa: Katwiran at Batas sa Hinilawod” (Nation as Fellow: Reason and Law in Hinilawod), 2013, published in the journal Malay, which uses the Bikol concept of man as rooted in his use of language to argue that the Hinilawod presents a concept of bayan that is created and recreated by and through speaking subjects.

There is a growing interest in explicating marginal voices for social and historical purposes. Teresita Maceda’s Mga Tinig mula sa Ibaba (Voices from Below), 1996, gathers and analyzes the songs of the Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas, Partido Socialista ng Pilipinas, Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon, and Hukbong Mapagpalaya sa Bayan, from 1930 up to 1955. Maceda uncovers the perspectives of the everyday workers and peasants regarding the material conditions that led to their choices, the experience of their struggles, their concepts of freedom and nation and society. Similarly, Macario Tiu’s Davao: Reconstructing History from Text and Memory, 2005, uses the oral traditions of the indigenous Filipinos to solve the contradictions of standard (colonial) documented sources, thus telling a more complete story of the Davao region. Tiu also ends the book with a selection of 64 myths and legends of the tribes around Davao—a move that shows how often Filipino critics must not only analyze cultural materials but also be their main collector and disseminator as well.

Anthologies of critical essays built around an author or book offer a history of reception and are clues to the literary presuppositions of the day. Banaag at Sikat: Metakritisismo at Antholohiya (Glimmer and Light: Metacriticism and Anthology), 2010, edited by Maria Luisa Torres Reyes, consists of 17 essays spanning 70 years of criticism on Lope K. Santos’s novel and surfaces early debates on verisimilitude and literary merit. Similar anthologies are Himalay: Kalipunan ng mga Pag-aaral kay Balagtas (Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Balagtas), 1988, Himalay: Kalipunan ng mga Pag-aaral kay Jose Rizal (Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Jose Rizal), 1991, both of which are edited by Patricia Melendrez-Cruz and Apolonio Chua. Poetikang Tagalog: Mga Unang Pagsusuri sa Sining ng Pagtulang Tagalog (Tagalog Poetics: Early Critical Works on the Art of Tagalog Poetry), 1996, edited by Virgilio S. Almario, makes available four of the earliest studies on Tagalog poetry mentioned above, those by Gaspar de San Agustin, Francisco Bencuchillo, Jose Rizal, and Lope K. Santos.

A chunk of critical work is focused on the interplay between history and culture. Much of Resil Mojares’s work exemplifies this activity. Waiting for Mariang Makiling, 2002, problematizes the relationship between literature and historiography. It maintains that neither field is separate from the other and that both are discourses, and that no text, literary or otherwise, is separate from the material and symbolic networks within which it was conceived. At the same time, Mojares also asserts the heterogeneity of the Filipino nation, arguing that there is no one singular and essentialist definition of the Filipino. Both of these ideas are exemplified in the title essay, which proposes a cognitive mapping of the Filipino nation via a systematic analysis of the various subject-positions—and thence the social, historico-material, and ideological underpinnings—of each of the many retellings of the legend of Mariang Makiling. Isabelo’s Archive, 2013, presents commentary on various cultural texts throughout Philippine history, and Brains of the Nation: Pedro Paterno, T. H. Pardo de Tavera, Isabelo de los Reyes and the Production of Modern Knowledge, 2006, explores the individual lives and work of each of the three titular personages before it delves into a Foucauldian genealogy of the intelligentsia in the Philippines.

As already mentioned, Marxism experienced a steep drop in public/academic interest during the first decade after EDSA. Although the Left was bolstered at first by the victory against Marcos, the many aforementioned crises of the Left led to growing disenchantment for both revolutionaries and academics alike. Nevertheless, many critics continued to produce critically engaging work. In 1990, Gelacio Guillermo published Ang Panitikan ng Pambansang Demokrasya (The Literature of National Democracy), which outlines the characteristics and overall project of the national democratic literature and reviews literary works.

Bienvenido Lumbera’s political framework for emplotting the history of Philippine literature as well as his ideas on national literature are crystallized in Writing the Nation / Pag-akda ng Bansa, 2005, a collection of his essays on literature, language, film, and other aspects of Philippine culture. Among the literature essays are “Bakit Hindi Paksaing Pilipino” (Why Not a Philippine Topic), a short essay where Lumbera speaks about his “re-education” from 1959 onward toward a more nationalist and Filipino-centered thinking; “The Soil in Which We Root: Sources of Tradition for Contemporary Filipino Artists,” where he problematizes the various forces that influence artistic production in the Philippines and in so doing, gives four main traditions that have been particularly influential—namely, ethnic culture, Philippine history, Christianity, and international/Western culture; and the aforementioned “Harnessing Regional Literature for National Literature.”

Despite the crisis in the Philippine Left in the 1990s, Marxist criticism continued to grow in scope and complexity, in part to address the concerns brought out by other newer theoretical traditions. An example is the writings of Epifanio San Juan Jr, who reacts vehemently against postcolonialism in After Postcolonialism, 2000, and In the Wake of Terror, 2007. San Juan reemphasizes the need for a nationalist and historical-materialist perspective in lieu of what he finds as the postmodern and postcolonial obsession with deconstruction and identity politics. According to San Juan, the latter is especially troubling because it reduces the Marxian notion of class to just another category of the personality alongside gender and ethnicity, whereas the status of all three, he asserts, is enmeshed in a dialectic with modes of production. Like San Juan, R. Kwan Laurel also attacks postmodern liberties with truth and history in contemporary literature in English and the co-optation of critical discourse and the academe to market forces in Philippine Cultural Disasters, 2010.

Edel Garcellano continues to be an equally polemical writer. Knife’s Edge, 2001, collects some of his most significant critical essays, mainly from three previous collections: First Person Plural, 1987; Intertext, 1990; and Interventions, 1998. Garcellano proffers a polemical and theoretically nuanced Marxist critique, often utilizing poststructuralist, feminist, and reader-response theories as well. In “Philippine Hermeneutics and the Kingpins of the Hill,” Garcellano critiques the “depoliticization of mainstream literary discourse” by poets like Gemino Abad, who he thinks has an overly abstract and metaphysical understanding of language as a medium under the author’s control, which thus can be neatly indigenized and owned. He also critiques the ideological, and often literal, collaboration of leading Philippines poets in the 1980s with the dictatorial state. Meanwhile, in “The Arrogance of Imaginary Power,” Garcellano dissects what for him is the continued nativist and anti-intellectual posturing of Virgilio S. Almario.

Among the younger generation of critics, the more prolific ones are Rolando B. Tolentino, Ramon Guillermo, Caroline Hau, and Neferti Tadiar. In Sipat Kultura: Tungo sa Mapagpalayang Pagbabasa, Pag-aaral at Pagtuturo ng Panitikan (Cultural Sight: Toward Liberative Reading, Study, and Teaching of Literature), 2007, Tolentino proposes reading literary and cultural texts along axes of history, society, and modernity—a socially oriented, theoretically savvy historical materialism that takes into account the ruptures and structures of modernization. In one essay, he contrasts the journey of Philippine epic heroes and the journeys of contemporary overseas Filipino workers (OFWs), thus deconstructing the government’s use of the label “bagong bayani” (new hero) for OFWs and revealing the exploitative and dehumanizing character of the state-sponsored enterprise. This reading practice reaffirms the transformative potential of literature, one that may be recruited for the creation of a truly just and nationalist society.

Ramon Guillermo’s Pook at Paninindigan (Site and Stand), 2009, demonstrates that the “translation” and “adaptation” of Western ideas and theories can be useful and even socially transformative. Guillermo is also known for using computer-aided methods in his analyses of the linguistic characteristics of single texts as well as in the analyses of semantic patterns of words over large bodies of work. Translation and Revolution, 2010, explicates the ideological forces in 19th-century Philippine nationalism by looking into the process by which Rizal translated Schiller’s Wilhelm Tell. Guillermo has also used computer-aided methods to call out important Filipino historians. For example, “Translation as Argument: The Non-Translation of Loob in Ileto’s Pasyon and Revolution,” 2014, published in Philippine Studies argues that Rafael Ileto’s non-translation of loob gives the word mystical connotations, meanings which underpin the argument of Ileto’s book. The actual use of the word in Tagalog texts throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, however, suggests that such interpretations of loob are overstated.

The work of Caroline Hau focuses on the relationships between literature and nationalism, and the various roles of each in the production of the other. Hau is particularly interested in identifying “the heterogenous elements … that inform, but also exceed, nationalist attempts to grasp, intellectually and politically, the complex realities at work in Philippine society” (6). In Necessary Fictions, 2000, Hau makes it clear that these excesses are irreducible by-products of the nationalist project, so the response to their identification should not be a poststructuralist abandonment of the nation, but rather a collective effort toward more sophisticated analyses of the nation. In her analysis of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino and Ileto’s Pasyon and Revolution, she shows how both authors oppose rigid dichotomies of “foreign” and “native” in their constructions of syncretic and dynamic conceptions of key players in Philippine history—a Hispanicized bourgeoisie on the one hand and a mass-based folk Christian millenarianism on the other. But while “foreign” elements are the excesses of nativist narratives of Philippine history, Joaquin’s and Ileto’s constructions of Philippine history are haunted by other excesses—the masses in the former, the quotidian excess of certain millenarian rituals in the other.

In On the Subject of the Nation, 2006, Hau continues her analysis of national mythmaking, focusing this time mostly on the lived experiences of collective belonging in marginalized testimonies (e.g., a personal account of the purges of the CPP, the story of an undocumented worker in Japan). These evince the problematic relationship of individuals to the nation, thus challenging and reconfiguring the very possibility of concretizing the nation as a political project.

Neferti Tadiar examines the interpellation of marginalized peoples within both the material and the imaginary productive forces of globalization. In Fantasy Production: Sexual Economies and Other Philippine Consequences for the New World Order, 2004, she combines Marxism and psychoanalysis à la Zizek to analyze the ways in which the Philippine state attempts to structure the fantasies—that is, “the hegemonic forms of expression of our desiring actions” (6)—of its constituents. Tadiar points out that imagining and dreaming, such as the neocolonial Philippine dream of a First World fantasy, are integral to capitalist and colonial logic as forms of living labor. She analyzes an array of cultural phenomena to explore the dreaming of gendered, racialized, and sexualized subjects within the fantasies of the state, as well as dream acts that fall outside of it and that may serve liberative purposes.

On the other hand, Things Fall Away: Philippine Historical Experience and the Makings of Globalization, 2009, looks into the various material and cultural practices of Filipino marginalized/subaltern populations that “fall away” from the purview of both global and national narratives of development, and yet are part of the productive forces in the global capitalism. Thus, by looking into the activities and literature of feminized labor, urban activists, and revolutionaries, Tadiar uncovers how they often depart from the overarching narratives of globalization and of feminists, activists, and revolutionaries themselves, how they produce the conditions for the system that marginalizes them, and how they offer possibilities for newer/different forms of resistance. Tadiar shows in Fanny Garcia’s story “Pina, Pina, Saan Ka Pupunta?” (Pina, Pina, Where Are You Going?) that the locus of decision making (in the context of prostituting feminized Filipina labor vis-à-vis American capital) lies not in an allegorical narrative of sacrifice but rather in the kapwa (shared subjectivity) system of “syncretic sociability” with other women in the community.

The recognition of the camaraderie in communities of women (with their own productive—though often unacknowledged—power and labor in society) is an important activity for many feminist movements, which seek to provide alternative (vis-à-vis the patriarchy) understandings of historical and social forces. When feminist literary criticism entered the country in the 1980s, this then became one of the goals in a number of feminist rereadings of canonical literary texts. A definition of a Filipino feminist theory appears in Elynia Mabanglo’s “Ang Babae sa Loob ng Bote” (The Woman inside the Bottle), 1990, published in the journal Ani, to which Virgilio S. Almario replied with his essay “Dula ng Balangkas at Sagisag: Panukalang Sipat sa ‘Katipan’ ni Mike L. Bigornia” (Drama of Form and Symbol: A Proposed Study of Mike L. Bigornia’s “Katipan”), 1990, eventually included in Mutyang Dilim: Ang Bagong Pormalismong Filipino sa Pagbasa ng Tula (Dark Muse: New Filipino Formalism in Reading Poetry), 2001. Another pioneering text is Thelma Kintanar’s Women Reading: Feminist Perspectives on Philippine Literary Texts, 1992, which rereads important literary works in light of feminist critiques of patriarchal societies and the othering of women.

Influenced perhaps by the feminist emphases on female comradeship and the deconstruction of masculine/public and feminine/domestic spaces, many critics collect the personal narratives of and/or encounters with and between women writers. These narratives allow their voices to be heard while also serving as primary material for the deconstruction of patriarchal and/or male-centric narratives in Philippine literary and cultural histories. They also provide many different, and occasionally contradictory, portrayals of women and feminism, thus allowing for a more empirically complex understanding of womanhood in the Philippines.

Edna Zapanta Manlapaz has done extensive work on the earlier generations of women writers in English using a technique that mixes criticism and creative writing. Our Literary Matriarchs, 1925-1953, 1996, presents scenes from the lives of Paz Marquez-Benitez, Loreto Paras-Sulit, Paz Latorena, and Angela Manalang Gloria that are imaginary, derived from the literature by and about them. Six Women Poets, 1996, ostensibly a collection of interviews co-authored with Marjorie Evasco, is replete with digressions, interjections, annotations from Manlapaz that are addressed to the reader, thus simulating a kind of tripartite dialogue between the interviewer, the interviewee, and the audience/reader. This mixing of creative devices with “objective” reporting is pushed even further in her biographies of Estrella Alfon (Estrella D. Alfon: Her Life in Her Own Words, 1997), Lina Espina-Moore (Austregelina: A Story of Lina Espina Moore’s Life and Selected Works, 2000), and Angela Manalang Gloria (Angela Manalang Gloria: A Literary Biography, 1993), the last of which she explicitly declares as being not Manalang Gloria’s story but rather Manlapaz’s story of Manalang Gloria. Filipino Women Writers in English: Their Story, 1905-2002, 2003, is a traditional bio-bibliographical survey of women’s writings.

Other works in the same vein are Rosario Torres-Yu’s Sarilaysay: Tinig ng 20 Babae sa Sariling Danas bilang Manunulat (Self-Narrative: 20 Women on Their Experience as Writers), 2000, and Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo’s Pinay: Autobiographical Narratives by Women Writers, 2000, both of which collect personal narratives from several generations of Filipina writers. Pantoja-Hidalgo also has essays on women’s writing in her essay collections A Gentle Subversion, 1998; Over a Cup of Ginger Tea, 2006; and Fabulists and Chroniclers, 2008.

Although feminists and Marxists have often been at odds—most often due to the latter’s subordination of the former’s concerns—E. San Juan’s Filipina Insurgency: Writing Against the Patriarchy in the Philippines, 1998, argues for the necessary collaboration of the two movements. San Juan examines the representations of women in various texts (from Jose Burgos’s La Loba Negra to Jessica Hagedorn’s story “The Belly of the Beast”) and their contradictions with the patriarchy. Motivating these essays are the beliefs that there is a need for historical-materialist consciousness in every endeavor and that the feminist campaign against the patriarchy is neither contradictory nor subordinate to the struggle for national liberation.

Lilia Quindoza Santiago’s Sexuality and the Filipina, 2007, analyzes both historical and literary texts to discuss the various constructions and interpellations of Filipina sexuality over the course of Philippine history. In Sa Ngalan ng Ina: Sandaang Taon ng Tulang Feminista sa Pilipinas 1889-1989 (In the Name of the Mother: A Century of Feminist Poems in the Philippines, 1889-1989), 1997, Santiago looks into the historical and cultural constructions of women in poetry and the development of women’s poetry in Ilocano, English, and Tagalog vis-à-vis the growth of feminist discourse and the women’s movement. Dangerous Liaisons: Sexing the Nation in Novels by Philippine Women Writers (1993-2006), 2010, by Ruth Jordana Luna Pison critiques the typical narrative/representation of the nation as woman, itself tied to the discourse of Third World, feminized service labor, by showing how the construction of female characters in the novels resists the integration of womanhood and nation. These facts lead to a discursive renegotiation of both woman and nation. Soledad Reyes in Teller of Tales, Singer of Songs, 2001, devotes a section to women writers (e.g., Elena Patron, Rosario Jose, and Lualhati Bautista) and another on female characters in literary and popular texts. She has also written a biography of Rosario de Guzman Lingat and edited a collection of Lina Flor’s works.

 

The number of critical literature on LGBTQ has increased slowly over the years. J. Neil C. Garcia, who with Danton Remoto edited the gay anthology series Ladlad (Coming Out), wrote the seminal study Philippine Gay Culture, 1996. It analyzes Philippine gay culture from the 1960s to the 1990s and the writings of three early gay writers, Severino Montano, Orlando Nadres, and Tony Perez. Among his arguments is the differentiation between bakla and homosexual, the former being linked with one’s interiority or kalooban, the latter with sexual preferences and the sexual act.

More critical essays are in Tabi-Tabi sa Pagsasantabi: Kritikal na Tala ng mga Lesbiana at Bakla sa Sining, Kultura, at Wika (Excuse the Slight: Critical Notes by Lesbians and Gays on Art, Culture, and Language), 2003, edited by Eugene Y. Evasco, Roselle V. Pineda, and Rommel B. Rodriguez. Lesbian criticism is being carried out by Sharon Pangilinan and Roselle Pineda.

Postcolonialism has been a major stream in Philippine literary criticism. In “The Other Other: Towards a Postcolonial Poetics,” 1989, Isagani Cruz argues that Philippine criticism suffers from a hegemonic internalization of the superiority of Eurocentric criticism over Philippine criticism, thus leading to the under-theorization of Philippine literature and culture. Cruz argues that it is necessary for Filipino critics to read the output of their own kritikos/as (critics) over the past century in order to build more a grounded theoretical practice in the Philippines. This essay has since been translated into Filipino and included in Bukod na Bukod: Mga Piling Sanaysay (Totally Incomparable: Selected Essays), 2003. That book and The Other Other, 2010, both edited by David Jonathan Y. Bayot, sum up Cruz’s basic concerns, including the slippery concept of literature and the political engagement of the critic. Some of Cruz’s essays are readings in structuralist and poststructuralist veins, for which activity Edel Garcellano took him to task in “Post-EDSA Literature and Marxist Discourse,” 1990.

As early as the 1980s, Cruz’s call for a more postcolonial Philippine criticism was already being fulfilled. There were Revaluation, 1984, and Abot Tanaw: Sulyap at Suri sa Nagbabagong Kultura at Lipunan (As Far as the Eyes Can See: A Glimpse and Analysis of a Changing Culture and Society), 1987, both by Bienvenido Lumbera; Originality as Vengeance, 1984, by Lucila Hosillos; Balagtasismo versus Modernismo, 1984, and Kung Sino ang Kumatha Kina Bagongbanta, Ossorio, Herrera, Aquino de Belen, Balagtas, Atbp.: Mga Imbestigasyon sa Panitikan ng Kolonyalismo (On Who Authored Bagongbanta, Ossorio, Herrera, Aquino de Belen, Balagtas, and Others: Investigations into the Literature of Colonialism), 1992, by Virgilio S. Almario; and Literature and Politics: The Colonial Experience in Nine Philippine Novels, 1993, by Jaime An Lim.

The first anthology of postcolonial literary criticism in the Philippines is Philippine Postcolonial Studies: Essays on Language and Literature, 1993, edited by Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo and Priscelina Patajo-Legasto. Many of the essays revolve around either the need for further studies of marginalized literatures (e.g., Lily Rose Tope’s “The Chinese Margin in Philippine Literature”) and proposals for new frameworks of studying literature (e.g., Angelito Santos’s “Philippine Oral Literature: An Introduction”). In 2008, Legasto edited another much larger anthology, Philippine Studies: Have We Gone Beyond St. Louis. In her introduction, Legasto defines Philippine studies as an approach that aims to liberate Filipinos from the material and ideological structures of colonialism and neocolonialism, structures that have interpellated Filipinos as merely “others” in a Western hegemonic system.

J. Neil Garcia is another prolific postcolonial critic. In Postcolonialism and Filipino Poetics, 2004, Garcia critiques formalist-romantic poetics in Tagalog and in English writings as forwarded by Virgilio S. Almario and Gemino Abad. His main contention is that both critics propagate nativist aesthetics. While in certain ways recalling Garcellano, Garcia posits Philippine identity as being inherently hybrid and performative in nature—a process of becoming vis-à-vis the world—rather than being an essential, unchangeable being. Garcia argues that future rereadings of Philippine texts, in light of contemporary theories, should offer a more accurate depiction of plurality of Philippine identity and literary activity. Almario responds to Garcia’s criticism in his introduction to his Pag-unawa sa Pagtula: Pagususuri at Kasaysayan ng Panulaang Filipino (Understanding Poetry: A Study and History of Filipino Poetry), 2006, to which Garcia then responds in his essay “Nativism and Critical Theory,” published in the first volume of his collection The Postcolonial Perverse, 2014.

That all Philippine literature is inherently hybrid is a point that Garcia makes in a number of his essays, especially with regard to Philippine literature in English. In one of his most recent works, “Translation and the Problem of Realism in Philippine Literature in English,” 2014, published in the journal Kritika Kultura, Garcia argues that much of Philippine literature in English cannot be viewed from the lens of realism because the mimetic rhetoric of Western realism hinges on the use of the local language for verisimilitude. Philippine literature in English is thus always, both literally and conceptually, a product of translation.

Filipino writers based abroad have contributed much in theorizing identity, especially the relations between “native” and “foreign.” Vicente Rafael’s Contracting Colonialism, 1988, looks into the multifaceted relationship between conversion and translation in the Philippines and the contradictory uses of the latter in the hands of Spanish missionaries and Tagalog natives. According to Rafael, the Spaniards saw translation (including the formalization of Tagalog grammar) as a way to subsume the Tagalog language into a semantic hierarchy that privileged Latin and Castilian as means of access to God. Translation thus served the Spanish purposes of domination and control. However, the Tagalog translated the Spaniards with a different purpose: the accumulation of words and signs into their own preexisting paradigms. Thus, for example, while the Spanish attempted to contract the meanings of words like utang na loob (debt of gratitude) and hiya (shame) in light of the man’s dependent relationship with God, the Tagalog understood this relationship (and so their relationships with Dios, Hesus, Maria, etc.) in light of their own notions of reciprocal debt-relationships. Rafael then argues that this kind of evasive translation was oftentimes a conscious and intentional act of resistance by the Tagalog, an act that allowed them to simultaneously function within two contrasting worlds and benefit from both.

Among the dozens of works on issues such as transnationalism and the diaspora itself, there are E. San Juan’s Racial Formations / Critical Transformations, 1992, a critique of multiculturalism and ethnic studies, and Augusto Fauni Espiritu’s Five Faces of Exile: The Nation and Filipino American Intellectuals, 2007, which reads the works of five Filipino American writers (Villa, Bulosan, Santos, Gonzales, and the diplomat Carlos P. Romulo) to provide a transnational account of Filipino-ness that explores the social formation of national identity in a position of exile. Tying together diasporic and LGBTQ criticism is Martin Ponce’s Beyond the Nation: Diasporic Filipino Literature and Queer Reading, 2012, which reads Filipino literature written in the United States through a matrix of neocolonialism, migration, and gender and sexuality in the subject formation of Filipino identities and nationalism in the United States. On the topic of diasporic critics themselves, on the other hand, there is Caroline Hau’s “Privileging Roots and Routes: Filipino Intellectuals and the Contest over Epistemic Power and Authority,” 2014, published in the journal Philippine Studies, which looks into the contradictions imbued in increasing skepticism of Filipino intellectuals in the archipelago about the capacity of Filipino intellectuals based abroad (especially Filipino Americans) to speak for and about the Philippines.

This debate, and the potential for hostilities and productive insights that come with it, will certainly continue in the years to come, as the Philippine state, the Philippine academe, and the Filipinos as laborers, teachers, critics, and scholars continue to integrate into the global economic system.

 

Conclusion

Most contemporary Filipino critics participate in a discursive field that combines various strategies and theoretical dispositions with the end goal of explicating Philippine cultures. Quite often, the critic will not identify with any one or two of the traditional schools of criticism, choosing to either declare himself or herself a student of multiple fields, or else to reject classifications altogether as unimportant and/or detrimental to understanding the complexities of Philippine reality.

On the other hand, a number of Philippine critics do identify and/or consistently engage with specific schools (or multiple schools) of criticism. For many of these critics, the active theorizing of Philippine literature, including a close engagement with “foreign” theories, is absolutely paramount for understanding Philippine culture and for the various projects of liberation (from economic, sexual, racial, ideological subjugation) that is often the goal of their work.

Significantly, however, this identification does not preclude a dialogue with and/or influence on and from other schools of criticism, even those with which the specific critic might vehemently disagree. In fact, it is more often the case that an alignment with one or more schools leads to more direct and systematic engagement with diverging theories, which results in some of the most fruitful (if sometimes hostile) critical and theoretical output in Philippine scholarship. For this reason, there are often large overlaps in terms of strategies used, theorists invoked, and concerns advocated, even in spite of a different overall project. The work of Neferti Tadiar, for example, is so thoroughly enmeshed in contemporary Marxist, feminist, and postcolonial discursive practices that to place Tadiar at the bridge between the first and the second is in no way less arbitrary than placing her at the bridge between the second and the third.

Formalism as a critical tradition has undergone a paradoxical development in the last 30 years. On the one hand, it continues to be utilized in countless critical texts (including a number of the surveys above) both by critics who mostly just critique form and by those who combine the skill of critical close reading with other theories. On the other hand, it is rare to find anyone identifying primarily as a “formalist,” owing in part to the multiple attacks it has received from not only Marxists but also feminists, LGBTQ critics, postcolonialists, and so forth. Similarly, an identification with the endless deferment of poststructuralism is just as rare, though the deconstructive strategies themselves are constantly used for other forms of critical traditions, such as in the works of Edel Garcellano, J. Neil Garcia, and Isagani Cruz, among others.  Written by Soledad Reyes, Bienvenido Lumbera, and Rosario Cruz-Lucero, updated by Dominic Sy, with notes from Virgilio S. Almario, Resil B. Mojares, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Reynaldo Duque, Nenita Escasa, Edgardo Tiamson, Alice G. Guillermo, Emmanuel Reyes, and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Conclusion

Although often executed in tandem, criticism and scholarship are separate activities that draw on each other. Scholarship refers to research in literary history and most often involves data collection and classification. Criticism refers to the use of scholarly work for the systematic and rigorous study of literary texts, which is often through the lens or multiples lenses of a critical or theoretical framework.
The Spanish Colonial Period: 1703-1898

Spanish Augustinian Fr Gaspar de San Agustin, in his Compendio de la Lengua Tagala (Summary of the Tagalog Language), 1703, relates that fellow missionary Fr Francisco de San Jose had shown some natives various poems written according to the rules of Spanish rhyming, to which one of them remarked: “Magaling, datapoua hindi tola” (It is good, but it is not poetry). This was the first published critical statement on literature known to have been made by a Filipino. The greater significance of this statement, however, is that it indicates that the indigenous Filipinos had their own criteria for defining poetry, distinct from those defining Spanish, or European, poetry. San Agustin’s Compendio is actually a grammar book; the final chapter is a discussion and illustration of Tagalog versification. Here, he covers its three aspects: rhyme, meter, and genre. He also divides Tagalog poetry into two types: the dramatic, like the soliranin, and the dalit, which is serious in theme. He further enumerates other types: diona, oyayi, and auit.

Other missionary poets, grammarians, and compilers of sample folk poems also codified the conventions of native poetry. In the mid-18th century, the state of Tagalog poetry had two commentators. Fr Melchor de Oyanguren’s Tagalysmo Elucidado, y Reducido [en lo Posible] a la Latinidad de Nebrija (Tagalism Elucidated, and Reduced [Where Possible] into the Latin of Nebrija), 1742, confirmed San Agustin’s earlier description of Tagalog poetry. The second commentator was Francisco Bencuchillo, whose Arte Poetico Tagalo (Art of Tagalog Poetry), 1750, published in 1895, is a more extensive description of Tagalog versification. It follows San Agustin’s classification of rhymes but observes more possibilities for Tagalog rhyme than San Agustin did. At the turn of the 19th century, Fr Joaquin Martinez de Zuñiga described Tagalog poetry in Estadismo de las Islas Filipinas (State of the Philippine Islands), based on his personal observation during poetry declamations and dramatic presentations. He gave the number of lines for various types of stanzas, the rhyming scheme, and the number of syllables per line for types of poems. The poems were invariably lyrical, usually about love or “some minor matters pertaining to their farms.” Among the other cultural forms that he saw were native dances accompanied by singing. These provoked his remark that the Fathers had set certain “limits of modesty,” a statement that explains to a great extent the absence of erotic poetry in the anthologies of the period and the lack of published secular poetry until the 19th century.

One of the last of the missionaries to make a commentary on Tagalog poetry was Fr Joaquin de Coria in the last section of his Nueva Gramatica Tagalog (New Tagalog Grammar), 1872. In seven chapters, he gives a general description of the types and functions of Tagalog poetry, as well as the manner in which each type is recited. The three most important chapters in this book are “Reglas del Tayotay en Tagalog” (Rules of Tagalog Metaphor), “De la Poesia en Idioma Tagalog” (Of Poetry in the Tagalog Language), and “De los Metros del Verso Tagalog” (Of Meters in Tagalog Verse). Coria focuses his attention on rhyme and meter, using these as basis for defining the tanaga (four-line stanza, with seven syllables per line) and the comedia (which he also described to be imitations of comicos latinos).

In Apr 1887, Jose Rizal delivered a paper in German titled “Tagalische Verkunst,” which he read before the Sociedad Etnografica in Berlin. He later translated this into Spanish, titled “Arte Metrica del Tagalog” (The Metrical Art of the Tagalog). This was the most thorough description of poetic conventions thus far written, noting details like the following: that a serious poem uses the dodecasyllabic line with a caesura on the sixth or seventh syllable; that a syllable may be added or removed as dictated by the meter; that, within one stanza, the monorhyming scheme may be adopted but another stanza must have a different rhyme; that a quatrain, generally composed of dodecasyllabic lines, is used for lyric poetry, and Francisco Baltazar’s poetry may serve as model; and, finally, that the quintilla, which generally consists of five hepta- or octosyllabic lines, is used for long narrative poetry that does not require rhetorical flourishes or imaginative elements, and the pasyon is a typical example. Stressing that “free verse is not recognized” by the Tagalog, Rizal then lists 12 kinds of rhyme, which he asserts are what distinguish Tagalog rhyme from that in any foreign literature, especially Spanish. To this date, this list of rhyming patterns still applies to Tagalog rhymed poetry.

article.value: By the 19th century, the rise of the bourgeois class also gave rise to the desire for conformity. In literary criticism, this desire was translated into concern for orthodoxy and style. Manga Puna (Criticisms), written in the early 19th century and published in 1907, by Filipino priest Aniceto de la Merced, pointed out doctrinal errors and weaknesses of style in Pasiong Mahal, 1814. Self-styled Spanish scholars, such as Sebastian de Totanes, Vicente Barrantes, and Toribio Minguella, wrote critical commentaries of Philippine literary forms. Barrantes’s El Teatro Tagalo (Tagalog Theater), 1889, provoked vehement refutations from the propagandists in Madrid, foremost of whom was Jose Rizal, who published “Excmo. Sr. D. Vicente Barrantes” (His Excellency, Sir Vicente Barrantes), 1889, in La Solidaridad. Minguella, in “Estilo Poetico” (Poetic Style), 1878, criticized the korido for lack of truthfulness, declaring that its contents should be based on correct theological doctrine and on the lives of real historical personages or saints.

Verisimilitude, or the concept of literature as a “mirror of life,” was used as a basis for the debate between Spanish scholars, who wrote critical commentaries of Philippine literary forms, and the propagandists in Madrid, foremost of whom were Jose Rizal and Marcelo H. del Pilar. Spanish critics who denounced Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, were Vicente Barrantes, who dismissed it as full of lies, and Spanish friar Jose Rodriguez, who, in his “Caiingat Cayo!” (Take Care!), called it heretical. Defenders of the novel were Marcelo H. del Pilar, whose satirical response “Caiigat Cayo!” (Hunt for the Eel), 1888, affirmed the truthfulness of the Noli. V. Caraig likewise refuted Rodriguez’s claims in his essay “M. R. P. Padre Jose Rodriguez,” 1890. Ferdinand Blumentritt, an Austrian scholar, defended the novel by citing the oppressive conditions in the Philippines. Hence, literary criticism was based on the concept of literature as a “mirror of life” and a “guide to life.”
The American Colonial Period: 1900-1940

The systematic diffusion of Anglo-American culture would shape a new sensibility that would have consequences on the critical works of the period. However, during the first decade of the 20th century, verisimilitude and didacticism continued to be the guiding principles of literary criticism.

Among the earliest critics to appear on the scene during the first decade of the American colonial period were those who decided to study Tagalog literature, which had opened itself up to genres other than the metrical romances called awit and korido, religious poetry, and lives of saints. With a growing number of literate Filipinos looking for other reading fare, the novel and the short story emerged to answer the need for works that depicted familiar worlds. Poetry itself had to diversify and to take into account other topics and issues that were being discussed during this period of intense colonization. In the past, drama derived much influence from the awit and korido (in the case of the komedya) and from the pasyon (in the case of the sinakulo), both in a nonrealist mode. Now it had to contend with the new demand for a more realistic representation of the world.

The Tagalog newspaper Muling Pagsilang, 1901-10, was an outlet for the critical essay. Many critiques were also delivered as lectures or speeches in conferences. Commenting on Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Light), 1906, Tagalog critics Macario Adriatico, Gabriel Beato Francisco, Manuel B. Francisco, and Godofredo Herrera debated on the timeliness of the Socialist program suggested by the novel. Similarly, the didactic element was the focus in Ubaldo Manapat’s critique of Anino ng Kahapon (Shadow of Yesteryears), 1907, by Francisco Laksamana. In the longest critical essay written during that first decade, Rosauro Almario did a more systematic study of Faustino Aguilar’s Busabos ng Palad (Slave of Fate), 1909. He evaluated the novel using the criteria of “organic unity, interest, and verisimilitude.” Patricio Mariano cited the novel’s achievement in unmasking society, whereas Gonzalo Cue Malay focused on the characters as victims of society’s ills. In general, the critical essay of this period was marked by the tendency to be polemical, rhetorical, and personal.

The second decade saw the critics paying more attention to the rhetorical elements of a literary work. An exchange of ideas between Carlos Ronquillo and Rosauro Almario focused on the diction, metaphor, and imagery of Almario’s own novel, Nang si Eba ay Likhain (When Eve Was Created), 1913. Beginning in 1914, a question arose as to whether the “epilogue” attached to a novel was also literary criticism. Julian Cruz Balmaseda, in “Matapos Basahin” (After Reading It), his epilogue to Precioso Palma’s novel Ipaghiganti Mo Ako! (Avenge Me!), 1914, believed there was a distinction, whereas Carlos Ronquillo, in “Ang mga Panghuling Salita” (Afterword), his epilogue to Nang si Eba Ay Likhain, believed that the epilogue’s function was to analyze and evaluate the work. Other epilogists/critics were Honorato de Lara, Teodoro E. Gener, and Remigio Mat Castro. This twofold role of the epilogue established the tendency in literary criticism at this time to heap lavish praise on the work or, at least, to overlook its flaws. For example, in his epilogue to Rosalia Aguinaldo’s novel Mutyang Itinapon (Exiled Sweetheart), 1922, Dionisio San Agustin notes the inconsistencies in characterization but concludes that the novel’s value lies in the “nobility of thought” personified by the characters. During this period, therefore, and on to the 1940s, didacticism continued to be the overriding concern, and this resulted in criticism that was highly impressionistic.

That said, while much work was done on Tagalog literature, there were also many calls to reject the past, in this case the literary types identified with the discredited Spanish regime and found wanting in their failure to approximate the real world of a subject people. A clear example was Severino Reyes’s Ang Dulang Tagalog (The Tagalog Drama), 1938, a scathing attack on the popular komedya. The critic’s argument focused on the komedya’s predisposition toward a highly idealized, thus false, rendering of experience. This critical position would find its most extreme manifestation in the series of works written by both American and Filipino writers which reduced the rich variety of Philippine literature in Spanish and the local languages into a collective nonentity, and at the same time argued that the texts being written in English were the only significant productions of the first two decades of American rule. In addition, critics such as Leopoldo Yabes would make the fearless forecast that the great Filipino work could be written only in English.

On the other hand, a number of critics thought that there was a need to preserve what had been handed down from the past not only for the future generations to enjoy, but also for the world to know that the country had its own rich and varied literature. Colonialism was a powerful force that had led the natives to believe that they had not produced any significant body of literature. The first attempts at writing various “literary histories” would prove to the skeptical ones that indeed numerous writers had contributed to their country’s literary heritage.

Lope K. Santos, in his Peculiaridades de la Poesia Tagala (The Peculiarities of Tagalog Poetry), 1929, would continue the work on Tagalog poetics where Rizal left off. Already the concern for placing one’s theoretical statements in historical context is signified by Santos’s first chapter, which consists of a survey of the work done by the missionary critics like San Agustin, Bencuchillo, Martinez de Zuñiga, and de Coria. The purpose of this survey is to demonstrate their failure to capture the essence of Tagalog poetry. Here, Santos declares that the missionary poets’ stress on religious versification and their own badly written verses, which they held up as models of good poetry, were largely responsible for the deterioration of Tagalog poetry, which, before Spanish intervention, was vigorous in both content and technique. He adds that the rhyming scheme of Tagalog poetry is also to be observed in that of Cebuano, Ilocano, Ilonggo, Kapampangan, and other Philippine languages. This was a step toward giving a national scope to the study of Philippine poetry that Rizal had begun. At the end of his paper, Santos suggests the four periods into which the history of poetry may be divided: the pre-Hispanic, religious or mystical, revolutionary, and contemporary or philosophical.

Meanwhile, Hermenegildo Cruz’s Kun Sino ang Kumatha nang “Florante” (On Who Authored "Florante"), 1906, and Epifanio de los Santos’s Balagtas y Su “Florante” (Balagtas and His "Florante"), 1916, broke new ground in the choice of issues and methodology. These two studies of Francisco Baltazar or Balagtas’s classic poem Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1838, served as models for a critical approach combining historical data, biographical materials, sociological insights, and reader response. What these works established at this point was the need to situate the text against its context—the society from which it emerged, the functions of the text, the manner in which the work is received, and the role of the writer in the production of meaning. In both critical works, the relevance of Balagtas’s poem to the generations being educated under the American colonial regime was stressed, its value as a source of moral values and patriotic fervor emphasized.

This didactic view of literature shaped the thinking of a large number of critics who would perceive in literature and literary analyses a powerful and effective means to teach the reader how to be a good citizen, a morally upright person, and a God-fearing individual. In this phase of criticism, when critics were dependent on established truisms aptly summarized in the classic formulation “dulce et utile” (sweet and useful) as the proper function of literature, the polemical and political thrust of the critical project was to defend native culture in the face of a massive assault against it. Variations on these aforementioned concepts on the nature and function of criticism appeared in various prefaces and introductions to a large number of Tagalog novels published in the first two decades and in poetry books written by the likes of Lope K. Santos and Pedro Gatmaitan.

In the 1930s, the Institute of National Language sponsored a series of lectures on the different aspects of Tagalog literature. The result was perhaps the first systematic compilation of essays that dealt directly with specific literary genres, such as poetry, novel, drama, short story, and specific writers and works like Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Modesto de Castro, and the popular korido Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird). Among these texts that provided a diachronic view of the genre were Iñigo Ed. Regalado’s Ang Pagkaunlad ng Nobelang Tagalog (The Development of the Tagalog Novel), 1939; Lope K. Santos’s Tinging Pahapaw sa Kasaysayan ng Panitikang Tagalog (A Cursory Look at the History of Tagalog Literature), 1938; and Fausto Galauran’s Ang Maikling Kathang Tagalog (The Tagalog Short Story), 1938. These attempts at constructing a history of the literary type were generally uneven in scope and depth. Nonetheless, they provided the impetus needed for the development of the critical perspective concerned primarily with establishing a framework against which the development of a particular genre could be viewed. Moreover, the critical essays have remained to this day invaluable sources of data, especially on the different stages in the development of the genre in the last decade of Spanish rule and the first decades of American rule. Two books in the series were on specific works: Ang Lakan ng mga Makatang Pilipino na si Balagtas at ang Kanyang “Florante” (The Prince of Philippine Poets Balagtas and His Florante), 1938, by Hermenegildo Cruz and Si Valeriano Hernandez Peña at ang Kanyang “Nena at Neneng” (Valeriano Hernandez Peña and His Nena and Neneng), 1940, by Nieves Baens del Rosario.

In the 1920s and 1930s, a new group of writers started to take upon themselves what they perceived was a critical task: to shape the directions that literary productions ought to follow. The group, headed by Alejandro G. Abadilla and Clodualdo del Mundo, saw literature as being too beholden to the legacy of traditional writing best exemplified by the works of Balagtas. They looked at themselves as principal agents for creating a new generation of writers more attuned to developments in Western literature. The criteria of form and universalism began to be used to measure literary works, along with a deliberate avoidance of authorial comment, emotional restraint, and the preference for artistic unity. In their newspaper columns, Abadilla’s Mga Talaang Bughaw (Blue Lists) and del Mundo’s Ang Tao sa Parolang Ginto (The Person in the Golden Lighthouse), they evaluated the poems and short stories being written during this time and selected what they deemed to be the best of the lot.

In 1935, a group of university-educated writers with some knowledge of Western literary trends and familiarity with such writers as Katherine Anne Porter, Sherwood Anderson, and Theodore Dreiser formed Panitikan. Calling themselves both “sakdalista” (an allusion to the peasant group protesting social conditions of the period) and “aristokrata” (an unbiased posture of superiority), they proceeded to do a critique of traditional ways of writing led by del Mundo and Abadilla. In perspective, their attempt to chart the directions of Tagalog literature during the American period should be seen partly as a reaction to the perceived gains being made by Filipino writers in English during the period.

One of the more influential members of the group who would exert tremendous influence in the short story was Teodoro Agoncillo. He became the chronicler of the literary era that witnessed the first wave of modernism. The issues in the debate between the traditional and younger critics surfaced more clearly in the discussion of the prizewinning entries in the contest sponsored by Liwayway in 1943. The anthology Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943 (The 25 Best Pilipino Short Stories of 1943), 1944, showcased works that had a consciousness of the modern short story from the West. Clearly, the young critics had by this time learned to valorize texts that utilized techniques learned from the West and to deprecate writing that seemed steeped in sentimentality and didacticism.

Agoncillo’s critique in 1936 of Santos’s Banaag at Sikat demonstrated the critical principle that ideology and idea must be expressed through literary elements and devices. Comparing the novel to the works of Rizal, he argues that Santos’s creation is more propaganda than art, and that the characters are driven by the plot and by ideas rather than by realistic depiction. Writing on the same novel, Juan C. Laya declared that its value lay in its content, although its long-winded speeches weakened its artistic merit. Another example of the dichotomy between subjectivism and formalism in literary criticism is Nieves Baens del Rosario’s critique of Valeriano Hernandez Peña’s Ang Kasaysayan ng Magkaibigang si Nena at si Neneng (The Story of the Friends Nena and Neneng), 1940. She praises the novel for three reasons: its didactic element, emotional restraint, and realism.

In Bikol, literary criticism in the 1920s was being published in the newsmagazine Sanghiran nin Bikol and in the Bikolana magazine by writers like Mariano Nicomedes and Mariano del Prado Goyena. Nicomedes’s “Hayokong na Pinagpagalan Dapit sa Paagi nin Pagsarambit sa Bikol” (A Short Essay on How to Write Poetry in Bicol) offers a definition of poetry in Bikol, which he calls the sinarambit. Goyena’s “Siisay si Rizal?” (Who is Rizal?) is a review of Trinidad H. Pardo de Tavera’s El Caracter de Rizal (The Character of Rizal), 1918. The first few issues of the Hiligaynon magazine (then called Ang Bisaya sa Hiligaynon), 1934, showed the essayists’ keen interest in literary theory and its application to their own literature. Lorenzo Dilag Fajardo’s “Ang Aton Manunulat kag Ila Sinulatan” (Our Writers and Their Writing), 1934, used samples of Ilonggo writing to define story-writing technique, to distinguish between the long and the short story, and to do an influence study of established Ilonggo writers and their followers. This triggered a response from Lerio Pama, who wrote “Langkoy Sabat kay Dilag Fajardo” (In Reply to Dilag Fajardo) and Delfin Gumban, who wrote “Kon sa Akon Lamang” (In My Opinion). In turn, Dilag Fajardo tried to extricate himself from this debate by protesting in yet another essay, “Paathag kay G. Lerio kag kay G. Delfin Gumban” (Explanation to Mr Lerio Pama and Mr Delfin Gumban): “My critique was not whimsical but, as usual, based on what is right, guided by things which serve as my criteria to strengthen my critique. I did not condemn or praise the writing of Mr Delfin Gumban” (Hosillos 1992, 213).

Literary criticism in Spanish was represented by Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Pardo de Tavera, Cecilio Apostol, Jaime de Veyra, and Epifanio de los Santos, who uniformly affirmed their pride in Philippine literature. Epifanio de los Santos’s “Nuestra literatura a traves de los siglos” (Our Literature through the Ages), 1914, is one of the first surveys of Tagalog literature. It shows the development of Tagalog poetry from the early native songs, to Spanish forms like the duplo, awit, korido, loa, pasyon, and dramatic verses of the komedya, to Francisco Baltazar’s lyrics and the poetry of the propaganda movement. Fernando Ma. Guerrero’s “La Formacion de una Poesia Tipicamente Filipina” (The Formation of a Typical Filipino Poetry), 1924, argues that Philippine literature cannot be written in any foreign language, but must be written only in the native languages. In the same vein, Manuel Briones’s Discursos y Ensayos (Speeches and Essays), 1954, contains the speech “La Afirmacion de lo Filipino en la Literatura” (The Affirmation of the Filipino in Literature), which states: “What matters is not the form and dress, or medium of expression, of this idea or feeling, but the Philippine reality, the block carved from the native quarries; in a word, the indigenous and national context.”

As the American educational system produced students who were increasingly steeped not only in the English language but in American and British literary criticism, criticism in English began to be written. The crucial decision to make English the medium of instruction in the whole country meant the introduction of a whole new curriculum that certainly encompassed more than what the few educated natives had gone through during the Spanish period, as well as the wider dissemination of a foreign language not possible earlier. A centerpiece in this curriculum was English as a subject with both the grammar and the literature components. Among the more famous teachers during this period were Dean S. Fansler and his wife Harriet Ely Fansler, George Pope Shannon, Tom Inglis Moore, Harold P. Scott, and C. V. Wickers. They taught not only the rudiments of English grammar but also and more importantly the works of English and American writers. What was inculcated therefore was not merely the use of English to communicate with one another and to understand the lessons being taught in that language, but a whole way of looking at a world that was not at all familiar to the students.

In literature classes, Romantic and Victorian writers were taught. Their works were eventually taken as models for writing. The result was impressive: students wrote and their works saw print in a number of magazines in English, such as Philippine Education Magazine and Graphic. The new culture was further strengthened with the founding of such groups as the Philippine Writers’ Association, 1925; the UP Writers’ Club, 1927; and the Philippine Writers League, 1939.
