Sections

The Early Printing Presses
The Growth of Printing in the 19th Century
Literary Publications during the Spanish Colonial Period
Reformist and Revolutionary Publications
Literary Publishing in Periodicals
Literary Publishing in Book Form
Literary Publishing in Digital Form
The Publishing of Literary Scholarship          

 

Literary publications refer to works of drama, poetry, and prose produced in print or digital form as books or as pieces in journals, newspapers, and magazines. Literary books may be individual or collected works by a single author or anthologies of various works by multiple authors. The term literary publishing refers to the process of production: from the selection and editing of the literary work for publication, to the printing or uploading and distribution or dissemination of the final version of the work.

 

The Early Printing Presses

During the Spanish colonial period, the religious orders owned the printing presses and thus dominated the publishing of literary as well as nonliterary works. From 1593 to 1811, more than 1,000 titles were published in the Philippines. Majority of these works were religious, such as church regulations, homilies, lives of saints, novenas, pastoral letters, pasyon, and spiritual guides. Among the published secular works were grammars and vocabularies of various Philippine languages, historical accounts, treatises on logic, and scientific texts. Miscellaneous tracts on government matters such as decrees and regulations were also produced.

The Dominicans produced the first books of the Philippines. In 1593, the order published Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala (Christian Doctrine in Spanish and Tagalog), with the material based on the Tagalog translations of Fr Juan de Plasencia, which had been edited by other priests. That same year, the Dominicans also published X?nkè S?ngsh? G?om?-xiàn Zhuàn Wújí Ti?nzh? Zhèngjiào Zh?nchuán Shílù; A Printed Edition of the Veritable Record of the Authentic Tradition of the True Faith in the Infinite God, by the Religious Master G?om?-xiàn, 1593, or Hsin-k’o Seng shih Kao Mu-hsien Chaun Wu chi T’ien chu Cheng Chiao Chen-ch’uan Shih lu in the Wade-Giles system. This is a treatise on theology, cosmography, and natural history written by Fr Juan Cobo, the G?om?-xiàn (or Kao Mu-hsien) of the title. Both books were printed in Manila, using a method called xylography, which involves the use of woodblocks.

 

 

In 1604, typography, which is printing by movable type, was introduced in the Philippines by Fr Francisco Blancas de San Jose and the Chinese Christian printer Juan de Vera. Two books were produced that year by the Dominican press using the new method: Libro de las Quatro Postrimerias del Hombre en Lengua Tagala, y Letra Española (The Book on the Four Last Things of Man in Tagalog and Spanish) and Ordinationes Generales Provintiae Sanctissimi Rosarii Philippinarum (The General Ordinances of the Philippine Province of the Holy Rosary).

The other religious orders also published their works through their own printing presses. The Augustinians established theirs, the second in the Philippines, in 1618. They had imported the machinery from Japan in 1565 and set it up in Bacolor, eventually moving to Manila in 1621. In 1623, they sold the press to the Jesuits. The Augustinians established another printing press in 1886 in Guadalupe, transferring it to Malabon in 1890, where it was known as Pequeña Imprenta del Asilo de Huerfanos de Nuestra Señora de la Consolacion. With the machinery they had acquired from the Augustinians, the Jesuits established their printing press in 1623 at the Colegio de San Ignacio in Manila, and used it to print their works until their expulsion in 1768. Returning to the Philippines after a hundred years, they acquired another press in 1897 and printed the publications of the Jesuit Weather Observatory in Manila.

The Franciscans set up their printing press in Sampaloc, Manila, in 1692, then moved it to Tayabas, now Quezon, in 1700. This press was transferred to several places: the Franciscan convent in Manila from 1705 to 1712; the Convent de la Candelaria in Dilao, now Paco, from 1713 to 1714; again, in Manila, from 1714 to 1736; and the Convento of Our Lady of Loreto in Sampaloc, where it stayed until 1822.

The early printing presses were initially operated by Chinese immigrants. In the early 17th century, Filipinos became active in printing, with the Tagalog Tomas Pinpin as the leading figure among them. In 1610, the Dominican press published Blancas de San Jose’s Arte y Reglas de la Lengua Tagala (Grammar and Rules of the Tagalog Language), which was printed by Pinpin. That same year saw the publication of Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila (A Book for the Tagalog to Study the Spanish Language), the first book authored by a Filipino; it was printed by another Tagalog, Diego Talaghay, also for the Dominican press. In 1613, Pedro de San Buenaventura’s Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala (Vocabulary of the Tagalog Language) was printed by Pinpin and Domingo Laog, also a Tagalog.

As printing progressed in the Philippines, books written by Spanish priests in other local languages were published. The first of these were Doctrina Christiana Rob. Bellarmini in Linguam Bisayam Translata in Visayan by Cristobal Jimenez, issued in 1610; Arte de la Lengua Pampanga (Grammar of the Kapampangan Language) by Francisco Coronel, 1617; Libro a Naisuratanamin a Bagas ti Doctrina Cristiana in Ilocano by Francisco Lopez, 1621; and Arte de la Lengua Bicolana (Grammar of the Bikol Language) by Andres de San Agustin, 1647.

 

The Growth of Printing in the 19th Century

In the late 1830s, with Manila opened to international trade and other cities following suit, private commercial presses began to be established in the Philippines. Among the more prominent enterprises in Manila were Los Amigos del Pais, founded in 1846; Ramirez y Giraudier, 1858; Don Esteban Balbas, 1880; and Chofre y Compañia, 1880. This development would lead eventually to breaking the monopoly on printing and publishing held by the religious orders. It also ushered in technological advances in printing. In 1847, Fr Marcial Funcia Ramos introduced the first iron press in the country. He also replaced the use of papel de arroz (rice paper) and papel de china (Chinese paper) with papel de hilo (linen paper) for quality printing, Belgian paper for newspapers, and French paper for other works.

Lithography, a printing method using stone surfaces, was introduced in the Philippines by a German, George Oppel, in 1858. Collaborating with the firm of the Spanish printers Manuel Ramirez and Baltasar Giraudier, Oppel printed the La Ilustracion Filipina, the first illustrated periodical in the Philippines. The Carmelo and Bauermann Printing Press, established in 1887 by Eulalio Lakandula Carmelo and William Bauermann, also utilized the lithographic process.

 

Cavite was reported to have a printing press as early as 1814 with Tomas de Oliva, a Filipino, as its regent. In Cebu, Domingo de Escondrillas established the first printing press in 1873. The first printing press in Iloilo was Imprenta Enriqueta, which published the province’s first newspaper, the Hoja Volante, in 1875. Mariano Perfecto established the Imprenta La Panayana in Mandurriao, Iloilo, in 1877. The press survived until 1965, publishing not only religious books but also sarsuwela, korido (metrical romance), nobela (novel), and berso (verse). In 1892, Perfecto also established the Imprenta Sagrada Familia in Nueva Caceres, now Naga City, which published religious pamphlets, metrical romances, and devotionals. In Vigan, Ilocos Sur, Imprenta Ecclesiastica was operating in 1884. In Manila, Sampaloc became the center of the printing industry, with presses operating in Daang Imprenta, now G. Tuason. Among the establishments found in this area were the Imprenta de Sampaloc, 1838-46, owned by the Spaniard Antonio de Llanes y Valdez; the Plana y Compañia, 1870-82, later placed under the direction of Salvador Chofre y Compañia, 1882-98; La Opinion and El Eco de Filipinas, 1889-93, with Iñigo Ed. Regalado as regent; and Manila Imprenta de Santa Cruz, owned by a Filipino, Jose de Jesus y Rosario.

 

Literary Publications during the Spanish Colonial Period

Philippine literary publishing began in the early 17th century when Tagalog poetry appeared as supplementary material in religious publications. Local literature came to be published in books of their own beginning in the 18th century. Owing to censorship enforced by the Spanish government, the Church monopoly on printing, and the interests of the authors who were mostly members of the clergy, the literature that appeared in print was primarily religious and didactic. The publications were in the forms of the pasyon, the “life of the saint,” and the metrical romance. In the 19th century, when secular literature was allowed to be published, the works that appeared were mainly in the metrical romance form.

The pasyon is a verse narrative of the Passion of Christ. The first such work was Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola at Ipinanagang sa Cataastaasang Poong Jesus Nazareno (Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse and Dedicated to the Highest Lord Jesus the Nazarene), written by the Tagalog printer and author Gaspar Aquino de Belen. It was published in 1703 by the Jesuit press in one volume together with Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Commendation for the Soul of the Dying), a Tagalog translation by Aquino de Belen of the Spanish version of Ordo Commendationis Animarum by Fr Thomas de Villacastin. Other Tagalog versions of the pasyon appeared after Aquino de Belen’s work: Pasion de Nuestro Señor Jesucristo (Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ) by Don Luis Guian, published in 1740; Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader) by an anonymous writer, 1814; and El Libro de la Vida: Historia Sagrada con Santas Reflexiones y Doctrinas Morales para la Vida Cristiana en Verso Tagalo (The Book of Life: Sacred History with Pious Reflections and Moral Teachings for the Christian Life Written in Tagalog Verse) by Fr Aniceto de la Merced, 1852.

The Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal was the most popular of all the Tagalog versions of the pasyon. It came to be known as the Pasyon Pilapil, after Fr Mariano Pilapil, one of the several priests who revised the original anonymous text. Various versions of the pasyon in the other local languages began to appear in the mid-1880s. Pasyon works continue to be printed to this day. Aside from being read aloud or chanted as the pabasa (reading) during Holy Week, the pasyon has also been adapted for stage as the sinakulo (passion play), which is performed during the Lenten season as well.

The “life of the saint” form was written in prose or verse. These accounts of the lives and deeds of saints appeared in brief form as prefatory material in novenas or in extended form as narratives in pamphlets, some as full-length books. One particularly popular book was Aral na Tunay na Totoong Pagaacay sa Tauo nang manga Cabanalang Gaua nang Manga Maloualhating Santos na sina Barlaan at Josaphat (Actual Lessons in Guiding People to Truth, Based on the Holy Works of the Glorious Saints Barlaan and Josaphat), translated from Spanish into Tagalog by Fr Antonio de Borja and published by the Jesuit press in 1712. It was reprinted in the 19th century. A new critical edition of the work, Barlaan at Josaphat: Modernisadong Edisyon ng Salin ni Fray Antonio de Borja (Barlaan and Josaphat: A Modernized Edition of the Translation by Fray Antonio de Borja), edited by Virgilio S. Almario, was published by the Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU) Press in 2003.

The metrical romances of the Philippines came in two types: the dodecasyllabic awit and the octosyllabic korido. The romances were transmitted orally by the colonizers; they came to be produced by Filipinos and eventually written down beginning in the 18th century. They were circulated in manuscript, memorized, and sung by local bards. Their sources were the sagas of Charlemagne, Arthur, and the Fall of Troy; the legends and history of Spain and the Spanish libros de caballerias (chivalry books); local folklore; the lives of the saints and the Bible. Like the pasyon, the awit and korido were adapted for performance: they were quoted in the duplo (oral verse contests), and their plots were used in the carillo (shadowgraphs) and the moro-moro or komedya.

The printing of metrical romances likely began in the late 18th century, but no copies from that period have survived. In the 19th century, they were produced in large numbers in various local languages. In Tagalog alone there were around 200 titles published, among them Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Princesa Adriana sa Caharian nang Antioquia at nang Principe Pantinople sa Imperiong Francia (The Life of Princess Adriana in the Kingdom of Antioquia and of Prince Pantinople in the Empire of France), Corridong Mariquit Pag-aliwan na Buhay nang Princesa Celira (Corrido for Pleasant Entertainment on the Life of Princess Celira), Corrido at Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe Baldovino sa Caharian nang Daces (Corrido and Life Experienced by Prince Baldovino in the Kingdom of Daces), and Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe D. Juan Teñoso (Life Experienced by Prince Don Juan Teñoso), and Historia Famosa ni Bernardo Carpio (Famous History of Bernardo Carpio). The metrical romances of the 19th century were printed as thin, cheap pamphlets, and were sold not only in bookshops but also in sidewalk stalls, outside churches, and by itinerant peddlers. Metrical romances would continue to be printed until the early decades of the 20th century.

 

The most popular and most important of the Philippine metrical romances is Pinagdaanang Buhay ni Florante at ni Laura sa Kahariang Albania (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the Kingdom of Albania), written in awit form by Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas. It is significant for its artistry as an accomplished piece of Tagalog poetry and for its allegorical depiction of the sufferings of the Filipino people under the oppressive Spanish colonial regime. Florante at Laura first appeared in 1838, printed in Manila by the Colegio de Santo Tomas press. Since then, nearly 100 editions of the poem have been issued by various publishers. It has seen print in many forms such as prose versions and comic books, and in translations in other Philippine and foreign languages. It has also been adapted for various performances, such as drama and dance.

In the 19th century, drama began to be published in the Philippines, although plays had been staged in the country as early as 1598. The Imprenta de la Oceania Española published local editions of Spanish plays, such as Gracia del Canto (Grace of the Song) and La Conquista de Jolo (The Conquest of Jolo) in 1865; El Alcalde de Zalamea (The Mayor of Zalamea), 1880; and El Castigo sin Venganza (Punishment without Vengeance), 1881. The press also published Spanish translations of the works of Shakespeare and Goethe in the 1880s. Other plays published during this period were Antonio Robles’s one-act comedy Salir a Tiempo de Pobre (Leaving Poverty in Time), 1852, by Imprenta de Santo Tomas; and Federico Bouvier’s one-act comedy Amor de Alojamiento (The Love of Lodging), 1860, by Imprenta de los Amigos del Pais.

The komedya was the most popular form in Philippine theater during the Spanish colonial period. A play in verse typically about princes and princesses of Christian and Muslim kingdoms in Europe during the Middle Ages, the komedya was written in several Philippine languages. They were published during the last decades of the 19th century and the first decade of the 20th. Among the plays that saw print were Comedia de Atamante (Comedia of Atamante) and Comedia de Rolante y Claudina (Comedia of Rolante and Claudina), both printed in 1895 by Imprenta de los Amigos del Pais; Comedia de D. Juan Teñoso en Dos Actos (Comedia of D. Juan Teñoso in Two Acts), 1903, by Imprenta Dulumbayan in Santa Cruz, Manila; and Belmore y Enriqueta (Belmore and Enriqueta), 1904, by Fajardo y Compañia in Manila.

Prose narratives began to be published in the late 19th century. Among them were the works of Francisco de Paula Entrala, all printed by Imprenta el Porvenir Filipino: La Rubia de Quiapo (The Fair-Haired One of Quiapo), 1874; La Morena de Sampaloc (The Brown Maiden of Sampaloc), 1875; and Los Amores de un Pintor (The Loves of a Painter), 1874. The same press also printed Antonio Vasquez de Aldana’s Maria la Vivandera (Maria the Provisioner) in 1874. Another work by Vasquez, Los Tulisanes Negros, Novela de Jimenez (The Black Bandits, Novel of Jimenez), 1874, was published by Botella y Compañia. The Imprenta de la Oceania Española in Manila printed three works by Jose F. del Pan: El Aderezo de Paquita (The Ornaments of Paquita) in 1887; El Caballero de Copas (The Knight of Cups), 1887; and Otra Especie de Fausto (Another Kind of Faust), 1887.

The prose narrative recognized as the first Filipino novel, however, was published not in the Philippines but in Spain. This work is Ninay: Costumbres Filipinas (Ninay: Philippine Customs) by Pedro A. Paterno, printed by Imprenta de Fortanet in Madrid in 1885. It was likely published by Paterno himself—that is, he paid for its printing and arranged its distribution himself. This was a common course of action for many Filipino novelists who followed him, including Jose Rizal. Self-publishing in Philippine literature is not an unusual practice, and it continues to be observed to this day.

Rizal published Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) in Berlin, Germany, in 1887 and El Filibusterismo (Subversion) in Ghent, Belgium, in 1891. The novels, both written in Spanish, were satirical depictions of 19th-century Philippine society and were immensely influential in the Philippine Revolution against Spain. Noli Me Tangere was first translated into Tagalog by Pascual H. Poblete in an edition that came out in 1906, published by Rizal’s sister Saturnina Rizal-Hidalgo and printed by Limbagan nang El Mercantil in Manila. The first Tagalog translation of El Filibusterismo was by Patricio Mariano, published in 1911 by I. R. Morales in Manila. The novels have been translated into other languages, both local and foreign, and issued in numerous editions throughout the years up to the present. They have been adapted in various literary forms, such as children’s books and comic books, as well as for performance on stage and in film.

 

Reformist and Revolutionary Publications

In the late 19th century, aside from Rizal’s novels, publications appeared that pressed for the reform of Spanish rule in the Philippines and, later, revolution against the Spanish government. Early efforts were in the form of periodicals published by Filipino reformists in Spain: El Eco Filipino, a fortnightly magazine launched in 1871 and banned in 1872; the Revista del Circulo Hispano-Filipino, 1882, which folded after its second issue; and the weekly newspaper España en Filipinas, 1887. It was La Solidaridad, however, that became the principal organ of the propaganda movement. Founded on 15 Feb 1889 in Barcelona, the newspaper lasted until 15 Nov 1895. Edited initially by Graciano Lopez Jaena and later by Marcelo H. del Pilar, La Solidaridad published essays in Spanish exposing abuses of the Spanish authorities in the Philippines and demanding social and political freedom, education, and equality.

 

In the Philippines, writings critical of Spanish rule were distributed or published or distributed in clandestine or creative ways. Del Pilar’s Dasalan at Tocsohan (Prayers and Temptations/Jokes), ca. 1888, which parodied The Lord’s Prayer, the Hail Mary, the Apostle’s Creed, and the Ten Commandments, was published as a pamphlet in the format of novenas. Lopez Jaena’s Fray Botod (Friar Potbelly), ca. 1889, which depicted the vices and abuses of the friars, was circulated only in manuscript form.

Reformist and revolutionary periodicals were published in the country as well, led by the short-lived Diariong Tagalog, which appeared in 1882 and was edited by del Pilar. The more influential publication in the movement against the Spanish, however, was Kalayaan, the official organ of the Katipunan. Its first issue appeared in 1896, edited by Emilio Jacinto. It contained an editorial on solidarity and independence, a poem by Andres Bonifacio, a manifesto by Jacinto urging revolution, and an article by Pio Valenzuela on the abuses of friars and civil guards. The publication was distributed in Manila and the neighboring provinces. It proved to be vital to the growth of the Katipunan, as the society gained thousands of new members after the first issue was released. The second issue of Kalayaan never saw print because the Philippine Revolution against Spain had broken out as it was being prepared.

From 1898 to 1910, some 33 nationalist periodicals were published. Among those which featured revolutionary literature were El Renacimiento, 3 Sep 1901–30 Jan 1910; Ang Bayang Kahapis-hapis, 1899, which published articles and poetry; Filipinas, 1900-1901, edited by Aurelio Tolentino and containing articles, essays, and poetry; El Pueblo, a weekly illustrated newspaper published by Vicente Sotto in Cebu; La Alborada, 5 Oct 1901, a weekly periodical containing the works of Teodoro M. Kalaw, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, and Pacifico Victoriano; Muling Pagsilang, 1901-10, the Tagalog edition of El Renacimiento, which published articles, essays, and satirical caricatures; Asamblea Filipina, begun on 14 Oct 1907, which featured articles and poems; Balagtas, 1907-10, with writers Lope K. Santos, Faustino Aguilar, Isabelo de los Reyes, Julian Balmaseda, and Gabriel Francisco; Lipang Kalabaw, begun on 27 Jul 1907, an illustrated periodical written in a satirical manner; Ang Liwayway, 2 Nov 1907, a weekly Tagalog periodical featuring short stories, serialized novels, poetry, and a section, “Ang Bayan,” on nationalist writings; and Plaridel, 1 Jan 1907, which carried writings on Del Pilar.

 
 

Literary Publishing in Periodicals

Newspapers and magazines started to become important venues for literature at the turn of the century and became even more significant during the first decades of the American colonial period. While the literary section or supplement was only a portion of most magazines in English, those in Tagalog, Cebuano, Hiligaynon, and Ilocano thrived because of the serialized novels and the short stories. The dependence of the novel on periodicals for publication entailed the observance of certain formulas and conventions: a series of interweaving narratives to sustain the reader’s interest, simple characterization, and language that resorts to formulaic and stock phrases. Ang Kapatid ng Bayan published the early Tagalog novels in serial form. Among them were Gabriel Beato Francisco’s Ang Cababalaghan ni P. Bravo (The Miracle of Fr. Bravo), 1899, which is acknowledged as the first published novel in Tagalog; Lope K. Santos’s Salawahang Pag-ibig (Inconstant Love), 1900; and Valeriano Hernandez Peña’s Rosa at Valerio (Rosa and Valerio), 1901.

The novel was a new genre in Philippine literature, and it was received enthusiastically by readers, who were said to have bought the periodicals of the day not for the news but for the serialized novels. The period 1905-21 is recognized as the “golden age of the Tagalog novel” for the rapid development of the genre and the prolific production of works.

It was more common for novels in Tagalog and the other local languages to be published as serials in periodicals rather than as books. The titles that appeared as books usually had been issued in installments in periodicals before being published in full-length, complete arrangement. Among the Tagalog magazines that regularly featured serialized fiction were Liwayway, first issued in 1922; Sampaguita, Dalaga, and Paraluman, 1925; Hiwaga and Aliwan in the 1940s; and Bulaklak in the 1950s. Liwayway, which initially appeared in 1922 as Photo News, was a weekly magazine published by Ramon Roces Publishing Company. With a circulation that grew from 3,000 to 80,000 in a few years, it became the primary literary outlet in Tagalog and eventually the most commercially successful magazine in the Philippines. Among its first writers were Fausto Galauran, Jose Esperanza Cruz, Antonio Sempio, Teofilo Sauco, and Deogracias Rosario. Liwayway periodically held literary contests, which served to launch the careers of some important writers in Tagalog. The contest in Jul 1925 led to the discovery of Gregorio Coching, Lazaro Francisco, Venancio Ascal, and Teodoro Virrey. Another contest in the 1960s started the careers of modernist writers Edgardo M. Reyes, Dominador Mirasol, Efren Abueg, Rogelio Ordoñez, and Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat.

During World War II, Liwayway was the only Filipino-owned publication allowed by the Japanese Military Administration to operate. Literary works were paid well to encourage writing in Tagalog, resulting in the submission of fiction and verses in haiku form. The best works of fiction of this period were compiled into an anthology titled Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943 (The 25 Best Pilipino Short Stories of 1943), 1944. Liwayway continues to be published today by the Manila Bulletin Publishing Corporation.

The periodicals Freeman, Bag-ong Kusog, Bisaya, and Tabunon Lamdag were the early outlets of Cebuano fiction, publishing the works of Angel Enemedo, Vicente Dutere, Natalia Bacalso, Florentino Suico, Vicente Flores, Vicente Arias, Jacinto Alcos, Elpidio Villacrucis. Bisaya, first issued in 1930, was published by Liwayway Publications in Manila. It dominated Cebuano magazine publishing. First edited by Vicente Padriga, it grew from an initial circulation of 5,000 to 60,000 in the 1960s. The magazine ceased operations during World War II, continued in 1946, and gave birth to a sister publication, Saloma, in 1948. A literary pamphlet, Saloma appeared monthly and carried a complete novel in a single issue. It lasted until the 1950s. Bisaya is published today also by the Manila Bulletin.

Kadapig sang Banwa and Makinaugalingon, 1913-41, the first outlets for Hiligaynon literature, featured the works of Magdalena Jalandoni, Flavio Zaragoza Cano, Serapion Torre, and Jose Nava. Hiligaynon, 1934-74, originally called Ang Bisaya sa Hiligaynon, was published by Ramon Roces Publications. The magazine started by featuring translations of the Tagalog novels of Fausto Galauran, Susana C. de Guzman, Gregorio Coching, and Belen Santiago. Later, it published the Hiligaynon novels of Ulises Vadlit, Rosalia Jalandoni, and Ramon Muzones. It also carried short stories, poems, and essays on the language and culture of the Ilonggo. The magazine sponsored short story contests in 1938 on the theme of social justice. Hiligaynon, along with all the publishing houses that were not state-sponsored, was closed down upon the declaration of martial law in 1972. It resumed publication in 1992 and is published today by the Manila Bulletin.

Bannawag, launched in 1934 and first edited by Magdaleno Abaya, was the main outlet for Ilocano writing. Although its first issues contained translated novels and borrowed illustrations from Liwayway, the magazine went on to feature the works of Ilocano writers like Leon Pichay, Hermogenes Belen, David Campañano, Godofredo S. Reyes, Liberato L. Marinas, Horencio Ma. Hernando, Benito S. de Castro, Arturo Centeno, and Benjamin Pascual. Bannawag ceased publication in 1941 at the outbreak of World War II and resumed in 1945. In 1956, the Ilocano orthography started to be patterned after Pilipino. In 1961, the magazine initiated literary contests. The circulation of Bannawag in the late 20th century was 40,000. It is published today by the Manila Bulletin.

In Bikol, among the venues for literary publication was the newspaper An Pabareta, first published in 1933 and resumed in 1954, which had among its editors Eustaquio Dino and Luis G. Dato. It featured Bikol poetry, stories, and essays. Other periodicals were Bikol Forum, begun in 1971, which published essays on Bikol culture; Bicol Chronicle, which occasionally published literary pieces; The Bicol Guardian (formerly Premier News and The Inquirer), begun in 1969, which published Bikol myths, legends, and folktales. Bikolandia Magazine, edited by Tomas Kilates, also published fiction, devoting majority of its pages to short stories and novels. It gave out annual awards to writers as well. The Rainbow, begun in 1965, a monthly Christian magazine, also published poetry.

For writings in English, periodicals also served as early important venues. Among the first to publish literary works were the Philippine Teacher, founded in 1904, which later became Philippine Education and then Philippine Magazine; Philippines Free Press, 1908; Woman’s Home Journal, 1919, the first women’s magazine in the Philippines; Philippines Herald, 1920, the first daily newspaper in English; the Manila Tribune, 1926; and Graphic, 1927. Three magazines in the 1930s were devoted solely to literary works: Expression, 1934; Story Manuscripts, 1935; and Veronica, 1937. The Graphic has survived up to the present and continues to publish literary works and sponsor literary contests.

The Philippine Magazine started by publishing syndicated press material from the United States, but by the 1930s it became the outlet for many significant Filipino works in English. Edited by A. V. H. Hartendorp from 1925 to 1941, the magazine published short stories by N. V. M. Gonzalez, Bienvenido Santos, Edilberto Tiempo, Manuel Arguilla, Amador T. Daguio, Francisco Arcellana, and others. The magazine also published in several installments Jose Garcia Villa’s “Definitions of Poetry,” as well as his poems; essays on literary theory and criticism, music, dance, architecture, and visual arts by Hartendorp, Ignacio Manlapaz, D. A. Hernandez, Pura Santillan-Castrence, Leopoldo Yabes, Amador T. Daguio, Salvador P. Lopez, and Arturo Rotor; anthropological essays by H. Otley Beyer; folktales, legends, and myths collected by Dean S. Fansler; a monthly humor column, Halo-Halo, written by T. Inglis Moore; and Four o’Clock in the Editor’s Office, a column that featured informal essays on discussions held by writers, artists, readers, and intellectuals who would meet for tea at 4:00 p.m. in Hartendorp’s office.

Among the first student publications in English were the College Folio, initially issued in 1910, Philippine Collegian, and Literary Apprentice of the University of the Philippines (UP); The Coconut, 1912, of the Manila High School; and The Torch, 1913, of the Philippine Normal School. Other student publications that also became good training ground for writers were Sands and Coral of the Silliman University; Quill and Varsitarian Quarterly, University of Santo Tomas (UST); Ateneo Quarterly, Ateneo de Manila University; Advocate and Crossroads, Far Eastern University; UE Expression and Dawn, University of the East; Orion, St. Theresa’s College; National, National University; and Clay, University of Manila.

During World War II, nearly all the periodicals were shut down or sequestered, and new Japanese-sponsored or Japanese-directed publications appeared, such as Pillars, Shin Seiki–Bagong Araw–New Day, Filipina, and Philippine Review. The Japanese government discouraged the use of English and instituted Tagalog as the national language. In Jun 1942, Liwayway was allowed to reopen and soon resumed its position as the leading publication nationwide. The periodicals of the period published essays, poems, short stories, and serialized novels. Some guerrilla newspapers were published underground. Among them were Matang Lawin, Liberator, Ing Masala, and Ang Tigbatas.

 

Immediately after the war, Aliwan appeared and served as a new and important outlet for Tagalog fiction. Launched in Jul 1945, Aliwan was a periodical that was published in book form. Each issue was dedicated to a complete short novel. The publication changed its format in Jan 1946 and began carrying serialized novels and short stories. It was published by Palimbagang Tagumpay, which was partly owned by Ramon Roces, the publisher of Liwayway. It lasted until 1947. Other Tagalog magazines were produced during the early post-World War II period, such as Bulaklak, Ilang-Ilang, Malaya, Sinag-Tala, all launched in 1945, and Bituin, Silahis, and Paraluman, 1946. They also published novels in serial form and short stories.

 

Among the effects of the war on Philippine literature was the introduction of a new medium: the comic book, known locally as komiks. The first Philippine comic book was Halakhak Komiks, published in Manila late in 1946 by Jaime Lucas. It was patterned after the comic books brought in by the American soldiers during World War II. Halakhak featured comic strips, illustrated fiction, illustrated series on Filipino history and folklore, crossword puzzles, song lyrics with illustrations, Filipino riddles and proverbs, as well as editorials and editorial cartoons on the sociopolitical issues of the day. It ran for only 10 issues, but its influence lasted a long time. It broke the ground for the komiks, which would be a phenomenally popular and commercially successful form.

In 1947, Roces established Ace Publications, a firm dedicated to comic book publishing. The company launched Pilipino Komiks that year, followed by Tagalog Klasiks in 1949, Hiwaga Komiks in 1950, and Espesyal Komiks in 1952. All titles were published in Tagalog and issued fortnightly. Pilipino Komiks was the most popular, with its initial print run of 10,000 copies per issue in 1947 growing to 120,000 copies in 1961.

Following the lead of Ace Publications, many other comic book firms were established. Some were set up by magazine or textbook publishers, others by printing presses, and a few by komiks writers and artists themselves. Roces, too, formed other companies to produce more titles. So popular were the komiks that the writers and illustrators of the fiction they featured became household names. Among them were Tony Velasquez, Danny Velasquez, Francisco V. Coching, Pablo S. Gomez, Mars Ravelo, and Carlo J. Caparas. Many komiks characters also became icons in Philippine popular culture, such as Tony Velasquez’s Kenkoy, Danny Velasquez’s Trese, Ravelo’s Darna, and Caparas’s Panday.

By the early 1970s, there were around 80 komiks titles circulating in the market. The declaration of martial law on 21 Sep 1972 ceased the operations of the komiks industry. Publishing resumed eventually, with only the larger firms reopening and surviving. By 1986, 47 komiks titles were in circulation. Nearly all the publications appeared weekly; the most popular ones came out twice a week. Komiks continued to be produced up to the early years of the 21st century, but their quality and quantity have been in steady decline since the mid-1980s.

Meant for mass audiences, the literatures in local languages that the magazines and komiks published were popular and, to a certain degree, commercial. The more serious works of prose and poetry appeared in journals published by literary groups and institutions. In 1982, the Philippine Literary Arts Council began publishing Caracoa, which featured poetry in English. The Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas launched Mithi in 1985; the journal produced around 20 issues. In 1987, the first issue of Ani appeared, published by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The 37th issue of Ani, commemorating its silver anniversary, was published in 2012; it featured poetry and prose in English, Filipino, Aklanon, Bikol, Chabacano, Ilocano, Kakanaey, and Pangasinan. In 2007, the UP Institute of Creative Writing launched Likhaan: The Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature, which features works in Filipino and English. The ninth edition of Likhaan was issued in 2015. The Artista at Manunulat ng Sambayanan (Armas) of the National Democratic Front (NDF) also publishes its journal of literature, Ulos, founded in 1972 and still active at present.

 

Literary Publishing in Book Form

Since the early 20th century, the publishing of literary books in the Philippines has been undertaken by writers, writers’ groups, printing and publishing firms, periodical-publishing companies, bookstores, and cultural, educational, and governmental institutions. Although periodicals were the more significant outlet of literature during the 20th century, the publishing of literary books flourished, particularly during the last decades of the period.

During the early decades of the 20th century, old literary forms continued to be published. Nineteenth-century versions of the pasyon, lives of the saints, and metrical romances were reissued and saw steady reprinting. Such texts were staples of new private enterprises such as that of Juan Martinez and of Praxedes Sayo Soriano, who were successful bookseller-publishers in Manila at that time. Martinez and Soriano also published novels.

In 1905, the first Tagalog novel in book form appeared: Ang Kasaysayan ng Magkaibigang si Nena at si Neneng (The Story of the Friends Nena and Neneng) by Valeriano Hernandez Peña, printed by Tipo-Litografia Germania in Manila and likely published by the author himself. Most Tagalog novels of the 20th century followed the course of Hernandez’s text, serialized initially in periodicals and then issued subsequently in complete arrangement as books.

 

Books of new Tagalog poetry began to be published, too, although they appeared much less frequently than books of fiction. Among the earliest publications of Tagalog poetry was Ang Pangginggera: Tulang Handog sa Kababaihang Tagalog (The Panggingge Card Player: Poem Dedicated to Tagalog Women) by Lope K. Santos, printed by Juan Fajardo in Manila in 1912.

Works in English started to be published in book form in the early 1920s, led by Zoilo M. Galang’s A Child of Sorrow, the first Filipino novel in English, published in 1921 by Galang himself. The other pioneering publications in English that followed were “Never Mind” and Other Poems by Procopio L. Solidum, initially published in Iloilo, ca. 1922, then in Manila in the same year; Daughters for Sale and Other Plays, 1924, by Carlos P. Romulo; Tales of the Philippines, 1923, by Galang; Filipino Poetry, 1924, edited by Rodolfo Dato; Filipino Love Stories, 1927, edited by Paz Marquez-Benitez; Philippine Prose and Poetry, 1927, published by the Bureau of Education for use in high schools, thus marking the beginning of the teaching of Philippine literature in English; and Philippine Plays, 1930, edited by Sol Gwekoh.

 

Writers’ groups played a significant role in the development of the publishing of literary books, as it was common practice among them to publish the works of their members. In the 1910s, the Tagalog writers’ groups Aklatang Bayan and Ilaw at Panitik published novels. The Philippine Book Guild, formed in 1936, published books of poetry and prose in English, among them Arturo Rotor’s The Wound and The Scar, 1937; Jose Garcia Villa’s Many Voices, 1939; and Manuel Arguilla’s How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife, 1940. The Philippine Writers League, established in 1939, published writings in English and reprints of Tagalog literary classics, such as Balagtas’s Florante at Laura, issued in 1941. Group publishing continues to be practiced today, as in the case of the High Chair group of poets, founded in 2002, which publishes their own and other poets’ works in a chapbook series.

Literary book publishing in the decades following World War II saw a steady growth, only to be curbed by martial law under the Marcos dictatorship, and then surged after the EDSA Revolt of 1986. In 1954, Alberto Benipayo, who operated the Benipayo Press and Photo-Engraving Company, launched the Philippine Contemporary Writers series with Children of the Ash-Covered Loam and Other Stories, a collection of short stories by N. V. M. Gonzalez. Under the series, Benipayo published around 11 books, which were novels, short story collections, and a poetry anthology by some of the day’s leading writers in English. The series lasted until the late 1960s.

Some writers who began as self-publishers became independent literary publishers. Among them were Andres Cristobal Cruz, Alberto S. Florentino, Rolando A. Carbonell, and F. Sionil Jose. Andres Cristobal Cruz, who was a staff member of Liwayway, was behind the Filipino Signatures book series of the 1960s. Estero Poems, Songs to My Beloved, and Other Songs: Sea Poems, 6 Clarius Poems is the title of its first publication, which is a collection of his own verse. He published around 17 books under the series, mainly poetry in English and Tagalog.

Alberto S. Florentino was a playwright who issued his own collection of one-act plays, The World Is an Apple and Other Prize Plays, 1959. In 1962, he launched the Peso Books series, with Jose Garcia Villa’s Poems 55 as the first title. Around 20 other books of short stories, poems, and essays in English appeared under the series. In 1973, Florentino published two other series: Makata, which featured the poetry of honored writers such as Balagtas, Rizal, Villa, Jose Corazon de Jesus, Amador Daguio, Luis Dato, Carlos Bulosan, and R. Zulueta da Costa; and Storymasters, featuring the short stories of Paz Marquez-Benitez, Paz Latorena, Loreto Paras-Sulit, Amador Daguio, Sinai Hamada, A. E. Litiatco, Arturo Rotor, and Francisco Arcellana. Florentino published around a hundred books by various authors.

Rolando A. Carbonell published his collection of poetry and prose, Beyond Forgetting, 1961, under the Horizons Book House imprint. It was a successful effort, with more than 20,000 copies sold in several reprints. He published other books of poetry by other authors.

F. Sionil Jose established the Solidaridad bookshop and publishing house in 1965. He published the magazine Solidarity and literary books, mainly his own novels. In the mid-1980s, he began to produce a series of translations of Southeast Asian novels by such authors as Pramoedya Ananta Toer and Mochtar Lubis. The translations were in Filipino; 19 books were published under the series. To this day, Jose maintains his bookshop and publishing activities, as well as his writing.

Writers’ groups continued to be active in book publishing, with some producing anthologies containing the works of their members. The poetry group Galian sa Arte at Tula or GAT, formed in 1973, has produced Gatilyo (Trigger) and the Galian series. Another organization of poets, Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo or LIRA, 1985, has published Unang Bagting (First Chord), 1988; Parikala (Irony), 1990; and Ikatlong Bagting (Third Chord), 2003. Its latest anthology, LIRA 30: Tatlong Dekada ng Makatang LIRA, was released in 2015. Katha, a group of fictionists writing in Filipino, 1987, has issued five anthologies so far: Engkwentro: Kalipunan ng mga Akda ng mga Kabataang Manunulat (Encounter: Anthology of Works by Young Writers), 1989; Habilin (Message before Leaving) and Impetu (Impetus), 1991; Alagwa (Surge), 1997; Relasyon (Relationships), 1999; and Kuwentong Siyudad (City Stories), 2002. The Women Writers in Media Now or WOMEN published the pioneering anthologies of women’s literature Filipina 1, 1984, and Filipina 2, 1985. Underground novels like Sebyo, by Carlos Humberto (pseud.), 1990, and Si Tatang sa Tungki ng Ilong ng Kaaway (Tatang on the Tip of the Enemy’s Nose), 1991, were published by the National Democratic Front’s cultural arm called Linang, or Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan.

University presses have contributed to literary book publishing. The University of the Philippines Press, founded in 1965, and the Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1972, publish books of classic and new fiction, poetry, and drama. The De La Salle University (DLSU) Press, 1983, now De La Salle University Publishing House, issued a few literary titles in the 1980s and 1990s, but its literary interests now are focused on criticism and theory. The UST Publishing House, since its establishment in 1996, has become an active producer of books of contemporary literature.

In 1986, the presses of ADMU, DLSU, and UP entered into a consortium for a six-year project called the Panitikan series, which aimed to reissue some out-of-print, local classics and to make accessible the little-known but significant literatures of some 12 non-Tagalog ethnolinguistic groups through Filipino and English translations. Among the titles in this series were Rogelio Sikat’s Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway (Blood at Daybreak), originally published in 1965, and Faustino Aguilar’s Pinaglahuan (Eclipsed), 1907. The translation series included Casabar Constante's Dagiti Mariing iti Parbangon (They Who Awaken at Dawn), originally serialized in Bannawag in 1956-57, and translated by Reynaldo Duque as Silang Nagigising sa Madaling Araw, 1993; Marcel M. Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano (Marcel M. Navarra: Selected Cebuano Stories), 1986, compiled, edited, and translated into Filipino and English by Teresita Gimenez-Maceda, and Sugilanon: Mga Piling Kuwentong Hiligaynon (Stories: Selected Hiligaynon Stories), 1991, translated into Filipino by Rosario Cruz-Lucero.

It was in 1986, too, when Tagalog romance novel series began to appear, first published by the firm Books for Pleasure. The popularity of the books led to the establishment of many companies dedicated to publishing such novels and to other publishers producing their own romance series. The most prominent and successful of them is Precious Pages Corporation, founded in 1992, which is the most prolific Tagalog romance novel publisher today.

Literary books have also been produced by the leading trade publishers. New Day Publishers, established in the 1970s, publishes fiction, drama, essays, and traditional literature. Kalikasan Press, begun in the mid-1980s and now defunct, published poetry, fiction, drama, and essays. Anvil Publishing, 1990, published new writings under their Contemporary Poetry and Contemporary Fiction series, as well as, briefly, popular romance novels and crime fiction series. Anvil has scaled back on their literary titles and currently publishes select authors only.

Children’s book publishing in the Philippines began in the 1980s and has grown to be a vibrant sector in the book industry today. Firms such as the pioneering Adarna House, established in 1980, Tahanan Books, 1991, and Lampara Books, 1997, publish traditional stories and songs, and new writings for children.

Some bookstores ventured into publishing, such as National Book Store, Bookmark, Goodwill Bookstore, Alemar-Phoenix Publishing House, and Popular Bookstore. Although the publishing activities of these enterprises mainly involved textbooks, they did issue literary works occasionally. Alemar-Phoenix published Stevan Javellana’s novel Without Seeing the Dawn in 1976. Among National Book Store’s publications was Nick Joaquin’s novel Cave and Shadows, 1983. In the 1990s, Bookmark published new editions of the works of Joaquin, Francisco Arcellana, and N. V. M. Gonzalez, and new translations of Rizal’s novels.

Literary contests, which serve to generate literary production, also provide material for publication. Winning entries of literary contests, such as the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, the Gawad CCP sa Panitikan, and the Gawad Collantes of the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, are published by the sponsoring institutions. The winning entries of the Centennial Literary Prize of 1998, which was held in commemoration of the independence of the Philippines, were published by the UP Press.

 

Literary Publishing in Digital Form

Philippine literature has an active presence on the Internet through the websites established and managed by authors, scholars, students, and various institutions of culture, education, and literature. Panitikan.ph, a joint project of the Likhaan Foundation, the UP Institute of Creative Writing, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), features new prose and poetry. High Chair publishes an online journal of poetry, launched in 2002 and now on its 19th issue. The electronic scholarly journal Kritika Kultura of the ADMU English Department has a literary section, which carries new fiction and poetry. There are also many blogs that publish Philippine literature, including regional writings. Some sites reproduce traditional and classic works; others feature new, original material.

 
 

The websites of periodicals that publish literature also maintain the presence of Philippine literature online. The Philippines Free Press operates an online site featuring selected materials from their archive, while the Philippines Graphic offers online versions of their magazine issues. Armas of the NDF has versions of its journal Ulos available online.

The publishing of electronic books is still at an early, tentative stage as of mid-2014. Among the publishers of literary books, only the UP Press has begun to issue e-book versions of its titles and only a small selection of literary works. Many old works of Philippine literature, however, such as early Tagalog novels and poems, have been made available for free in electronic-format digital libraries, such as Project Gutenberg.

 

The Publishing of Literary Scholarship

Literary scholarship is generally published by university presses, research centers, and institutes, all of which put out books, journals, monographs, and occasional papers. Most of these organizations are attached to institutions of higher learning and are usually managed by faculty and research staff. While the majority of publishing and publishing-related organizations are in Metro Manila, some scholarly publishers that are in other regions are the Cordillera Studies Center, the De La Salle Bacolod Research Center, the University of San Carlos publication office and its Cebuano Studies Center, and the Mindanao State University publication office.

Books on Philippine literary criticism and literary history have been published mainly by the presses of UP, ADMU, and DLSU. St. Scholastica’s College, through the Babaylan Publishing Collective of its Institute of Women’s Studies, has published some books on feminist literature and criticism. Anvil Publishing, although a trade publisher, has issued a few titles of local literary scholarship and manuals on the teaching of Philippine literature.

There are a few academic journals dedicated to literary studies, such as Kritika Kultura of the ADMU English Department and the Journal of English and Comparative Literature of the Department of English and Comparative Literature of UP Diliman. Articles on Philippine literary criticism and literary history have also occasionally appeared in the journals Philippine Studies of the ADMU, Humanities Diliman of UP Diliman, and Bulawan of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Written by Joi Barrios, Glecy Atienza, and Carol Afan updated by Patricia May Jurilla, with notes from Esther Pacheco, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava, Resil B. Mojares, Hermilinda Lingbaoan-Bulong, and Maria Lilia F. Realubit

The Publishing of Literary Scholarship

Literary publications refer to works of drama, poetry, and prose produced in print or digital form as books or as pieces in journals, newspapers, and magazines. Literary books may be individual or collected works by a single author or anthologies of various works by multiple authors. The term literary publishing refers to the process of production: from the selection and editing of the literary work for publication, to the printing or uploading and distribution or dissemination of the final version of the work.
The Early Printing Presses

During the Spanish colonial period, the religious orders owned the printing presses and thus dominated the publishing of literary as well as nonliterary works. From 1593 to 1811, more than 1,000 titles were published in the Philippines. Majority of these works were religious, such as church regulations, homilies, lives of saints, novenas, pastoral letters, pasyon, and spiritual guides. Among the published secular works were grammars and vocabularies of various Philippine languages, historical accounts, treatises on logic, and scientific texts. Miscellaneous tracts on government matters such as decrees and regulations were also produced.

The Dominicans produced the first books of the Philippines. In 1593, the order published Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala (Christian Doctrine in Spanish and Tagalog), with the material based on the Tagalog translations of Fr Juan de Plasencia, which had been edited by other priests. That same year, the Dominicans also published X?nkè S?ngsh? G?om?-xiàn Zhuàn Wújí Ti?nzh? Zhèngjiào Zh?nchuán Shílù; A Printed Edition of the Veritable Record of the Authentic Tradition of the True Faith in the Infinite God, by the Religious Master G?om?-xiàn, 1593, or Hsin-k’o Seng shih Kao Mu-hsien Chaun Wu chi T’ien chu Cheng Chiao Chen-ch’uan Shih lu in the Wade-Giles system. This is a treatise on theology, cosmography, and natural history written by Fr Juan Cobo, the G?om?-xiàn (or Kao Mu-hsien) of the title. Both books were printed in Manila, using a method called xylography, which involves the use of woodblocks.

article.value: In 1604, typography, which is printing by movable type, was introduced in the Philippines by Fr Francisco Blancas de San Jose and the Chinese Christian printer Juan de Vera. Two books were produced that year by the Dominican press using the new method: Libro de las Quatro Postrimerias del Hombre en Lengua Tagala, y Letra Española (The Book on the Four Last Things of Man in Tagalog and Spanish) and Ordinationes Generales Provintiae Sanctissimi Rosarii Philippinarum (The General Ordinances of the Philippine Province of the Holy Rosary).

The other religious orders also published their works through their own printing presses. The Augustinians established theirs, the second in the Philippines, in 1618. They had imported the machinery from Japan in 1565 and set it up in Bacolor, eventually moving to Manila in 1621. In 1623, they sold the press to the Jesuits. The Augustinians established another printing press in 1886 in Guadalupe, transferring it to Malabon in 1890, where it was known as Pequeña Imprenta del Asilo de Huerfanos de Nuestra Señora de la Consolacion. With the machinery they had acquired from the Augustinians, the Jesuits established their printing press in 1623 at the Colegio de San Ignacio in Manila, and used it to print their works until their expulsion in 1768. Returning to the Philippines after a hundred years, they acquired another press in 1897 and printed the publications of the Jesuit Weather Observatory in Manila.

The Franciscans set up their printing press in Sampaloc, Manila, in 1692, then moved it to Tayabas, now Quezon, in 1700. This press was transferred to several places: the Franciscan convent in Manila from 1705 to 1712; the Convent de la Candelaria in Dilao, now Paco, from 1713 to 1714; again, in Manila, from 1714 to 1736; and the Convento of Our Lady of Loreto in Sampaloc, where it stayed until 1822.

The early printing presses were initially operated by Chinese immigrants. In the early 17th century, Filipinos became active in printing, with the Tagalog Tomas Pinpin as the leading figure among them. In 1610, the Dominican press published Blancas de San Jose’s Arte y Reglas de la Lengua Tagala (Grammar and Rules of the Tagalog Language), which was printed by Pinpin. That same year saw the publication of Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila (A Book for the Tagalog to Study the Spanish Language), the first book authored by a Filipino; it was printed by another Tagalog, Diego Talaghay, also for the Dominican press. In 1613, Pedro de San Buenaventura’s Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala (Vocabulary of the Tagalog Language) was printed by Pinpin and Domingo Laog, also a Tagalog.

As printing progressed in the Philippines, books written by Spanish priests in other local languages were published. The first of these were Doctrina Christiana Rob. Bellarmini in Linguam Bisayam Translata in Visayan by Cristobal Jimenez, issued in 1610; Arte de la Lengua Pampanga (Grammar of the Kapampangan Language) by Francisco Coronel, 1617; Libro a Naisuratanamin a Bagas ti Doctrina Cristiana in Ilocano by Francisco Lopez, 1621; and Arte de la Lengua Bicolana (Grammar of the Bikol Language) by Andres de San Agustin, 1647.
The Growth of Printing in the 19th Century

In the late 1830s, with Manila opened to international trade and other cities following suit, private commercial presses began to be established in the Philippines. Among the more prominent enterprises in Manila were Los Amigos del Pais, founded in 1846; Ramirez y Giraudier, 1858; Don Esteban Balbas, 1880; and Chofre y Compañia, 1880. This development would lead eventually to breaking the monopoly on printing and publishing held by the religious orders. It also ushered in technological advances in printing. In 1847, Fr Marcial Funcia Ramos introduced the first iron press in the country. He also replaced the use of papel de arroz (rice paper) and papel de china (Chinese paper) with papel de hilo (linen paper) for quality printing, Belgian paper for newspapers, and French paper for other works.

Lithography, a printing method using stone surfaces, was introduced in the Philippines by a German, George Oppel, in 1858. Collaborating with the firm of the Spanish printers Manuel Ramirez and Baltasar Giraudier, Oppel printed the La Ilustracion Filipina, the first illustrated periodical in the Philippines. The Carmelo and Bauermann Printing Press, established in 1887 by Eulalio Lakandula Carmelo and William Bauermann, also utilized the lithographic process.

article.value: Cavite was reported to have a printing press as early as 1814 with Tomas de Oliva, a Filipino, as its regent. In Cebu, Domingo de Escondrillas established the first printing press in 1873. The first printing press in Iloilo was Imprenta Enriqueta, which published the province’s first newspaper, the Hoja Volante, in 1875. Mariano Perfecto established the Imprenta La Panayana in Mandurriao, Iloilo, in 1877. The press survived until 1965, publishing not only religious books but also sarsuwela, korido (metrical romance), nobela (novel), and berso (verse). In 1892, Perfecto also established the Imprenta Sagrada Familia in Nueva Caceres, now Naga City, which published religious pamphlets, metrical romances, and devotionals. In Vigan, Ilocos Sur, Imprenta Ecclesiastica was operating in 1884. In Manila, Sampaloc became the center of the printing industry, with presses operating in Daang Imprenta, now G. Tuason. Among the establishments found in this area were the Imprenta de Sampaloc, 1838-46, owned by the Spaniard Antonio de Llanes y Valdez; the Plana y Compañia, 1870-82, later placed under the direction of Salvador Chofre y Compañia, 1882-98; La Opinion and El Eco de Filipinas, 1889-93, with Iñigo Ed. Regalado as regent; and Manila Imprenta de Santa Cruz, owned by a Filipino, Jose de Jesus y Rosario.
Literary Publications during the Spanish Colonial Period

Philippine literary publishing began in the early 17th century when Tagalog poetry appeared as supplementary material in religious publications. Local literature came to be published in books of their own beginning in the 18th century. Owing to censorship enforced by the Spanish government, the Church monopoly on printing, and the interests of the authors who were mostly members of the clergy, the literature that appeared in print was primarily religious and didactic. The publications were in the forms of the pasyon, the “life of the saint,” and the metrical romance. In the 19th century, when secular literature was allowed to be published, the works that appeared were mainly in the metrical romance form.

The pasyon is a verse narrative of the Passion of Christ. The first such work was Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola at Ipinanagang sa Cataastaasang Poong Jesus Nazareno (Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse and Dedicated to the Highest Lord Jesus the Nazarene), written by the Tagalog printer and author Gaspar Aquino de Belen. It was published in 1703 by the Jesuit press in one volume together with Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Commendation for the Soul of the Dying), a Tagalog translation by Aquino de Belen of the Spanish version of Ordo Commendationis Animarum by Fr Thomas de Villacastin. Other Tagalog versions of the pasyon appeared after Aquino de Belen’s work: Pasion de Nuestro Señor Jesucristo (Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ) by Don Luis Guian, published in 1740; Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader) by an anonymous writer, 1814; and El Libro de la Vida: Historia Sagrada con Santas Reflexiones y Doctrinas Morales para la Vida Cristiana en Verso Tagalo (The Book of Life: Sacred History with Pious Reflections and Moral Teachings for the Christian Life Written in Tagalog Verse) by Fr Aniceto de la Merced, 1852.

The Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal was the most popular of all the Tagalog versions of the pasyon. It came to be known as the Pasyon Pilapil, after Fr Mariano Pilapil, one of the several priests who revised the original anonymous text. Various versions of the pasyon in the other local languages began to appear in the mid-1880s. Pasyon works continue to be printed to this day. Aside from being read aloud or chanted as the pabasa (reading) during Holy Week, the pasyon has also been adapted for stage as the sinakulo (passion play), which is performed during the Lenten season as well.

The “life of the saint” form was written in prose or verse. These accounts of the lives and deeds of saints appeared in brief form as prefatory material in novenas or in extended form as narratives in pamphlets, some as full-length books. One particularly popular book was Aral na Tunay na Totoong Pagaacay sa Tauo nang manga Cabanalang Gaua nang Manga Maloualhating Santos na sina Barlaan at Josaphat (Actual Lessons in Guiding People to Truth, Based on the Holy Works of the Glorious Saints Barlaan and Josaphat), translated from Spanish into Tagalog by Fr Antonio de Borja and published by the Jesuit press in 1712. It was reprinted in the 19th century. A new critical edition of the work, Barlaan at Josaphat: Modernisadong Edisyon ng Salin ni Fray Antonio de Borja (Barlaan and Josaphat: A Modernized Edition of the Translation by Fray Antonio de Borja), edited by Virgilio S. Almario, was published by the Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU) Press in 2003.

The metrical romances of the Philippines came in two types: the dodecasyllabic awit and the octosyllabic korido. The romances were transmitted orally by the colonizers; they came to be produced by Filipinos and eventually written down beginning in the 18th century. They were circulated in manuscript, memorized, and sung by local bards. Their sources were the sagas of Charlemagne, Arthur, and the Fall of Troy; the legends and history of Spain and the Spanish libros de caballerias (chivalry books); local folklore; the lives of the saints and the Bible. Like the pasyon, the awit and korido were adapted for performance: they were quoted in the duplo (oral verse contests), and their plots were used in the carillo (shadowgraphs) and the moro-moro or komedya.

The printing of metrical romances likely began in the late 18th century, but no copies from that period have survived. In the 19th century, they were produced in large numbers in various local languages. In Tagalog alone there were around 200 titles published, among them Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Princesa Adriana sa Caharian nang Antioquia at nang Principe Pantinople sa Imperiong Francia (The Life of Princess Adriana in the Kingdom of Antioquia and of Prince Pantinople in the Empire of France), Corridong Mariquit Pag-aliwan na Buhay nang Princesa Celira (Corrido for Pleasant Entertainment on the Life of Princess Celira), Corrido at Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe Baldovino sa Caharian nang Daces (Corrido and Life Experienced by Prince Baldovino in the Kingdom of Daces), and Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe D. Juan Teñoso (Life Experienced by Prince Don Juan Teñoso), and Historia Famosa ni Bernardo Carpio (Famous History of Bernardo Carpio). The metrical romances of the 19th century were printed as thin, cheap pamphlets, and were sold not only in bookshops but also in sidewalk stalls, outside churches, and by itinerant peddlers. Metrical romances would continue to be printed until the early decades of the 20th century.
