text:
Organizations are groups of writers who come together for a variety of purposes. Writers may organize themselves because of a common worldview, political ideology, or intellectual temperament. Others form groups for publication and workshop projects. Writers have also been known to get together for the sake of literary fellowship and sharing of artistic output, with some ritualistic elements involved. Groups outside of Manila have strengthened their ranks so that they may continue to assert regional writing and identity, in the process contributing to the development of a multiethnic body of national literature.

A listing of the history of writers’ groups is essential for two reasons. One, it gives a picture of how writers’ groups have influenced literary trends and movements. Second, it shows how writers may have influenced one another’s works.

The origins of literary organizing in the Philippines can be traced back to the reform movement, 1882-96. The prime movers of the reform movement based in Spain chose to publish critical, often satirical, essays about the Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. These writers, among them Jose Rizal and Marcelo H. del Pilar, used the newspaper La Solidaridad as the venue for their campaign for reforms. While it is debatable that these propagandists organized themselves formally as a “literary group,” one cannot deny that these writers were bound by a common desire to work for a political cause through their writings.

 

The oldest literary society in the country could be the Liceo-Artistico Literario, established in 1879 to promote Spanish letters in the Philippines and to establish “professional chairs of literature, drama, music and painting.” Emiliano Olano became the president of this organization, which lasted for only three years but which succeeded in launching two projects. One was the publication of a weekly (later, fortnightly) magazine, Revista del Liceo Artistico-Literario, 1879. It came out with six issues. The editor in chief, Francisco de Marcaida, a Filipino, had a staff of 21 Spaniards and three Filipinos, many of them award-winning prose writers and poets.

The other project was a literary contest. Two contests were held by the Liceo: one in 1879 and another in 1880, to commemorate the 264th death anniversary of Miguel de Cervantes. Jose Rizal’s entries won in both contests: “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth) in 1879 and “El Consejo de los Dioses” (The Council of the Gods) in 1880.

The core activity of literary groups active during the last decade of the 19th century and the first decade of the 20th century was the tertulia, or a gathering of artists, lovers of art and culture, and friends who discuss a variety of topics. These gatherings provided venues for the study of works of other writers, poetry readings, literary discussions, and debates on the political issues of the period.

The tertulia sponsored by the Academia de la Lengua y Literatura, founded in 1892 at the residence of Vicente Ilustre by Macario Adriatico, attracted the best writers of the period. Among its 50 members, then university students, were Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Gregorio Aguilera, Luis Luna, and Cecilio Apostol. By 1894, the organization was holding its gatherings at Epifanio de los Santos’s residence in Intramuros. New members were Rafael Palma, Clemente Jose Zulueta, and Manuel Guerrero. Others who were reported to have joined the literary tertulias of the Academia were Emilio Jacinto and Juan Sumulong.

Another literary club of the period was El Jardin de Epicuro, founded by Fernando Ma. Guerrero. The members of this group were modernist writers like Sixto Roces, Feliciano Basa, Jose R. Teotico, Flavio Cano Zaragoza, Alejo Valdez Pica, Jose Gavira Hernandez, and Jesus Balmori. This group discussed, among other things, the works of Ruben Dario, a Spanish writer who greatly influenced their works.

The tertulias of Liceo, the Academia, El Jardin, and other groups attracted the participation of Tagalog writers such as Iñigo Ed. Regalado.

Tagalog writers started to form groups during the first decade of American colonial rule. Aklatang Bayan was formed in 1910 in Tondo, Manila, with Rosauro Almario and Gerardo Chanco elected president and secretary, respectively. The Aklatang Bayan’s objectives, published in the newspaper Renacimiento Filipino, included fighting “bad” habits and beliefs in politics, religion, and everyday life (Almario 1984, 54).

 

 

Among the activities sponsored by the Aklatang Bayan were weekly meetings that featured poetic orations and songs. The group also sponsored contests and propagated the national language. The Aklatang Bayan celebrated Balagtas Day, 2 Apr, by staging literary jousts in several towns in Bulacan: Baliuag, 1915; Meycauayan, 1916; and Bigaa (now Balagtas), 1917. Aklatang Bayan drew its strength from the popularity of its members, many of whom were the leading writers of the period whose activities were featured in the dailies. Active in the group were Lope K. Santos, Carlos Ronquillo, Faustino Aguilar, Benigno Ramos, Patricio Mariano, Pedro Gatmaitan, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Severino Reyes, Nemesio Caravana, Amado V. Hernandez, Leonardo Dianzon, and Aniceto Silvestre. Its two other presidents were Precioso Palma, 1915, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda, 1920, who led the group until his death in 1947.

It is said that discontent with the “academic taste” of Aklatang Bayan became the basis for the founding of Ilaw at Panitik (Lumbera 1967, 386). Organized during the early 20th century, the group was headed for a long time by Jose Esperanza Cruz. It was one of the biggest and most popular of the literary societies, and had among its members the likes of the Tagalog short story pioneer Deogracias A. Rosario, the much-acclaimed poet Jose Corazon de Jesus; poet Teodoro Gener; poet, novelist, journalist, and labor leader Amado V. Hernandez; and poet-playwright Cirio H. Panganiban. Jose Esperanza Cruz, editor of the Liwayway for more than 20 years, became the first president of Ilaw at Panitik.

In Aug 1915, Cirio H. Panganiban explained that “Ilaw,” or light, referred to the belief and confidence of the writer, whereas “Panitik,” or pen, referred to a literature committed to the independence of the country. Other literary organizations active during the first decade were Samahang Mananagalog, Kapisanang Sisne, Dunong Ginto, Florante at Laura, Aklatang Barusaga, all of which were in Tondo, and Aklatang Balagtas in Sampaloc.

In 1935, at the residence of Alejandro G. Abadilla in Santa Cruz, Manila, the young writers of Tagalog literature formed the Kapisanang Panitikan. The group was a reaction to the older Aklatang Bayan and Ilaw at Panitik, whose members were being published in major outlets like Liwayway.

In a statement, the members of the Kapisanang Panitikan described their group as “sakdalista at aristokrata,” because like the radical peasant group also called Sakdalista, it rejected the reigning aesthetic in Tagalog literature and it was ready to be alienated from the mainstream (Almario 1984, 134). This group, led by Abadilla, founding vice president, and Clodualdo del Mundo, founding president, “was determined to be ‘modern,’ in the sense that it was to diverge from the traditional along lines being pursued by the writers of Philippine English literature” (Lumbera and Lumbera 1982, 112). Among the members of Panitikan were Teodoro Agoncillo, Brigido Batungbakal, Salvador Barros, Epifanio Gar. Matute, Teo S. Buhain (founding secretary), Fernando Monleon, Genoveva Edroza-Matute, Pablo Glorioso, Jesus Arceo, Cresencio Cruz Torres, Manuel Car. Santiago, Gonzalo K. Flores, Manuel Principe Bautista, and Ruben Vega.

The members of Panitikan held a book-burning rally at Plaza Moriones in Tondo in 1940, the intent of which was to destroy works that they thought did not merit being passed on to posterity (Lumbera 1967, 387). Many of what they burned were the works by the older writers. The book burning was a symbolic event which showed the rift between the older writers and the members of Panitikan. In 1938, Panitikan managed to put out a magazine also called Panitikan. The organization endured for decades and lasted until the 1970s.

In the late 1920s, a group of students of the University of the Philippines (UP) formed the UP Writers’ Club, “impelled by a noble aim to elevate to the highest pedestal of possible perfection the ENGLISH language in the Islands.” The group’s original motto was “ART shall not be a Means to an End but AN END IN ITSELF” (Abad and Manlapaz 1989, 253). Among the founders of the club were the following: Casiano Calalang, Augusto Catanjal, Loreto Paras, Arturo Rotor, Felicidad Dani-Martin, Eugenio P. Santos, Vicente del Fierro, Francisco Tonogbanua, Jose M. Hernandez, Paz Latorena, Gabriel Tuazon, and Jose Garcia Villa.

 

 

The constitution of the UP Writers’ Club outlines the following objectives: foster unity among its members; encourage and cultivate responsible and relevant writings in the university and society; provide a link between established and developing writers in the university; and promote literary exchange between the club and literary groups/programs outside the university and the country.

Among the most prominent members of the UP Writers’ Club before World War II were the following: Jose Lansang Sr, Angela Manalang Gloria, Federico Mangahas, Amador T. Daguio, Manuel Arguilla, Maria Kalaw-Katigbak, Juan Cabreros Laya, Maria Luna-Lopez, Sinai Hamada, Bienvenido Santos, Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, Nelly Xerez-Burgos, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Teofilo D. Agcaoili, Francisco Arcellana, Armando Malay, Leopoldo Yabes, Estrella Alfon, Manuel Viray, and Dominador Ilio.

Through the decades, the UP Writers’ Club counted among its members not only those who wrote professionally but also those who excelled in other fields. Among them are Gemino Abad, Napoleon Abueva, Mila Aguilar, Virgilio S. Almario, Pacifico Aprieto, Lorena Barros, Pura Santillan-Castrence, Benjamin Cervantes, Onofre Corpuz, Karina Constantino David, Ricaredo Demetillo, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Felix Fojas, Ibrahim Jubaira, Paula Carolina Malay, Resil Mojares, Virginia Moreno, Hernando Ocampo, Ninotchka Rosca, Epifanio San Juan Jr, Edilberto Tiempo, Edith L. Tiempo, Kerima Polotan-Tuvera, and Alfred A. Yuson.

The Literary Apprentice was started by the club in 1927 and became its most enduring project. The quality of the works published in the literary magazine was such as to make the editors of the Philippine Magazine and of the Philippine Prose and Poetry textbooks reprint works first published in the Apprentice.

 

At around the time that Kapisanang Panitikan was founded, some Filipino writers using English also formed a radical group. Calling themselves the Veronicans, their “bold” stories were rejected for publications by magazines (Serrano 2009, 81). They published their works in three magazines that they themselves started: Expression, 1934, Story Manuscripts, 1935, which was mimeographed, and Veronica, 1935-36, all short-lived (Abad and Manlapaz 1989, 257-58).

Among the writers identified as Veronicans were Francisco Arcellana, Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, Manuel Arguilla, Ernesto Basa, Angel de Jesus, Oscar de Zuñiga, Lazaro Espinosa, Salvador Faustino, Lina Flor, Antonio S. Gabila, N. V. M. Gonzalez, Armando J. Malay, Hernando Ocampo, Pacita Pestaño, and Manuel Viray.

In the 1930s and early 1940s, some of the bilingual writers were members of both Panitikan and Veronicans. It was their involvement in the literary movement toward modernism that encouraged these writers to band together.

Probably the first women’s literary group was the Bachelorettes. They associated with the Veronicans in teas and literary gatherings (Ordoñez 1986, 2). Teresa Arzaga, Luisa Barrera, Nelly Xerez-Burgos, Corazon Juliano, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Sally Barrera, Olivia Calumpang, and Carmen Perez were the eight original Bachelorettes. Both the Veronicans and Panitikan members “saw themselves as literary rebels and avant-garde artists” (Lumbera and Lumbera 1982, 112).

In 1939, the Philippine Writers League was formed. Considered to be the first national writers’ group with a social orientation, it believed that literature must have “social content.” The League’s officers were the following: Federico Mangahas, president; Salvador P. Lopez, vice president; Jose A. Lansang, vice president; I. P. Caballero, vice president; and R. R. Roces Jr, treasurer. The formation of the league was a crystallization of the debate already begun some years earlier, and which continued after World War II, on the function of literature. On one side were Lopez and Arturo Rotor; on the other, A. E. Litiatco and Francisco Arcellana. The league followed the “alternative critical orientation” offered by Salvador P. Lopez in his essays, eventually published as Literature and Society, 1940. Lopez pointed out the “vacuousness” of Villa’s aestheticism (Lumbera and Lumbera 1982, 116). In 1940, the Philippine Writers’ League sponsored the Commonwealth Literary Contests to promote socially conscious literature and accordingly rewarded entries that were such, like Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s “Like the Molave.”

The Kalipunan ng mga Manunulat sa Wikang Pilipino (Kawika) was organized immediately after the Japanese-sponsored republic was proclaimed. At around this time, Tagalog was proclaimed as a national language, a development that had a significant impact on literature. The members of Kawika attended classes conducted by Lope K. Santos, who was then head of the Institute of National Language. Among those who enrolled were Francisco Arcellana, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Amadeo Dacanay, Lina Flor-Trinidad, N. V. M. Gonzalez, Paz Latorena, Juan C. Laya, Salvador Lopez, Maria Luna Lopez, Hernando Ocampo, and Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla. Little else is known about Kawika except that some members who were at that time primarily writing in English shifted to Tagalog. N. V. M. Gonzalez won an award for a short story published in Liwayway. H. R. Ocampo, who would later on be known as a painter, also produced fiction and poetry in Tagalog.

No other writers’ organization seemed to be active during the Japanese occupation. A few literary pieces were published in the Sunday Magazine; Philippine Review; Pillars, published by the Philippine Cultural Institute; Bagong Araw, Filipina, and Liwayway.

However, the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon or Hukbalahap, the main anti-Japanese resistance group in Central Luzon, had a cultural bureau that produced plays. Revolutionary songs and poetry were also produced by the guerrillas. Anonymous writers produced propaganda literature, but they did not form literary groups.

After the war, the Philippine literary scene suffered from a lack of literary outlets. Teodoro Agoncillo’s Malaya, founded in 1945, folded up after a brief period (Almario 1984, 153-54). Moreover, the commercial magazines did not seem to encourage writings that were not popular with the public.

It was in this context that the postwar writers produced their works. Manuel Viray, still reacting to the politics of the Philippine Writers’ League, organized the Filipino Writers’ Guild. The guild had the following objectives: advancement of the economic interests of the writer, publication of the books of its members, and cooperation with workers in allied trades and with the cause of unionism in the country. Viray thought that the guild should adopt simply the “spectatorial attitude” and “should be careful of writing which makes of doctrine the motive and end of writing” (Ordoñez 1986, 3).

Two other writers’ groups were active in the 1950s, the Ravens among the writers in English and the Kapisanang Aklat, Diwa at Panitik (Kadipan) among Tagalog writers.

Founded in 1951, the Ravens was an offshoot of the UP Writers’ Club. Among its original members were Pacifico Aprieto, Hilario Francia, S. V. Epistola, Virginia Moreno, Elmer Ordoñez, Maru Santaromana, Raul R. Ingles, Alejandrino Hufana, Bernardo de Leon, Andres Cristobal Cruz, and Armando Bonifacio. Most of them at that time were writing for either the Philippine Collegian, the official newspaper of the UP, or the Philippinensian, the UP yearbook. They were later joined by Adrian Cristobal, Morli Dharam, Nick Nicolas, Romy Chua, Danny Villanueva, and E. P. Patanne.

The origin of the group’s name is said to be Edgar Allan Poe’s poem. Members of the Ravens, however, claim no other cause but that they liked the sound of the word. The Ravens had as mentor N. V. M. Gonzalez, who conducted informal workshops at his residence as well as at that of Virginia Moreno on Juan Luna St, Tondo. The group also held poetry readings. The Ravens were influential in the 1950s because they occupied key positions in publications like the Literary Apprentice, the Philippine Collegian, and the Diliman Review. The Ravens continued to be active in the 1980s and the 1990s. In Nov 1975, they sponsored an International Poetry Festival, which was well attended by writers. The group published three anthologies of their works: The Ravens, 1980; The Ravens 2, 1996; and Ravens in Love, 2002.

 

At least two members became leading figures in the largest and most influential writers’ groups in the country. Adrian Cristobal was chairperson of the Unyon ng mga Manunulat ng Pilipinas in the 1970s and 1980s. Elmer Ordoñez was elected founding chairperson of the Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas (Panulat) in 1987.

Founded on 22 Oct 1950 at the Manuel L. Quezon Educational Institution (later University) in Quiapo, Manila, Kadipan had as its members aggressive, idealistic, and socially aware young writers from various colleges and universities in Manila. The organization’s objectives were to promote the Pilipino language, to generate a vigorous Philippine literature, and to expand the space allotted to the national language in campus papers. Because of its commitment to the development of the national language, the group had the support of the Pilipino departments of member schools as well as the Institute of National Language (Almario 1984, 198).

Among its first members were Ponciano Pineda (who later became the director of the Institute of National Language), Tomas C. Ongoco, Hilario Coronel, Pablo Bautista, Elpidio Kapulong, Benjamin Condino, C. C. Marquez Jr, Bienvenido Ramos, and Pedro Ricarte. They were joined later by Virgilio S. Almario, Efren Abueg, Domingo Landicho, Rogelio Mangahas, and Lamberto Antonio. These leading literary figures, as well as other members from Manuel L. Quezon University, the University of Santo Tomas, Philippine Normal College, Far Eastern University, Philippine College of Commerce, and UP, became very active in the projects of Kadipan in the 1960s.

Kadipan sponsored an annual literary contest, which lasted from 1956 to 1968. Winners were chosen from the poems, essays, or stories published in the school papers. Another valuable output of the group was the anthology Mga Piling Akda ng Kadipan (Selected Works of Kadipan), 1965, in Manila.

 

The Philippine Center of Poets, Essayists, Novelists (PEN) International was born in the late 1950s, with Alfredo T. Morales as chairman and F. Sionil Jose as national secretary. The local chapter held its first national writers’ conference in Baguio on 26-29 Dec 1958. Among the issues discussed were the state patronage of the arts, literature and politics, nationalism, and the problems of publishing. The PEN Philippine Center endured even during the martial law period. The group has hosted foreign writers, including Wole Soyinka, Richard Kim, Lin Yutang, Khushwant Singh, Hirabayashi Taiko, Hayako Sono, Norman Mailer, Gunter Grass, and Mario Vargas Llosa. It has been sponsoring several conferences on such topics as underground literature, protest theater, Filipino as the language of national literature, and feminist writing; and it continues to publish papers and resolutions on questions of freedom of expression, including protests against the disappearance of journalists and the Maguindanao Massacre in 2009. It also holds teacher-training workshops and forums around the country. Apart from F. Sionil Jose, other writers connected with the Philippine PEN are Bienvenido Lumbera, Charlson Ong, Elmer Ordoñez, Edgardo Maranan, Jose Wendell Capili, Herminio Beltran Jr, and Jun Cruz Reyes.

 

During the 1980s and the 1990s, prolific novelist F. Sionil Jose continued to be the prime mover behind the Philippine PEN. He has also been a moving force behind the Southeast Asian writers’ conferences participated in by young writers, mostly in their 30s. Jose is well known as owner of Solidaridad Publishing House, which puts out the quarterly journal Solidarity. Many members of the Philippine PEN contribute to this publication. Funded by the Ford Foundation, Solidarity has produced a substantial number of issues and has featured essays, poetry, fiction, and drama, as well as papers delivered during Southeast Asian writers’ conferences. The members of its editorial board are writers from Southeast Asia—among them, Mochtar Lubis, Edwin Thumboo, Sulak Sivaraska, and Isagani R. Cruz.

During martial law, several writers who were also members of the PEN became political prisoners. While they may have been imprisoned not primarily for their writings but because of their political activities, several fellow members encouraged other writers to petition for their release. This, plus the support of writers from other countries, eventually pressured the Philippine government to release them.

On 12 Oct 1962, a new organization, the La Solidaridad Filipino-Hispana Inc, was set up to promote the value of the Spanish language in the Philippines. Its incorporators were Dr Jose Maria Delgado y Salcedo, first Filipino ambassador to the Vatican; Dr Benjamin Barrera, dean of the UP College of Medicine; Dr Jesus M. Tan, director of the San Juan de Dios Hospital; Don Francisco Delgado, Don Antonio Delgado, and Dr Agustin Perez Lizano.

At around this time, Don Manuel Cuenco succeeded in having a law passed increasing the required 12 units of Spanish in college to 24. The Cuenco Law required the reading of the patriotic writings of Filipinos in Spanish. A very active organization, the Solidaridad organized radio and TV programs; published a bimonthly magazine for Spanish teachers titled El Maestro; opened Spanish-language and dance classes; and sponsored researches in Filipino music, dance, costume, and architecture. It compiled all books published in Spanish. Lectures were delivered by its members on various topics.

Two groups of poets became known in the 1960s for ushering in modernism in Tagalog poetry. One of these groups was the Manlilikha, whose leading lights were Virgilio S. Almario, Lamberto Antonio, Rogelio Mangahas, and Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, all based at the University of the East. The poems of the Manlilikha group were published in the pages of Dawn, the university’s militant campus paper, which at that time had a weekly circulation of 65,000. It is said that even the writers of Liwayway and Taliba eagerly awaited the works of these poets. In 1967, they came out with the anthology Manlilikha: Mga Piling Tula 1961-1967 (Creator: Selected Poems 1961-1967), edited by Rogelio Mangahas. This collection of new poetry was determined to prove to the literary public that modernism had arrived in Tagalog poetry (Lumbera and Lumbera 1982, 248).

The bagay poets, based at Ateneo de Manila University, were highly influenced by trends in European and American philosophy and literature. The group drew on the Imagists, a school of poetry formed in the first decade of the twentieth century. The word bagay literally means “thing” or “object.” The implication is that the poetry of the group is built on situational imagery. Bagay poems avoided sentimental and traditionally “poetic” subject matter. Instead, the bagay poets used ordinary experience, like hanging around in the cafeteria, coming home from the cinema, or apartment living. If a potentially emotional situation, such as a wake or a homecoming, were the subject of a piece, the use of concrete details, sharp sensual images, and precise, informal language prevented the poem from becoming maudlin.

A new kind of poetic discourse followed the Manlilikha and bagay period. The writers of the late 1960s and the early 1970s became more politically involved, joining not only literary organizations but mass rallies, demonstrations, and marches—activities characterizing the nationalist movement for social change known as the First Quarter Storm. Thus did poetry take on a radical voice. In 1971, these nationalist writers formed the Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan or PAKSA. This included some of the members of the Manlilikha and bagay group and new writers based in various colleges and universities.

The nationalist and progressive writers began organizing PAKSA in Jul 1970. A group met informally on 26 Sep 1970 at the Philippine College of Commerce (now Polytechnic University of the Philippines or PUP). They agreed to form an organization in order to safeguard writers’ rights against exploitative publishers and editors. They also passed a resolution to this effect and agreed on the new organization’s name.

The first official meeting was held on 23 Mar 1971 at the Philippine College of Commerce, attended by 16 writers. Elected officers of the Committee for the launching of PAKSA were Domingo Landicho as chairperson, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat as secretary general, and Bienvenido Lumbera, Rogelio Ordoñez, and Virgilio S. Almario as spokespersons.

The first activity was a demonstration on 2 Apr 1971, Balagtas Day, at Plaza Moriones, site of the book-burning activity of Panitikan in 1940. The demonstration carried the theme “Panulat para sa Pambansang Rebolusyong Pangkultura” (Writing for the National Cultural Revolution). Marching from Plaza Moriones to the National Library, PAKSA members were joined by members of the Kabataang Makabayan (KM), Samahang Demokratiko ng Kabataan, Samahang Molabe, Tanghalang Kamanyang, and Tanghalang Bayan, the last two being activist theater groups.

That same afternoon, several writers were being honored inside the National Library. Those who were members of PAKSA went out to meet the marchers and added the plaques they had just received to the pyre. This symbolized the writers’ rejection of reactionary literature (Almario 1984, 267).

PAKSA held a national workshop for writers on 24-25 Jul and 1 Aug 1971. An official congress was held on 18-19 Dec 1971. Bienvenido Lumbera was elected chairperson. The PAKSA manifesto espoused the view that since literature is part of culture and writers are a society’s conscience, writers must be committed to the creation of literature that speaks for the people—a mass literature that should forge the revolution against American imperialism and the installation of national democracy (Almario 1984, 268). True to its name and its acronym, meaning “theme,” the organization worked around the basic theme of protracted struggle in the field of culture and sought to create a literature that was purposive and oriented toward praxis, one that seeks to “expose and oppose” the evils of Philippine society and one whose social analyses and calls to action are carried out through its writers’ street activism and cultural work in schools and factories.

PAKSA, however, was short-lived. It was branded by the Marcos intelligence apparatus as a front of the Communist Party of the Philippines. With the declaration of martial law, many of its members either went underground or shifted to other forms of political work, thus preventing it from developing into a full-blown national organization of writers with an open national democratic orientation in literary production and other forms of cultural work.

On 21 Sep 1972, martial law was declared, heightening the contradiction between the establishment and colonial culture, on the one hand, and the Filipino, mass, democratic culture, on the other (Tiongson 1984, 5). Undaunted by the atmosphere of repression, writers continued to found literary organizations.

The concept of forming a “union,” which implied that, like workers, writers needed to organize to fight for their rights, was brought to focus by the establishment in 1975 of the Writers’ Union of the Philippines (WUP). It later became known as the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas (UMPIL). It was the largest group of writers in the country in the 1970s, and continues to be a viable organization with a roster of members and institutional support.

 

The first president of WUP or UMPIL was Adrian Cristobal, after whom the Adrian Cristobal Memorial Lecture at the annual UMPIL national convention is named. For many years Virgilio S. Almario was acknowledged as the prime mover behind the organization. Among its most active members during the early 1980s were T. D. Agcaoili, Lamberto Antonio, Teo Antonio, Arnold Azurin, Mike Bigornia, Andres Cristobal Cruz, Jose Y. Dalisay Jr, Ligaya David Perez, Conrado de Quiros, Ruby Gamboa-Alcantara, Alejandrino Hufana, J. Eddie Infante, Marne Kilates, Edgardo Maranan, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, Wilfrido Nolledo, Ponciano Pineda, Godofredo Roperos, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Luis V. Teodoro, Edilberto Tiempo, Rowena Tiempo-Torrevillas, and Rene O. Villanueva. Officers have included Almario, Salanga, Kilates, Bigornia, Mario Miclat, Karina Bolasco, Vim Nadera, Fidel Rillo, Rebecca T. Añonuevo, Roberto T. Añonuevo, and Michael M. Coroza.

The main activities of the organization are an annual literary awards, consisting of the Gawad Balagtas, given to outstanding writers in various genres, the Gawad Paz Marquez-Benitez, given to educators, and Gawad Pedro Bucaneg, given to literary organizations; an annual national convention, often revolving around a theme; conferences for teachers; poetry readings in various universities; and until 1995, the publication of its journal, Mithi. In 2013, it began the “UMPILan” interview series, which explores one aspect of Philippine literature.

In 1986, several officers and members of UMPIL resigned or became inactive in the organization because of political differences with other members. Thus was born another writers’ organization describing itself as a union, the Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat ng Pilipinas or Panulat. An unpublished document called the “Filipino Writers’ Declaration of 1986” led to the founding of the organization. According to this declaration, there was a need for a national organization of writers committed to the protection, promotion, and enhancement of the economic welfare of Filipino writers; such an organization of writers had an imperative task of defending the right to free expression; and the development and propagation of a national culture was among the tasks of writers at present. More than 300 writers signed the declaration.

Panulat describes itself as being committed to the welfare of its own members. Its program of action includes initiating dialogues between writers and editors, and between writers and publishers, film producers, donors, and various patrons of the arts, whether here or abroad, to secure writing grants, more and better outlets, and improved compensation for writers. It also recognizes that the problems of writers should be related to the larger problems of Philippine society. The Panulat declaration asserts that the group would also “support all national efforts at solving problems of underdevelopment, which are at the root of the economic difficulties writers suffer from and the general depression of opportunities in publishing and writing.” Elected founding chairperson and secretary-general during the first congress were Elmer M. Ordoñez and Reuel Molina Aguila, respectively. Bienvenido Lumbera and Nonilon V. Queaño succeeded them as chairperson and secretary-general of the organization, respectively.

Panulat sponsored a grassroots-writing workshop, a comics-writing workshop, a concert titled Panaghoy (Lamentation), and a conference on arts and literature which coincided with the 20th anniversary of PAKSA. Among those who have been elected to the Panulat board of directors and secretariat are Joi Barrios, JJ dela Rosa, Tala Isla, Jose F. Lacaba, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, Francine Medina, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Rolando Santos, Rolando B. Tolentino, and Ariel Valerio.

Panulat distinguishes itself from other writers’ unions and organizations by focusing on the organization and training of grassroots writers. In his opening remarks at the founding congress of Panulat in 1986, Ordoñez said that the purpose of the group was “to form a national writers’ union that looks after and beyond the needs of its members, committed to help the less fortunate in our society and having a stake in building a just, sovereign, and democratic country.”

In the 1980s, many groups were formed by those whose writing was focused on a particular literary genre. Among these organizations are the Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo or LIRA, 1986, and Katha, a group of fictionists, 1989.

 

LIRA was organized in 1986 by poets who attended the Rio Alma Poetry Clinic, named after Virgilio S. Almario, whose pseudonym is Rio Alma, at the Adarna House office on Quezon Ave. Vim Nadera was elected president. Among the most active members of the group were Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Suzette Flores, Luna Sicat, and Maningning Miclat. Mike Bigornia and Teo Antonio were advisers. The group describes itself as “bayanihan ng mga makata” (cooperative of poets). It has produced these anthologies of works by its members: Unang Bagting (First Chord), 1988; Parikala (Irony), 1990; Ikatlong Bagting (Third Chord), 2003; Lirang Pilak (Silver Lyre), 2010; and LIRA 30: Tatlong Dekada ng Makatang LIRA, 2015. Today LIRA holds its annual poetry clinic every Saturdays and Sundays for four months, often in UP Diliman. It is one of the longest-running literary training programs in the country. Almario, as workshop director emeritus, still actively oversees the sessions and gives lectures every now and then, while other senior members, like Michael Coroza, Rebecca T. Añonuevo, Roberto T. Añonuevo, and Baquiran, handle the regular sessions.

In 2008, LIRA began a nationwide outreach program called Sining ng Tugma at Sukat (later called Pambansang Edukasyong Pampanitikan) aimed at promoting literature and language through the teaching of native literary works and forms. More than 3,000 teachers and students from 300 public and private schools in more than 30 towns have participated in the program. The two-day seminar includes sessions on “Sining ng Tugma at Sukat” (Art of Rhyme and Meter) and “Sining ng Talinghaga at Tayutay” (Art of Metaphor and Figures of Speech), as well as writing workshops and special lectures. As a primarily training organization, a majority of its active members continue to be young, such as Edgar Calabia Samar, Giancarlo Abrahan, Mariane A. R. T. Abuan, Louie Jon A. Sanchez, John Enrico Torralba, Beverly Siy, and Phillip Kimpo Jr.

The idea to form a group of fictionists was explored in 1989 by Rolando B. Tolentino, JJ de la Rosa, Joi Barrios, Ricky Nuñez, and Francine Medina. Tolentino was elected founding president of Katha. Elected as officers were De la Rosa, Barrios, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Honorio Bartolome de Dios, and Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez. Other members were Luna Sicat, Vim Nadera, Eli Guieb, Joel Sayo, Abet Umil, Ian Victoriano, Noel Salonga, Ariel Valerio, Rolando Santos, Mes de Guzman, and Nenet Lachica.

A regular activity of Katha is its Sunday workshop, which has been held at various venues—among them, the Heritage Art Center, the residences of its members, and UP. These workshops have also served as venues for writers to interact. Among those who have given lectures for Katha are Mario Miclat, Gelacio Guillermo, Alice Guillermo, Romeo Dizon, Lualhati Bautista, and Jun Cruz Reyes. Fidel Rillo and Romulo Sandoval have served as advisers to the group.

Six anthologies have been published by Katha. These are Engkwentro: Kalipunan ng mga Akda ng mga Kabataang Manunulat (Encounter: Anthology of Works by Young Writers), 1989; Impetu (Impetus) and Habilin (Message before Leaving), 1991; Alagwa (Breakaway), 1997; Relasyon (Relation), 1999; and Kuwentong Siyudad (City Stories), 2002.

In 1988, a group of women writers formed the group Women Involved in Creating Cultural Alternatives (WICCA). Among its most active members were Marjorie Evasco, Fanny Llego, Grace Monte de Ramos, Merlinda Bobis, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Lina Sagaral Reyes, Nerissa Balce-Cortes, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, and Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. The group had several projects—among them, a bookshop, a research project about the babaylan (shaman) in Bohol, WICCA greeting cards, and several women’s workshops.

Two writers’ groups active at PUP were the Pambansang Linangan at Ugnayan ng mga Manunulat or PLUMA, led by Rogelio Ordoñez and Ave Perez Jacob, and the Pandayan ng Literaturang Pilipino or Pandaylipi, 1977, headed by Cesario Torres. PLUMA was a trisectoral organization of workers, students, and professional writers.

Other groups that held their own literary workshops and readings were the following: the Bestiario Writers’ Foundation, established in 1985, by Jose Y. Dalisay Jr, Isabel Banzon, Benedicto Bitonio, and Gina Apostol, and later joined by Charlson Ong, Anthony F. V. Serrano, Ma. Elena Paterno, and Danton Remoto; and the Literary League of the Philippines, established in 1986 by Efren Abueg, Alfredo Tiamzon, and Angelito Santos.

Outside of Metro Manila are these groups: the Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano iti Filipinas Inc (GUMIL-Filipinas) or the Ilokano Writers’ Association of the Philippines Inc; Sanghiran san Binisaya, based in Leyte and Samar; the Sumakwelan of Vernacular Writers in Western Visayas; the Samar Alliance; and the Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya or LUDABI of Cebuano writers.

 

The GUMIL is the umbrella organization of Ilocano writers here and abroad. Among its activities are regular and annual workshops and conferences. The group has come up with several publications, such as Alintatao (The Mind’s Eye), 1981, an anthology of short stories and poems in Ilocano, and Kurditan: Mga Kwentong Iluko (Canvas with Images: Ilocano Stories), 1988, an anthology of Ilocano short stories translated into Tagalog. Today the group has 11 provincial chapters, including Pangasinan, La Union, and Metro Manila, as well as seven overseas chapters in as far away as Greece. Balikas is its official quarterly newsletter, which includes literary pieces in Ilocano written by members. Since 2010, it has run the Pasnaan Literary Workshop for beginning writers in Ilocano. Ilocano writers like Reynaldo Duque, Cles Rambaud, and Roy Aragon continue to be associated with the organization.

An important organization in the development of Waray literature is the Sanghiran san Binisaya. The organization was founded in 1909 by Norberto Romualdez Sr with Jaime C. de Veyra, Casiano L. Trinchera, Francisco Alvarado, Iluminado Lucente, Juan Ricacho, Francisco Enfectana, Espiridion Brillo, and Eduardo Makabenta as its members. Among its most notable achievements are establishing the alphabet and the orthography for Waray in 1923, making the Sanghiran an academy similar to the Academia Real of Spain, and influencing the direction of Waray literature from 1910 to the 1950s.

In Western Visayas, considered the most durable among the Ilonggo literary societies is the Sumakwelan. Founded in 1948, the group had among its members Ramon Muzones, Conrado Norada, Emilio Zaldivar, and Lino Moles. The organization continues today with chapters in Negros Occidental, Capiz, and Antique. Among its activities are contests, revivals, and seminars that promote and preserve Ilonggo. Under the leadership of poet and retired judge Nilo Pamonag, the group published the groundbreaking Hiligaynon grammar book Pulong Hiligaynon para sa Tanan (Hiligaynon Language for All), 2010. The book has two parts—namely, fundamental principles of Hiligaynon and the affixes, and Hiligaynon rules of spelling, correct usage, and other salient aspects. The anthology Mga Bahandi sang Hiligaynon: Mga Pagdayaw sa Hara at mga Binalaybay (Hiligaynon Treasure: Praises for Hara and Poems) came out in 2011. Sumakwelan also holds literary contests in Hiligaynon for students.

In other regions, writers have been active in other larger organizations, such as the Banaag in Cebu and the Kulturang Atin Foundation in Davao. Other writers have also been based in the academe, such as those active at the Silliman University.

In the revolutionary underground, a number of writers organized the Artista at Manunulat ng Sambayanan (Armas), founded in 1987 and affiliated with the National Democratic Front. Its members recognize the need not only for committed literature reminiscent of the line followed by the Philippine Writers’ League in the 1940s and PAKSA in the 1970s, but also for writers to work in the interests of the basic masses and the national democratic revolution. In a statement in Filipino issued during the Aquino administration, Armas called for revolutionary writers and artists to use art and literature to fight imperialism, to promote the vision of national democracy, and to work with and in behalf of workers and peasants (Guillermo 1990, 32-33).

The 1990s saw the Internet transform the way writers formed groups. It facilitated communication across distances, made works posted online accessible and facilitated archiving, and helped groups widen their reach by helping them publicize their activities. Programs remained primarily geared toward publication, although there was also a marked increase in clinics and workshops, aimed at promoting the appreciation and practice of literature to a broader audience. Public readings continued in diverse venues, from bars and auditoriums to picket lines at rallies.

The combination of this leap in technology, a number of state incentives, and the increasing “academization” of writing in schools and universities contributed further to the thriving of organizations. Regional groups outside the already established communities of Cebuano, Hiligaynon, and Ilocano writers were formed. Spurred by a renewed critical interest post-EDSA in regional literature and, in some cases, underwritten by grants from state cultural institutions like the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA)), writers in the regional languages have formed pioneering groups while established organizations have broadened their reach. Most emerged out of the academe, but there are some that are based in communities and operate in the grassroots. These groups seek to promote either a language, like Aklanon, Waray, or Bikol, or a place, like Cavite, Baguio, or Davao, in continuing response to the lopsided development of writing outside Manila. To that end, they give workshops and clinics to budding writers in the region and publish works that would otherwise have not found a venue.

 

The Baguio Writers Group was founded in 1998, professing to “celebrate Cordilleran literature and nurture the souls of Cordilleran writers.” Its activities include poetry readings and workshops intended for beginning writers. Founding members include Cirilo F. Bautista, Nap Javier, Francis Macansantos, Luisa Igloria, and Gabriel Baban Keith. The anthologies The Baguio We Know, 2009, and Baguio Calligraphy, 2010, are two of the group’s publications.

In Pangasinan, the group Ulupan na Pansiansiay Salitan Pangasinan launched a literary magazine called Balon Silew in 2000, the first outlet for writing in the Pangasinan language since Maria Magsano’s Silew (Light) in the 1930s. The publication helped resurrect writing in the Pangasinan language, as it encouraged the local literati and public school teachers, among others, to write again in Pangasinan. Among the more prominent contributors to the magazine is Santiago Villafania, one of the more prolific writers from the province. The group also holds creative writing seminars and workshops.

In Southern Luzon, the formation of the Cavite Young Writers Association in 2003 was encouraged by Tagalog novelist Efren Abueg. The group, composed mostly of students from the universities in the province, strives to hone the literary consciousness of its members, promote the study of Cavite-born writers like Teo Baylen and Alejandro G. Abadilla, and emphasize a Cavite “brand” of writing. Over the years, the group has helped publish several anthologies and has participated in cultural events. It holds small gatherings in a member’s house where personal projects are discussed and one another’s works critiqued.

Pride in the legacy of a province is also the driving force behind the groups Neo-Angono Artists Collective and the Angono 3/7 Poetry Society in Rizal. The Neo-Angono Artists Collective, which counts visual artists, writers, musicians, filmmakers, art critics, and cultural workers as members, has given free poetry workshops and seminars to students from all over Rizal province. The Angono 3/7 Poetry Society conducts weekly workshops among members and publishes chapbooks. It published In(ter)vention kina Maestro Lucio at Botong, 2012, an anthology of poems about Angono-born National Artists Carlos “Botong” Francisco and Lucio San Pedro. Both groups have extensive collaboration with the local government.

In Quezon, Kuta ng Sining is a province-wide organization of artists and culture advocates based in Lucena City. The Guni-Guri Collective calls itself as an “alternative artists’ group” composed of visual and multimedia artists, musicians, and writers. The group was founded in 2010 by mostly visual artists until it was opened up to other artists who espouse the same “progressive and pro-people orientation” (Mallari 2014). Members are encouraged to hone and practice their craft in their own communities, and in the process educate others on how art can help society. Regular activities include workshops, exhibits, and outreach efforts.

The Bicol region witnessed perhaps the most pronounced and sustained surge in organizing activity from a virtual lack in the past. This development occurred alongside a resurgence of Bikol literature and corresponding critical attention. Aside from attempts to establish a big, region-wide organization, what particularly invigorated the scene were spirited efforts by small, mostly youthful groups gearing to promote literature in their respective communities.

Kabulig-Bikol started in 1993 from the idea of Bikol writer and academic Maria Lilia F. Realubit, with Rudy Alano as the first president and Frank Peñones as one of the founding members. After being dormant in 1995-99, it was revived in 2000 to help set up Pagsurat Bikolnon, the first conference of Bikol writers, and its iterations in 2004 and 2008. It became a more compact organization in 2004, holding regular meetings and discussions on Bikol art, culture, language, and literature. Its activities include workshops, such as the Arejola workshop in Pili, Camarines Sur. Bangraw is its literary magazine. Over the years it became the umbrella organization with chapters in Naga, Iriga, and Albay. Prominent members include Kristian Cordero, Jazmin Llana, Honesto Pesimo Jr, Marissa Reorizo-Redburn, Paz Verdades-Santos, and Rizaldy Manrique.

When Kabulig-Bikol began to wane in 2010, a breakaway group “from the margins” founded Parasurat Bikolnon. Pioneer members include Marissa Redburn, an entrepreneur from Masbate; Irvin Sto. Tomas, a government employee and Bikol orthography expert from Camarines Sur; and Jerome Hipolito, a college instructor at the Central Bicol State University of Agriculture. The group worked in the grassroots of their communities, differentiating themselves from the mostly academe-based initiatives of Kabulig-Bikol. They run the annual Saringsing Writers Workshop and Aking Parabasa, geared at promoting reading among children. It has also sponsored TigsTXT and Padurunongan, contests that seek to promote the tigsik, a traditional Bikolnon poetry form.

Another grassroots effort is An Banwa: Kultura buda Arte kan Tabaco (ABKAT), a community-based arts and culture group. Set up in 2005 by young artists, ABKAT aims to spearhead the research, development, and promotion of Bikol culture and language through the arts. Its most sustained activity is a monthly multi-genre cultural show called Pagtanyog (To Shake). It has been presented in barangays and schools, as well as aired over the radio. The group also organized conferences and workshops, such as the Tabaco Writers’ Workshop in 2007 and the Albayanong Parasurat Workshop in 2011 and 2012. It also held competitions, such as Seeds: Tabak Literary Contest. They have published anthologies and books, and helped spread Bikol literature on the ground by distributing to pedicabs stickers that contained tigsik verses. Its Haraya art magazine and Salabay poetry chapbook series are its other publication projects, in conjunction with concerts, art workshops, and theater performances, all in the Bikol languages. Founders include playwright Richard Madrilejos, filmmaker Frederick Maurice Lim, poet Noel Dorente, and musician Julius Bariso.

Western Visayas has also enjoyed a renewed, if short-lived, literary scene in the 1990s, which resulted in the formation of literary groups that complemented the continued activities of Sumakwelan. The formation of small groups was driven largely by the efforts of senior writer Leoncio Deriada and incentives from the CCP. However, their inability to expand membership beyond the original core group led to their eventual demise.

It was the participants of Deriada’s workshops in Iloilo, Antique, and Aklan who formed the Aklanon Literary Circle in the early 1990s. Early members include young writers Melchor Cichon, John E. Barrios, Alex de Juan, and Joeffrey Ricafuente, who was the group’s first president. Envisioned as a group that would revive and promote Aklanon literature, the group started the monthly journal Bueabod in 2005 and came out with nine issues until it folded in Sep 2006 when De Juan and Barrios graduated from college. The group tried to resurrect it in 2010 with an issue that contained a short story by Barrios and some Aklanon poems, but the revival was short-lived, and the Aklanon Literary Circle ceased to exist afterward.

It was the same story for a group of Karay-a writers called Tabig, which was formed in 1989 during the last days of another CCP-funded workshop. Tabig’s founding members include Alex de los Santos, Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica, Acay Flores, Leah Pagunsan, Edison Tondares, and Moi Magbanua. Tabig remained a small group, whose members, mostly students, would leave upon graduation. It held workshops, exhibits, and readings. The revival of Karay-a literature is its lasting achievement. After its core members became involved with other things, the group also ceased to exist in the late 1990s.

The Tarangban Literary Guild, based in the University of San Agustin in Iloilo, traces its roots to the Mirror Poetry Guild, a group adjunct to the school’s campus publication. First members include alumni of the San Agustin Regional Writers Workshop, organized by the writer John Iremil Teodoro. Later, the group accepted non-alumni and branched out to genres other than poetry.

In Eastern Visayas, the writer Harold Mercurio helped spur the formation of organizations during his term as regional coordinator of the NCCA’s National Committee on Literary Arts. Based in Tacloban, the Katig-ubanhan mga Magsusurat ha Sinirangan Bisayas, or the Katig Writers Network, is an umbrella organization of writers in Leyte, Samar, and Biliran and Capul Islands. Under it are the groups Calbayog Literary Arts Organization in Calbayog, Samar; the Abaknon Literary Arts Guild in Capul, Northern Samar; the Sirak Writers in Borongan City, Eastern Samar; and the Bisdak Writers in Biliran. The groups aim to revive and spur writing in Waray, Cebuano, and Inabaknon, the language spoken in Capul Island.

In Mindanao, two groups that helped revitalize writing in the region are the Davao Writers Guild (DWG) and Bathalad-Mindanao. Their efforts were toward the publication of works that highlight the creative output of writers from the region and, in the case of Bathalad-Mindanao, the “Bisaya” language as a distinct variant of the Cebuano used in Cebu.

 

The DWG, set up in 1999 by the formerly Manila-based poet Ricardo de Ungria, is responsible for Dagmay, which started in 2001 as a quarterly newsletter before eventually becoming a monthly supplement to the newspaper Sun Star Davao and, later, a Sunday literary page. Among those published under the group’s Tubaw book series were Don Pagusara’s Cebuano and English poetry collection Qontrapuntal, 2003; Macario Tiu’s English story collection Sky Rose, 2003; and Josie Tejada’s English story collection The House on Calle Seminario, 2007. With help from NCAA, the group has published several other books, including two anthologies of Mindanao writing. It has either co-sponsored or instituted workshops, with all fellows coming from Mindanao, including its very own Davao Writers Workshop in 2009. Members include Aida Rivera-Ford, Tita Lacambra-Ayala, Margarita Marfori, Eva Socorro Aranas, Josie Tejada, and Saturnino P. Apoyon, its first president. The DWG has a youth wing called the Young Davao Writers, which holds an annual poetry reading event called “LitOrgy,” directed at a young audience.

Originally a chapter of Bathalad-Cebu, Bathalad-Mindanao is a small gathering of writers in Cagayan de Oro which eventually expanded to Bukidnon, Lanao, Davao, Cotabato, Butuan, Surigao, and Zamboanga. Its major projects include the creation of a Bisaya dictionary and thesaurus and establishing the Bisaya orthography toward developing writing and readership in the language. In addition, the group seeks to increase interest in the diverse cultures and concerns of Bisaya writing and publish works to heighten national awareness. Members include Rey Poloyapoy, Gumer Rafanan, Arturo Peñaserada, Richel Dorotan, Jonecito Saguban, Marcelo Geocallo, and Anito Beronilla.

The 1990s and 2000s also saw the flourishing of creative writing centers based in universities, following in the heels of the UP Creative Writing Center, established in 1978 and renamed Likhaan: The UP Institute of Creative Writing in 2002. These include the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices, 2000; the De La Salle University Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center, 1991; the UST Center for Creative Writing and Literary Studies, 1999, reopened, 2012; the Silliman University Edilberto K. Tiempo and Edith L. Tiempo Creative Writing Center, 2012; and the PUP Sentro Para sa Malikhaing Pagsulat, 2013.

 

Campus organizations continue to be a training ground for budding writers, although no contemporary group has achieved the status of the UP Writers’ Club during the late 1920s. Workshops among members and nonmembers are a common activity, as are the publication of folios and zines and school-wide literary competitions. These campus-based groups include the UP Quill and the UP Ugnayan ng Manunulat or UP Ugat in UP Diliman; the Samahang L.A.Y.B. in UP Los Baños; Literary Society and Tinta in UP Mindanao; Ateneo de Manila’s Heights; Ateneo de Davao’s Society of Ateneo Literature and English Majors; the DLSU Writers Guild and Malate Literary Folio of De La Salle University; the Thomasian Writers Guild of UST; and the FEU Writers Guild of Far Eastern University. In 2011, there was a collaborative effort among the UP Writers’ Club, Heights, Malate Literary Folio, and the Thomasian Writers Guild, with the publication of Buklod, featuring works from members and alumni of the four organizations.

UMPIL and Philippine PEN continued to be the two biggest nationwide organizations of writers, both with continuing ties with academe and state cultural institutions. Outside the big organizations with institutional support, there were spirited efforts mostly by poets to organize and promote literature through regular readings, workshops, and so-called alternative publication. The most sustained effort to this end has been that of High Chair, a small nonprofit press. High Chair has refused institutional backing, traditional distribution channels like commercial bookstores, and maximum revenue schemes.

High Chair has not explicitly defined an aesthetic, although the influence of modernism may be detected in the works of members. Among those who founded it are Allan Popa, Marc Gaba, Mabi David, Alex Gregorio, and Kristine Domingo. Other poets who came to be identified with the group include Conchitina Cruz, Adam David, Vincenz Serrano, Mark Anthony Cayanan, Mesandel Virtusio Arguelles, Jose Perez Beduya, Oliver Ortega, and Joseph de Luna Saguid.

Beginning informally in 2001 and officially organized the following year, High Chair comes out with a semiannual online journal of poems, essays, and interviews. A special issue, in 2009, was on the Maguindanao Massacre. The books it published include Popa’s Kami sa Lahat ng Masama (We from All Evil), 2003; Gregorio’s The Rosegun, 2004; Arguelles’s Ilahas (Feral), 2004; Cruz’s Elsewhere Held and Lingered, 2008; Gaba’s Nouveau Bored, 2009; and David’s You Are Here, 2009. In 2011, it launched a poetry appreciation program called Compass. Members visit school- and community-based writers’ groups and conduct discussions and workshops using a unique teaching module it has developed.

“Learning and interaction” are the main thrusts behind Pinoypoets, formed in 2004, a group of poets and poetry enthusiasts. Disavowing any political ideology or advocacy, the group aims to provide a venue for members to enrich their knowledge and improve their craft. It has held workshops, published chapbooks, and produced a CD featuring original poems written and read by members. Its online activities include posting of poems for workshop as well as writing exercises.

In the mid-2000s, another group of poets, led by Joel Toledo and Andrea Teran, started Happy Mondays, a biweekly poetry reading series, which had also come to refer to the loose collective of writers who frequented the readings and held informal workshops and discussions. The readings took place at Mag:net Café and Gallery in Quezon City and, later, in other venues. Regular members include Arkaye Kierulf, Rafael San Diego, Naya Valdellon, Marie La Viña, Allan Pastrana, Pocholo Goitia, and Daryll Delgado, although Almario, Gemino Abad, Jose Lacaba, Krip Yuson, J. Neil Garcia, Marjorie Evasco, Marne Kilates, Angelo Suarez, Conchitina Cruz, Lourd de Veyra, and Mookie Katigbak have each at one point read at a Happy Mondays event. Like High Chair, the group demurs at professing a single poetic aesthetic, although a cursory survey of its members’ works would reveal an inclination toward a poetry of affect, the same one fostered in the workshop circuit, where almost all its members have emerged from.

In children’s literature, Kuwentista ng mga Tsikiting (Kuting) is credited by the Reading Association of the Philippines for “having professionalized writing for children, raising it to the level of art, and for ensuring the emergence of the Golden Age of children’s literature” (Alba 2003). Formed during the 1995 UP National Writers Workshop, Kuting was composed of university teachers, journalists, visual artists, writers for TV, and students. Members formed a support network for the then-burgeoning genre, pushing for writers’ rights in the children’s book publishing industry and sharing opportunities with each other. They also hold workshops and seminars exclusive to members, as well as outreach activities like storytelling sessions and book drives for the benefit of children in need. Its publication projects include Water in the Ring of Fire, 1996, an anthology of folktales from the Asia Pacific region, edited by Carla Pacis, features Kuting members. Members include Pacis, Lara Saguisag, Augie Rivera, Luis Gatmaitan, Heidi Eusebio-Abad, Becky Bravo, May Tobias-Papa, Robert Magnuson, and Rhandee Garlitos.

Another group credited for invigorating a genre is the Lit Critters, organized by the writer Dean Alfar in 2006. Its regular critiquing sessions are grounded on what its manifesto asserts as the value of speculative fiction, or “non-realist” fiction, as “a valid and vibrant form of literature” (Alfar 2014). Early sessions were devoted to craft, technique, and literary theory, and, later, workshops. From the core group—Alfar and his wife Nikki, Kate and Alexander Osias, Andrew Drilon, and Vincent Michael Simbulan—the group’s membership has expanded to include Charles Tan, Kenneth Yu, Elyss Punsalan, and Ian Rosales Casocot, who leads its Dumaguete chapter. Its contribution to Philippine letters is the assimilation of speculative fiction into the mainstream, evident in the thriving community of readers, especially of Alfar’s Philippine Speculative Fiction series, which began in 2005.

Creators and enthusiasts of graphic literature also formed groups, championing the genre and helping spur its resurgence in the 1990s and 2000s, as well as asserting a Filipino quality in the traditionally Western form. A pioneering group is Alamat Comics. Inspired by noted Filipino-American comic book writer and artist Whilce Portacio, Alamat was founded in 1994 as an umbrella organization of independent Filipino comic book creators and studios. Founding members include Gerry Alanguilan, Carlo Vergara, David Hontiveros, Arnold Arre, Budjette Tan, Bow Guerrero, J. B. Tapia, and others. Portacio rallied them to work together under one banner that people would easily identify as a “Philippine-made comic book.” True enough, Alamat single-handedly helped Filipinos carve a niche in an industry traditionally ruled by American titles. Their pioneering efforts are credited for revivifying the local comic book industry. While individual groups still funded the printing and distribution of their comic books, Alamat as an organization became a central promotional office, in which information, such as affordable printing presses, is shared and publicity for Alamat titles is emphasized. Alamat creators mounted exhibits in rock clubs and galleries. They were invited to conduct workshops and seminars in schools. Since 2005, only a handful of the original Alamat members have remained active. While some have set up their own publishing companies or are being published by a commercial press, they continue to place the Alamat logo on the cover of their works.

A newer group is Studio Salimbal, which takes its name from the mythological ship in Bukidnon lore that transports people to heaven. Established in 2013, it is run by professional graphic artists Elbert Or and Paolo Chikiamco and counts as members industry stalwarts such as Budjette Tan and Mervin Malonzo, as well as young artists Koi Carreon and Cristina Rose Chua. Like Alamat, the group aims to “create avenues for sustainable production of comic books and creative intellectual properties.”

 

Independent groups include Meganon Comics and Gerry Alanguilan’s Komikero Artists Group based in San Pablo, Laguna. Meganon Comics is a group of young independent artists and writers who aim to foster a more sustainable indie comics community by assisting creators in publishing their works and reaching a wider market. The core group includes Tepai Pascual, Maika Ezawa, Paolo Herras, and Brent Sabas. The Komikero Artists Group is a loose gathering of mostly comic book artists, but it includes painters, photographers, and installation artists. The group occasionally organizes events, including the San Pablo Comics Art Festival in 2003, 2009, and 2011. Active members include Jonas Diego, Johnny Danganan, Kevin Ray Valentino, Jason Torres, Brian Balondo, Dexter Entera, Ryan Toledo, and Geoff Borgonia.

Aside from building a thriving community of comic book artists and enthusiasts, the comic book organizations mentioned have helped create a Filipino aesthetic and sensibility in the comic book genre, with works that use elements drawn from local myths and folklore or that rework foreign genres to tell Filipino stories. Most of the stories in Alamat titles are set in the Philippines, with a good mix of genres, ranging from Pinoy superheroes to space opera and science fiction. Studio Salimbal has a project called “Mythspace,” a “space opera” that reimagines Philippine folklore creatures as aliens, and “Bravos,” which is set in a universe where the Philippines has a monopoly on superpowers. For his San Pablo group, Alanguilan discourages the use of styles closely associated with other cultures, like Japanese manga. There is also a conscious effort to promote the works of old masters of Filipino comics, including Francisco Coching, Nestor Redondo, Alfredo Alcala, and Alex Niño.

Campus organizations, like the UP Graphic Arts in Literature (GRAIL), established in 1999, provide a venue for young creators and enthusiasts to nourish their interest in the genre. UP GRAIL participates in local comic book conventions by showcasing its annual anthologies, created by members. Skills improvement is also on the agenda, with its scriptwriting, layout, paneling, and general art workshops.

Progressive post-EDSA writers’ groups, mostly in the ranks of the youth, continue to emphasize the political role of art and writers in society in the tradition of PAKSA. Kilometer 64 and Kataga (Word) profess to abiding by a critique of history and society as they seek to bring literature closer to the masses. Founded in 2003, Kilometer 64, or KM 64, gets its name from the initials of Kabataang Makabayan and the year it was established, 1964. Members write nationalist poetry, which they disseminate through publications and public readings in bars, schools, picket lines, and urban poor communities. Its first efforts include a pamphlet of anti-imperialist poetry printed in time for US President George W. Bush Jr’s Philippine visit. Its chapbooks include Ped Xing (Pedestrian Crossing), Chacha: Sayaw sa Bubog (Chacha: Dance in Broken Glass), and Please Fasten Your Seatbelt, all published in 2004, and Kabyawan (Sugar Mill), 2005, which recounts the harsh plight of tenants in Hacienda Luisita. In the same year, during KM’s 40th anniversary, KM 64 published 40: Mga Tulang Alay sa mga Martir na Kabataan (40: Poems Dedicated to Youth Martyrs), which consists of poems written by members and nonmembers: Lumbera, Jesus Manuel Santiago, Domingo Landicho, Emmanuel Lacaba and Amado V. Hernandez. Tulagalag, a portmanteau of the words “tula” (poem) and “lagalag” (wanderer), is a mobile and public poetry initiative in which poems are posted in public places.

Kataga was formed by Reuel Aguila in 2008. It published its first anthology, Kataga 1 (Word 1), in 2013. The introduction to the book stressed the need for writers to go beyond their private concerns and ensure that their works reach their audience. The poems engage human rights violation, enforced disappearances, poverty, and the indignities of daily life in a society as grossly unequal as the Philippines. A satellite chapter in the Quezon province is Kataga-Lucena, which is composed of two divisions, Panitikan (Literature) and Pagtatanghal (Performance). Other Kataga chapters can be found in Manila, Quezon City, and Zambales. There is also a Kataga chapter online.

In general, there are three reasons why organizations are formed. One is to provide a venue for writers to develop their craft by training and interaction; another is to seek opportunities and venues for the publication of their works; a third is to articulate a particular vision of society through literature and advance this by means of a political agenda.

The organizational affiliation of writers may provide clues in the study of their works as one divines or attempts to determine their sources and influences. The mentorship of organizations by established writers—like Virgilio S. Almario for Galian sa Arte at Tula (GAT) and, later, LIRA; Fidel Rillo for Katha; and N. V. M. Gonzalez for the Ravens—can exert an influence on the style and substance of a writer’s craft.

As the writing community in the Philippines remains small and largely parochial, almost all writers tend to belong to groups, whether informal cliques or big organizations. This dynamic makes organizations vital transmission grounds for the spread of aesthetic and political predispositions, which over time can shape the country’s overall literary landscape.  Written by Rolando B. Tolentino and Joi Barrios, updated by Glenn Diaz, with notes from Edgardo Tiamson, Bienvenido Lumbera, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava, Kate Picart, Reynaldo Duque, Vic Sugbo, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Mabi David, Joel Toledo, Dean Alfar, Gerry Alanguilan, Budjette Tan, Elbert Or, Tepai Pascual, Karl Orit, Phillip Kimpo Jr, Irwin Sto. Tomas, Eduardo Uy, John E. Barrios, and Julian dela Cerna

article.value: Organizations are groups of writers who come together for a variety of purposes. Writers may organize themselves because of a common worldview, political ideology, or intellectual temperament. Others form groups for publication and workshop projects. Writers have also been known to get together for the sake of literary fellowship and sharing of artistic output, with some ritualistic elements involved. Groups outside of Manila have strengthened their ranks so that they may continue to assert regional writing and identity, in the process contributing to the development of a multiethnic body of national literature.

A listing of the history of writers’ groups is essential for two reasons. One, it gives a picture of how writers’ groups have influenced literary trends and movements. Second, it shows how writers may have influenced one another’s works.

The origins of literary organizing in the Philippines can be traced back to the reform movement, 1882-96. The prime movers of the reform movement based in Spain chose to publish critical, often satirical, essays about the Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. These writers, among them Jose Rizal and Marcelo H. del Pilar, used the newspaper La Solidaridad as the venue for their campaign for reforms. While it is debatable that these propagandists organized themselves formally as a “literary group,” one cannot deny that these writers were bound by a common desire to work for a political cause through their writings.

article.value: The oldest literary society in the country could be the Liceo-Artistico Literario, established in 1879 to promote Spanish letters in the Philippines and to establish “professional chairs of literature, drama, music and painting.” Emiliano Olano became the president of this organization, which lasted for only three years but which succeeded in launching two projects. One was the publication of a weekly (later, fortnightly) magazine, Revista del Liceo Artistico-Literario, 1879. It came out with six issues. The editor in chief, Francisco de Marcaida, a Filipino, had a staff of 21 Spaniards and three Filipinos, many of them award-winning prose writers and poets.

The other project was a literary contest. Two contests were held by the Liceo: one in 1879 and another in 1880, to commemorate the 264th death anniversary of Miguel de Cervantes. Jose Rizal’s entries won in both contests: “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth) in 1879 and “El Consejo de los Dioses” (The Council of the Gods) in 1880.

The core activity of literary groups active during the last decade of the 19th century and the first decade of the 20th century was the tertulia, or a gathering of artists, lovers of art and culture, and friends who discuss a variety of topics. These gatherings provided venues for the study of works of other writers, poetry readings, literary discussions, and debates on the political issues of the period.

The tertulia sponsored by the Academia de la Lengua y Literatura, founded in 1892 at the residence of Vicente Ilustre by Macario Adriatico, attracted the best writers of the period. Among its 50 members, then university students, were Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Gregorio Aguilera, Luis Luna, and Cecilio Apostol. By 1894, the organization was holding its gatherings at Epifanio de los Santos’s residence in Intramuros. New members were Rafael Palma, Clemente Jose Zulueta, and Manuel Guerrero. Others who were reported to have joined the literary tertulias of the Academia were Emilio Jacinto and Juan Sumulong.

Another literary club of the period was El Jardin de Epicuro, founded by Fernando Ma. Guerrero. The members of this group were modernist writers like Sixto Roces, Feliciano Basa, Jose R. Teotico, Flavio Cano Zaragoza, Alejo Valdez Pica, Jose Gavira Hernandez, and Jesus Balmori. This group discussed, among other things, the works of Ruben Dario, a Spanish writer who greatly influenced their works.
The tertulias of Liceo, the Academia, El Jardin, and other groups attracted the participation of Tagalog writers such as Iñigo Ed. Regalado.

Tagalog writers started to form groups during the first decade of American colonial rule. Aklatang Bayan was formed in 1910 in Tondo, Manila, with Rosauro Almario and Gerardo Chanco elected president and secretary, respectively. The Aklatang Bayan’s objectives, published in the newspaper Renacimiento Filipino, included fighting “bad” habits and beliefs in politics, religion, and everyday life (Almario 1984, 54).

article.value: Among the activities sponsored by the Aklatang Bayan were weekly meetings that featured poetic orations and songs. The group also sponsored contests and propagated the national language. The Aklatang Bayan celebrated Balagtas Day, 2 Apr, by staging literary jousts in several towns in Bulacan: Baliuag, 1915; Meycauayan, 1916; and Bigaa (now Balagtas), 1917. Aklatang Bayan drew its strength from the popularity of its members, many of whom were the leading writers of the period whose activities were featured in the dailies. Active in the group were Lope K. Santos, Carlos Ronquillo, Faustino Aguilar, Benigno Ramos, Patricio Mariano, Pedro Gatmaitan, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Severino Reyes, Nemesio Caravana, Amado V. Hernandez, Leonardo Dianzon, and Aniceto Silvestre. Its two other presidents were Precioso Palma, 1915, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda, 1920, who led the group until his death in 1947.

It is said that discontent with the “academic taste” of Aklatang Bayan became the basis for the founding of Ilaw at Panitik (Lumbera 1967, 386). Organized during the early 20th century, the group was headed for a long time by Jose Esperanza Cruz. It was one of the biggest and most popular of the literary societies, and had among its members the likes of the Tagalog short story pioneer Deogracias A. Rosario, the much-acclaimed poet Jose Corazon de Jesus; poet Teodoro Gener; poet, novelist, journalist, and labor leader Amado V. Hernandez; and poet-playwright Cirio H. Panganiban. Jose Esperanza Cruz, editor of the Liwayway for more than 20 years, became the first president of Ilaw at Panitik.

In Aug 1915, Cirio H. Panganiban explained that “Ilaw,” or light, referred to the belief and confidence of the writer, whereas “Panitik,” or pen, referred to a literature committed to the independence of the country. Other literary organizations active during the first decade were Samahang Mananagalog, Kapisanang Sisne, Dunong Ginto, Florante at Laura, Aklatang Barusaga, all of which were in Tondo, and Aklatang Balagtas in Sampaloc.

In 1935, at the residence of Alejandro G. Abadilla in Santa Cruz, Manila, the young writers of Tagalog literature formed the Kapisanang Panitikan. The group was a reaction to the older Aklatang Bayan and Ilaw at Panitik, whose members were being published in major outlets like Liwayway.

In a statement, the members of the Kapisanang Panitikan described their group as “sakdalista at aristokrata,” because like the radical peasant group also called Sakdalista, it rejected the reigning aesthetic in Tagalog literature and it was ready to be alienated from the mainstream (Almario 1984, 134). This group, led by Abadilla, founding vice president, and Clodualdo del Mundo, founding president, “was determined to be ‘modern,’ in the sense that it was to diverge from the traditional along lines being pursued by the writers of Philippine English literature” (Lumbera and Lumbera 1982, 112). Among the members of Panitikan were Teodoro Agoncillo, Brigido Batungbakal, Salvador Barros, Epifanio Gar. Matute, Teo S. Buhain (founding secretary), Fernando Monleon, Genoveva Edroza-Matute, Pablo Glorioso, Jesus Arceo, Cresencio Cruz Torres, Manuel Car. Santiago, Gonzalo K. Flores, Manuel Principe Bautista, and Ruben Vega.

The members of Panitikan held a book-burning rally at Plaza Moriones in Tondo in 1940, the intent of which was to destroy works that they thought did not merit being passed on to posterity (Lumbera 1967, 387). Many of what they burned were the works by the older writers. The book burning was a symbolic event which showed the rift between the older writers and the members of Panitikan. In 1938, Panitikan managed to put out a magazine also called Panitikan. The organization endured for decades and lasted until the 1970s.

In the late 1920s, a group of students of the University of the Philippines (UP) formed the UP Writers’ Club, “impelled by a noble aim to elevate to the highest pedestal of possible perfection the ENGLISH language in the Islands.” The group’s original motto was “ART shall not be a Means to an End but AN END IN ITSELF” (Abad and Manlapaz 1989, 253). Among the founders of the club were the following: Casiano Calalang, Augusto Catanjal, Loreto Paras, Arturo Rotor, Felicidad Dani-Martin, Eugenio P. Santos, Vicente del Fierro, Francisco Tonogbanua, Jose M. Hernandez, Paz Latorena, Gabriel Tuazon, and Jose Garcia Villa.
