text:
Literary training is the process by which writers learn their craft. In the Philippines, this activity includes the training of students in the creation and transmission of oral literature, formal education in universities offering creative or imaginative writing courses, and workshops offered by cultural institutions and organizations involved in literary creation.

In the case of oral literature, because it is continually evolving, the singer and the storyteller are themselves creators of literary works. In epics, for example, accretion and omission occur; characters, elements, and passages are added, embellished, or deleted. Some forms of literary expression may be etched on bamboo like the surat Mangyan.

 

The epic is learned at an early age, usually from a relative. Pagyaw, E. Arsenio Manuel’s source for the Manobo songs The Maiden of the Buhong Sky and Tuwaang Attends a Wedding, learned them from a bard named Inuk, who belonged to a family of epic chanters. Liyos Ambog, the source for the Subanon epic Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan (The Kingdom of Keboklagan), learned it from her mother Anaya. Anaya’s mother Sapar had learned it at the age of six. Blagtas Pandakan, the source for Agyu, learned the epic from his uncle Sugalan, who, in turn, had learned it from his father Ampalid.

Precolonial poets followed rules, learning from childhood that each stanza consisted of three, four, or five lines with a single assonantal rhyme (Lumbera 1986). The conventions of oral literary forms, such as formulaic repetitions, stereotyping of characters, and regular rhythmic and musical devices—learned during childhood—facilitated the transmission of poems, songs, tales, and sayings. Over time, the origin and original meaning of the words may be lost as the songs are learned by rote. The contemporary Tboli, once practicing an animistic religion, have become Christians, and call their place Santa Cruz instead of Lemlunay. They continue to chant a song about Lemlunay taught to them by the babaylan (priestess), yet they cannot explain the meaning of the phrases “spirits that guard” and “spirits that destroy” (Almario 1991).

During the Spanish colonial period, European poetic forms were introduced by the Spanish friars who ran printing presses and published books. The octosyllabic romance, for example, was used by Fr Francisco de San Jose in Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua Tagala (Guidelines for the Christian Life in the Tagalog Language), 1605. It was also in this book that the term ladino was first used to refer to poems in both Spanish and Tagalog, and to poets writing in this manner. The first verses written by Filipinos using the romance are attributed to Fernando Bagongbanta and the anonymous author of the poem “May Bagyo Ma’t May Rilim” (Though It is Stormy and Dark). During the 18th century, Tondo became known as a center for poets. Jose de la Cruz, considered to be the best among them, is said to have taught himself philosophy and canon law. He became the teacher of many aspiring poets, such as Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas, Ananias Zorilla, Tomas Ledo, and the brothers Juan and Prudencio Feliciano. De la Cruz reputedly charged a sisiw (chick) for lessons, thus earning the epithet “Huseng Sisiw.” De la Cruz wrote poems at the request of young men courting women, and he scripted dramas commissioned by committees for town fiestas. In this way, the language of Tagalog poetry “moved from the earthiness of Gaspar Aquino de Belen to the refinement and elegance of Jose de la Cruz.” Poetic diction may be said to have begun with De la Cruz (Lumbera 1986, 103).

It was Balagtas’s works which represented the fusion of all the traditions of Tagalog poetry from the 16th to the 19th century. After obtaining the equivalent of a high school education at the San Juan de Letran, Balagtas took higher studies, which included Latin, philosophy, theology, canon law, and Roman and Spanish laws, at the Colegio de San Jose. His works show that he had read Virgil and Homer and was familiar with Greek and Roman mythology. In Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), ca. 1838, Balagtas not only employs the talinghaga and the monorhyming quatrain of precolonial Tagalog poetry; he also uses classical allusions and incorporates diverse elements of the Spanish ballad.

When the Spanish colonial government established a system of education in 1863, rhetoric and poetry were among the courses included in programs leading to a bachillerato en artes (bachelor of arts). In the normal schools and universities, students read trozos or selections from famous Catholic and Castilian prose and verse writers like Cervantes, Mariana, Fray Luis de Leon, Herrera, Rioja, Zorilla, and Lope de Vega (Tiongson 1978).

The rise of the middle class in the 19th century resulted in its sending its children to Europe to study. While no records show that they studied creative writing formally, many were influenced by, on the one hand, the literary works they read in Europe and, on the other, the folk forms familiar to them. Jose Rizal studied medicine but followed the tradition of realism employed by Galdos, Balzac, Hugo, and Dickens. Meanwhile, Marcelo H. del Pilar, who studied law at the University of Santo Tomas, deliberately used folk and popular forms for his poems and satirical works (Lumbera 1986, 140). Both propagandists also mastered the essay as shown in Rizal’s “Su Excelencia, Señor Don Vicente Barrantes” (His Excellency, Mr Vicente Barrantes) and Del Pilar’s “Asimilacion de Filipinas” (Assimilation of the Philippines).

Examples of revolutionary literature written in Tagalog using monorhyming quatrains are the trilogy of poems “Hibik ng Pilipinas sa Inang España (Filipinas’ Lament to Mother Spain), 1889, by Hermenegildo Flores; “Sagot nang España sa Hibik nang Pilipinas” (Spain’s Reply to Filipinas’ Lament), 1889, by Marcelo H. del Pilar; and “Katapusang Hibik ng Pilipinas” (Last Lament of Filipinas), 1896, by Andres Bonifacio. The first two poems were written as companion pieces; Flores was both teacher and fellow propagandist to del Pilar. Bonifacio became familiar with versification as an actor in Tagalog plays and was much inspired by Rizal’s two novels, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. These two factors may have contributed to the dramatic force and explicit revolutionary intent of his reply to “Hibik” and “Sagot.”

After the establishment of the Revolutionary Government of Malolos on 23 Jun 1898, immediately created were the Universidad Literaria de Filipinas on 19 Oct 1898 and the Instituto Burgos, which set the curriculum followed by other schools. While Tagalog had been proclaimed the national language, the general curriculum continued to include the reading and writing of Spanish and the appreciation of Spanish literature. Among the teachers were writers Pedro Paterno and Leon Ma. Guerrero (Tiongson 1978, 141).

During the first decades of the 20th century, the American Insular Government pursued two orientations in the education of Filipinos for “citizenship”: industrial or manual education, begun by Fred Atkinson; and “literary” or liberal education, first broached by David Barrows. English was made the language of instruction in 1900. Elementary schools used the Baldwin Readers and later the Insular Readers. In high schools, students became familiar with works such as Longfellow’s “Evangeline”; Irving’s Sketchbook; an anthology titled English Poems from Chaucer to Kipling, George Eliot’s Silas Marner; and Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice and Macbeth (Tiongson 1978, 141-47).

Even with the establishment of more colleges and universities and the teaching of language and literature, creative writing in Tagalog or in any of the other regional languages was not taught as a subject. Instead, poets continued to follow “rules” learned through other poets or their works. The formalization of these rules of traditional poetry, which had come to be called balagtasismo, after Balagtas, was made by Lope K. Santos in his paper “Particularidades de la Poesia Tagala” (Particularities of Tagalog Poetry), 1929, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda in Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog (The Three Periods of Tagalog Poetry), 1947. The formal teaching of poetry, however, has been limited to the mechanical use of rhetorical elements; observance of the basic rules on rhyme and meter; and the memorization of the aral (lesson) from versification. Additional elements, such as irony and tension, were studied from the works of foreign writers, such as William Empson, I. A. Richards, Paul Valery, or Charles Olson, who were deemed superior to Filipino critics and writers like Teodoro E. Gener or Rufino Alejandro (Almario 1991, 5).

Among the first-generation novelists were Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Roman Reyes, Gabriel Beato Francisco, Patricio Mariano, Severino Reyes, Aurelio Tolentino, Lope K. Santos, Faustino Aguilar, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, and Juan Arsciwals. Born in the late 19th century, many of them finished secondary education at Ateneo de Manila, San Juan de Letran, or the Universidad de Santo Tomas, where they became familiar with the works of Quevedo, Cervantes, Galdos, Voltaire, Zola, Dumas, and Eugene Sue. Many were also educated during the American colonial period. The works of Shakespeare, Hugo, Dante, Milton, Tolstoy, and Dumas were studied for forms and themes. These works were translated into Tagalog by Gerardo Changco, Francisco Laksamana, Narciso Asistio, and Rosendo Ignacio.

 

Established by the American colonial government in 1908, the University of the Philippines (UP) and, in particular, its College of Arts and Sciences, greatly contributed to the rise of English as a literary language in the opening decades of the 20th century. Creative writing classes today may be traced to the composition classes under its Department of English during the American colonial period. In terms of training, no other Philippine university would go on to have a more “significant” and “sustained” impact in creative writing—particularly in English (Dalisay 2007, 7). Most of the first- and second-generation writers in English studied at UP. The undergraduate English classes served as their training ground as writers. Angela Manalang Gloria, Jose Garcia Villa, Casiano Calalang, F. B. Icasiano, Luis Dato, and Loreto Paras-Sulit, and, later, Manuel Arguilla, Bienvenido Santos, Arturo B. Rotor, Salvador P. Lopez, Maria Luna-Lopez, Maria Kalaw, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, and Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla were classmates in UP. Among the teachers were George Pope Shannon, Paz Marquez-Benitez, C. V. Wickers, Vicente M. Hilario, Cristina Jamias, Carlos P. Romulo, and A. V. H. Hartendorp. Paz Marquez-Benitez, who wrote the first Filipino modern short story in English, held a short story class thrice a week that proved to be training ground for many beginning fictionists. She encouraged new work, “good or bad,” helping students polish their style and technique (Alegre and Fernandez 1984, 98, 113). It was under her class where Casiano Calalang wrote “Soft Clay,” Paras-Sulit wrote “Laarni,” and Bienvenido Santos wrote “The Years are Very Long,” which she reputedly described as “the best story I have read written by a Filipino.”

 

Essay writing was taught by Professor Valenzuela, while literature teacher C. V. Wickers encouraged Angela Manalang Gloria and Luis Dato to write poetry. Other teachers included Tom Inglis Moore in poetry, Robert Conklin in advanced English, and Mrs Conklin in dramatic presentation. Today, UP Diliman is the only university that offers the full range of programs in creative writing in English and Filipino, from the two-year certificate to a PhD.

Organizations also became a venue for training writers, often in the form of workshops and other methods of informal tutelage. Many of the writers who were members of the UP Writers’ Club or staffers of the Philippine Collegian held informal sessions to discuss each other’s stories and poems as well as current literature. The works of Wilbur Daniel Steele, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg, Amy Lowell, Bernard Shaw, Vidal Tan, and Carlos P. Romulo were among those they discussed. The Ravens, which had started as an offshoot of the UP Writers’ Club, were mentored by N. V. M. Gonzalez, who conducted informal workshops at his residence.

Some first-generation writers also went abroad for formal training in creative writing. Maria Kalaw-Katigbak was awarded the Barbour Scholarship in Michigan in 1933 and majored in creative writing. In 1941, Bienvenido Santos, then president of Legazpi College, went to the United States on a Rockefeller Grant and at one point studied under American novelist Philip Roth. N. V. M. Gonzalez, also on a Rockefeller, went to the United States in the late 1940s and was influenced by a number of “Southern Agrarians” who championed a militant regionalism that resonated with his so-called rural sensibility. All three, including Salvador P. Lopez and Leopoldo Yabes, would become teachers.

The training for some second-generation writers consisted of reading as well as of direct interaction with other writers and critics. The books of Erskine Caldwell, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Thomas Wolfe were available to them. However, it was through writing workshops that most gained access to the works of others and improved their craft. The workshop model, together with the creative writing programs in universities, would prove to be the most defining training venues for Filipino writers, especially in English.

Edilberto and Edith L. Tiempo, who along with Ricaredo Demetillo and Dominador Ilio were the first Asians to attend the prestigious Iowa Writers’ Workshop, institutionalized the workshop model in the Philippines when they established the Silliman National Writers Workshop in 1962. Patterned after the pioneering Iowa Writers’ Workshop, it was originally under Silliman’s English department. It traces its roots to a university-based semestral workshop that was credited for two to three units, which students could get upon official arrangement with Edilberto Tiempo. Held every summer for five, and, eventually, three weeks in Dumaguete City, the workshop discussions center on the poems, short stories, plays, and essays submitted by the participants, the majority of whom write in English. Occasional works in Filipino and other regional languages were submitted with translations until it became an all-English workshop. Applicants submit samples of their works—three to five short stories, a suite of seven poems or so, three to five essays, a play—and recommendation letters from professors or former workshop fellows. Applications average 70-80 a year. Board and lodging, as well as minimal transportation and living allowances, are provided to the chosen participants.

 

The Tiempos ran the workshop for nearly 50 years, a period in which their name became synonymous with Silliman and all that it stood for in the literary world. Their daughter Rowena Tiempo-Torrevillas, herself a writer and professor at the University of Iowa, took over as director in 2011. Succeeding her were Susan Lara and Ricardo de Ungria. Over the years, regular panelists have included Dumaguete-based writers Cesar Ruiz Aquino, Myrna Peña-Reyes, Bobby Villasis, and Ernesto Superal-Yee, and guest panelists such as Gemino Abad, Merlie Alunan, Marjorie Evasco, D. M. Reyes, and Alfred A. Yuson.

The Silliman Workshop has had a “tremendous influence” in creative writing in English in the country, as well as in other writers’ workshops (Pernia 2002, 7). “Practically all Filipino writers of any importance” have gone to Silliman at one point, either as fellows, lecturers, or panelists (Bautista 1998). Its roster of alumni includes Gregorio Brillantes, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, Emmanuel Lacaba, Virgilio S. Almario, Ninotchka Rosca, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Cirilo F. Bautista, Ricky Lee, Aida Rivera-Ford, Estrella Alfon, Jun Cruz Reyes, Edel Garcellano, Merlie Alunan, Ophelia Dimalanta, Jose Dalisay, Marjorie Evasco, Rofel Brion, and Rene Amper. National Artists Nick Joaquin and Francisco Arcellana served as panelists at the inaugural workshop in 1962. Other former fellows include Bienvenido Santos, Doreen G. Fernandez, N. V. M. Gonzalez, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

In the same way that more than half of “second-wave” programs in the United States were founded by Iowa graduates, subsequent workshops in the Philippines are said to be modeled after Silliman. Former Silliman fellows and panelists went on to become part of other workshops, often bringing with them the critical praxis they had learned in Dumaguete. These include Jaime An Lim, Anthony Tan, Christine Godinez-Ortega, and Leoncio Deriada with the Iligan workshop; Erlinda Alburo with the Cornelio Faigao Workshop; Ophelia Dimalanta with the UST workshop; Elsa Coscolluela, Grace Monte de Ramos, and Marjorie Evasco with the IYAS workshop; Merlie Alunan with the UP Visayas workshops; and Aida Rivera-Ford and Ricky de Ungria with the Davao Writers Workshop.

The annual workshops in Dumaguete are also credited for the spread and ascendance of New Criticism as a critical lens and, consequently, a “Silliman school of writing,” which places a premium on craft above everything else (Alunan 1997, 115). Dominant in the United States from the 1940s to the 1960s, New Criticism views literary texts as autonomous, self-contained objects. The workshops at Silliman generally scrutinized works based on such standards, favoring those that have a certain “finish, smoothness, and polish” (119). This emphasis on aesthetics and form, while recognized for improving writers’ technique, has also been criticized for its willful disregard of context.

UP began the UP National Writers Summer Workshop three years after the founding of the Silliman workshop, in 1965, and was held every other year thereafter until 1980, when it started to be held annually for 10 days and, eventually, a week. The venue was mainly in Diliman and, occasionally, in UP’s other campuses in Cebu, Davao, Tacloban, Miag-ao, and Baguio, where it has been held since 2003. After it was established in 1979, the UP Creative Writing Center (UPCWC) started to take charge of the workshop. Alejandrino Hufana, Francisco Arcellana, and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio served successively as directors of the center and became prime movers of the annual workshop, assisted by a workshop director. Applicants submit samples of their works, which are then evaluated by the associate directors of the UPCWC. Board and lodging, as well as a minimal allowance, are provided for the students. Works in poetry, fiction, and drama, in both English and Filipino, are discussed. Sometimes, a particular genre, theme, or audience is given focus in a workshop. For instance, the 1983 workshop was in children’s literature, 1984 in poetry, 1985 in fiction, 1986 in drama, and 1990 in gender issues. Aside from the workshops, there are lectures and discussions on a certain topic. Among those who have been workshop directors are N. V. M. Gonzalez, Elmer Ordoñez, Gemino Abad, Jose Dalisay Jr, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, Domingo Landicho, and Thelma Kintanar. In 2007, the workshop was reformatted to cater to “mid-career” writers to respond to the dearth in mentorship for writers who are in a latter stage of their careers. Thus, only those who have already published a book or who are about to publish their first book are eligible.

Influenced by the university’s nationalist leaning, the conduct of the UP National Writers Workshop, including its theme, venue, orientation, and format, is seen as being more attuned to history, a counterpoint to Silliman’s formalist tendencies (Ordoñez 1993, 215). The analyses often “incline heavily towards all forms of Marxism” (Bautista 1998).

Like UP’s, the Ateneo Writers’ Workshop was also established in 1965 but lasted only until 1968, although the university had a workshop on writing in Pilipino in 1970. It was revived in 2001. UST held its first national writers’ workshop in 2000. It was discontinued in 2009 and revived in 2012 but limited to invited UST students. It became competitive and national in scope again in 2014. UP’s Department of Filipino and Philippine Literature set up the Palihang Rogelio Sicat (Rogelio Sicat Workshop) in 2008 for works in Filipino and other Philippine languages with Filipino translations. Criticism workshops include UST’s J. Elizalde Navarro National Workshop on Criticism and DLSU’s Kritika National Workshop on Art and Cultural Criticism.

 

For writers in the regional languages, workshops have long been a boon because of the dearth of other institutional support (Nadera 2007). The Cebuano Studies Center of the University of San Carlos in Cebu began the Cornelio Faigao Memorial Annual Writers Workshop in 1984 for works in Cebuano and English. Named after Faigao, who was then chairman of USC’s English Department, it is the longest-running workshop that accepts work in a regional language. The Iligan National Writers Workshop was set up in 1994 by the Mindanao State University–Iligan Institute of Technology. Explicitly geared to promote regional literature, it allocates slots to fellows from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. Works in Cebuano, Hiligaynon, Karay-a, as well as in English and Filipino, are eligible for the IYAS Creative Writing Workshop, established in Bacolod City’s University of St. La Salle in 2001. Other university-based workshops include UP Tacloban’s Panagsugat All-Visayas Workshop, Ateneo de Zamboanga’s Western Mindanao Writers Workshop, UP Clark’s Kapampangan workshops, and UP Baguio’s Cordillera Creative Writing Workshop.

 

Despite the apparent breadth and number of such activities, funding for writing workshops remains to be limited (Pernia 2002, 11). Even Silliman, which has achieved a measure of stature, “constantly faces the threat of dissolution because of financial constraints.” In 1990, Silliman University withdrew its support of the workshop, forcing organizers to look for government and corporate sponsors. It “returned” to Silliman only in 2008. The 17th edition of the Iligan workshop did not get its usual funding from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and fellows had to pay for their own transportation, board, and lodging.

Over the decades, workshops have also been a major project of most literary organizations, like the Galian sa Arte at Tula on poetry; Katha on fiction; Telon Playwrights Circle on drama; Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas on the teaching of literature; Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat on grassroots writing; and the Artista at Manunulat ng Sambayanan (Armas) on revolutionary literature. Campus organizations, like the UP Writers’ Club and Ateneo’s Heights, also hold annual workshops.

Now a yearly five-month-long course, the poetry clinic of Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo (LIRA) traces its roots to the weekly critiquing session of a small group of young poets under the guidance of Virgilio S. Almario. Over the years, it has produced a roster of important writers in Filipino, including founding members Romulo P. Baquiran Jr and Vim Nadera, as well as Teo Antonio, Luna Sicat, Michael M. Coroza, Fidel Rillo, and Rebecca Añonuevo. The LIRA clinic, which emphasizes “a strong grounding in Filipino literary traditions” before transitioning to more “modern” forms, conforms with the nativist poetics of Almario, who as workshop director emeritus continues to exert a strong influence on the clinic’s conduct.

In 2008, the group started a nationwide outreach program called Sining ng Tugma at Sukat (later Pambansang Edukasyong Pampanitikan) for nonmembers. The two-day seminar for teachers and students also focus on “native literary works and forms,” with sessions on “Sining ng Tugma at Sukat” (Art of Rhyme and Meter) and “Sining ng Talinghaga at Tayutay” (Art of Metaphor and Figures of Speech).

Poetry group and alternative press High Chair has also developed a poetry appreciation program called Compass, in which members visit school- and community-based writers’ groups and conduct discussions and workshops. The group Pinoypoets used the Internet as a venue to train members, mostly poets and poetry enthusiasts, with online writing exercises and workshops. The Lit Critters, a group of writers of speculative fiction, continues to hold workshops for members and prospective members alike.

Regional organizations also conduct workshops, from those that are exclusive to members to others that are open to the public: Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano iti Filipinas Inc and the Baguio Writers Group for writers from northern Luzon; Kabulig-Bikol, Parasurat Bikolnon, and An Banwa: Kultura buda Arte kan Tabaco for writers from Bicol; Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang, Women in Literary Arts, and Tarantula for writers in Cebuano; and the Davao Writers’ Guild for writers from Mindanao.

State cultural institutions also fund workshops. The NCCA has held workshops on regional writing, emergent literature, and women’s writing. The Cultural Center of the Philippines, through its Coordinating Center for Literature, offers workshop and venue grants for literary organizations and institutions. For example, it was funding from the CCP that helped revive Western Visayas writing through workshops in the late 1980s and early 1990s (Cichon 2006).

As a result of all these activities, by the 1990s, “young writing” had become inseparable from universities (Lumbera 1995, 5). The decade saw, in addition to even more workshops, the establishment or reopening of more university-based creative writing centers and programs similar to UP’s. These have provided writers with more “institutional resources to undertake training and publication projects” (Dalisay 2007, 8). These include the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices, 2000; the De La Salle University Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center, 1991; and the UST Center for Creative Writing and Literary Studies, 1999, reopened, 2012. Silliman University’s Creative Writing Center was renamed the Edilberto K. Tiempo and Edith L. Tiempo Creative Writing Center in 2012 after Edith L. Tiempo’s death the previous year.

Of these, Silliman has the oldest and longest-running creative writing program in the country, established by the Tiempos in 1951 as a possible area of concentration for English majors (Pernia 2002, 6). An MA was set up in 1960, which required attendance at the then-semestral writers’ workshop, a thesis in a student’s chosen genre, and an examination. An MFA, described as “a specialized degree program … intermediate between the usual MA and the doctor’s degree,” was briefly offered in 1972 before being canceled owing to the lack of enrollees (49). It currently has a PhD program under which students may submit a creative work with a critical introduction.

Other schools followed suit. In UP Los Baños, communication arts students can specialize in creative writing. UP Mindanao’s program, set up in 1995, is the only one of its kind in Mindanao. DLSU offers an MFA and a DFA, while Ateneo offers a BFA. UST, whose literature students can take creative writing electives, revived its MA program in 2012. Far Eastern University, Miriam College, and the University of San Carlos offer creative writing electives, but these do not lead to an academic degree. Starting in 1992, students at the state-funded Philippine High School for the Arts in Los Baños can major in creative writing.

This increase in creative writing programs, especially at the graduate level, mirrors a similar boom in postwar United States. In America, this surge is said to have had the most impact on postwar American literary production. It forged new roles for writers, turning “[older] writers into salaried writing professors and students into tuition-paying apprentices” (McGurl 2009, 4). As proof of the programs’ positive contribution, proponents point to the “surfeit of literary excellence,” the “system-wide rise” in the quality of American literature after World War II (410). In the Philippines, the relevance and efficacy of creative writing programs—and the workshop structure at their pedagogical core—have similarly been defended, often by the argument that training programs in other arts, such as in music and dance, are rarely, if at all, questioned (Dalisay 2013). Meanwhile, in the United States, critics have argued that the phenomenon has homogenized writing, with students coming up mostly with the “workshop story” or “McPoem” (Earnshaw 2007, 20). The New Critical emphasis on aesthetics and aversion to “extra-literary” ideas have also been criticized as simplistic and naive. The ideological underside of creative writing programs during the Cold War has also been up for scrutiny (Bennett 2014).

In the end, the full impact of training activities on the country’s literary landscape cannot be fully ascertained by any statistical data, although the achievements of writers who participate in workshops, undergo informal tutelages, and enroll in creative writing programs can be seen as products of these modes of training. Their effects are more “cumulative, rather than periodic … the effervescence evident in the writing scene” (Bautista 1998). While literary training platforms can be manipulated to be conduits of self-serving politics and ideology, at their best, they can help “inaugurate … the sensitivity, the imagination, and the craftsmanship” necessary in the writers’ continued practice of their vocation.  Written by Joi Barrios, updated by Glenn Diaz, with notes from Phillip Kimpo Jr, Mabi David, and John Bengan

article.value: Literary training is the process by which writers learn their craft. In the Philippines, this activity includes the training of students in the creation and transmission of oral literature, formal education in universities offering creative or imaginative writing courses, and workshops offered by cultural institutions and organizations involved in literary creation.

In the case of oral literature, because it is continually evolving, the singer and the storyteller are themselves creators of literary works. In epics, for example, accretion and omission occur; characters, elements, and passages are added, embellished, or deleted. Some forms of literary expression may be etched on bamboo like the surat Mangyan.

article.value: The epic is learned at an early age, usually from a relative. Pagyaw, E. Arsenio Manuel’s source for the Manobo songs The Maiden of the Buhong Sky and Tuwaang Attends a Wedding, learned them from a bard named Inuk, who belonged to a family of epic chanters. Liyos Ambog, the source for the Subanon epic Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan (The Kingdom of Keboklagan), learned it from her mother Anaya. Anaya’s mother Sapar had learned it at the age of six. Blagtas Pandakan, the source for Agyu, learned the epic from his uncle Sugalan, who, in turn, had learned it from his father Ampalid.

Precolonial poets followed rules, learning from childhood that each stanza consisted of three, four, or five lines with a single assonantal rhyme (Lumbera 1986). The conventions of oral literary forms, such as formulaic repetitions, stereotyping of characters, and regular rhythmic and musical devices—learned during childhood—facilitated the transmission of poems, songs, tales, and sayings. Over time, the origin and original meaning of the words may be lost as the songs are learned by rote. The contemporary Tboli, once practicing an animistic religion, have become Christians, and call their place Santa Cruz instead of Lemlunay. They continue to chant a song about Lemlunay taught to them by the babaylan (priestess), yet they cannot explain the meaning of the phrases “spirits that guard” and “spirits that destroy” (Almario 1991).

During the Spanish colonial period, European poetic forms were introduced by the Spanish friars who ran printing presses and published books. The octosyllabic romance, for example, was used by Fr Francisco de San Jose in Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua Tagala (Guidelines for the Christian Life in the Tagalog Language), 1605. It was also in this book that the term ladino was first used to refer to poems in both Spanish and Tagalog, and to poets writing in this manner. The first verses written by Filipinos using the romance are attributed to Fernando Bagongbanta and the anonymous author of the poem “May Bagyo Ma’t May Rilim” (Though It is Stormy and Dark). During the 18th century, Tondo became known as a center for poets. Jose de la Cruz, considered to be the best among them, is said to have taught himself philosophy and canon law. He became the teacher of many aspiring poets, such as Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas, Ananias Zorilla, Tomas Ledo, and the brothers Juan and Prudencio Feliciano. De la Cruz reputedly charged a sisiw (chick) for lessons, thus earning the epithet “Huseng Sisiw.” De la Cruz wrote poems at the request of young men courting women, and he scripted dramas commissioned by committees for town fiestas. In this way, the language of Tagalog poetry “moved from the earthiness of Gaspar Aquino de Belen to the refinement and elegance of Jose de la Cruz.” Poetic diction may be said to have begun with De la Cruz (Lumbera 1986, 103).

It was Balagtas’s works which represented the fusion of all the traditions of Tagalog poetry from the 16th to the 19th century. After obtaining the equivalent of a high school education at the San Juan de Letran, Balagtas took higher studies, which included Latin, philosophy, theology, canon law, and Roman and Spanish laws, at the Colegio de San Jose. His works show that he had read Virgil and Homer and was familiar with Greek and Roman mythology. In Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), ca. 1838, Balagtas not only employs the talinghaga and the monorhyming quatrain of precolonial Tagalog poetry; he also uses classical allusions and incorporates diverse elements of the Spanish ballad.

When the Spanish colonial government established a system of education in 1863, rhetoric and poetry were among the courses included in programs leading to a bachillerato en artes (bachelor of arts). In the normal schools and universities, students read trozos or selections from famous Catholic and Castilian prose and verse writers like Cervantes, Mariana, Fray Luis de Leon, Herrera, Rioja, Zorilla, and Lope de Vega (Tiongson 1978).

The rise of the middle class in the 19th century resulted in its sending its children to Europe to study. While no records show that they studied creative writing formally, many were influenced by, on the one hand, the literary works they read in Europe and, on the other, the folk forms familiar to them. Jose Rizal studied medicine but followed the tradition of realism employed by Galdos, Balzac, Hugo, and Dickens. Meanwhile, Marcelo H. del Pilar, who studied law at the University of Santo Tomas, deliberately used folk and popular forms for his poems and satirical works (Lumbera 1986, 140). Both propagandists also mastered the essay as shown in Rizal’s “Su Excelencia, Señor Don Vicente Barrantes” (His Excellency, Mr Vicente Barrantes) and Del Pilar’s “Asimilacion de Filipinas” (Assimilation of the Philippines).

Examples of revolutionary literature written in Tagalog using monorhyming quatrains are the trilogy of poems “Hibik ng Pilipinas sa Inang España (Filipinas’ Lament to Mother Spain), 1889, by Hermenegildo Flores; “Sagot nang España sa Hibik nang Pilipinas” (Spain’s Reply to Filipinas’ Lament), 1889, by Marcelo H. del Pilar; and “Katapusang Hibik ng Pilipinas” (Last Lament of Filipinas), 1896, by Andres Bonifacio. The first two poems were written as companion pieces; Flores was both teacher and fellow propagandist to del Pilar. Bonifacio became familiar with versification as an actor in Tagalog plays and was much inspired by Rizal’s two novels, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. These two factors may have contributed to the dramatic force and explicit revolutionary intent of his reply to “Hibik” and “Sagot.”

After the establishment of the Revolutionary Government of Malolos on 23 Jun 1898, immediately created were the Universidad Literaria de Filipinas on 19 Oct 1898 and the Instituto Burgos, which set the curriculum followed by other schools. While Tagalog had been proclaimed the national language, the general curriculum continued to include the reading and writing of Spanish and the appreciation of Spanish literature. Among the teachers were writers Pedro Paterno and Leon Ma. Guerrero (Tiongson 1978, 141).

During the first decades of the 20th century, the American Insular Government pursued two orientations in the education of Filipinos for “citizenship”: industrial or manual education, begun by Fred Atkinson; and “literary” or liberal education, first broached by David Barrows. English was made the language of instruction in 1900. Elementary schools used the Baldwin Readers and later the Insular Readers. In high schools, students became familiar with works such as Longfellow’s “Evangeline”; Irving’s Sketchbook; an anthology titled English Poems from Chaucer to Kipling, George Eliot’s Silas Marner; and Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice and Macbeth (Tiongson 1978, 141-47).

Even with the establishment of more colleges and universities and the teaching of language and literature, creative writing in Tagalog or in any of the other regional languages was not taught as a subject. Instead, poets continued to follow “rules” learned through other poets or their works. The formalization of these rules of traditional poetry, which had come to be called balagtasismo, after Balagtas, was made by Lope K. Santos in his paper “Particularidades de la Poesia Tagala” (Particularities of Tagalog Poetry), 1929, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda in Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog (The Three Periods of Tagalog Poetry), 1947. The formal teaching of poetry, however, has been limited to the mechanical use of rhetorical elements; observance of the basic rules on rhyme and meter; and the memorization of the aral (lesson) from versification. Additional elements, such as irony and tension, were studied from the works of foreign writers, such as William Empson, I. A. Richards, Paul Valery, or Charles Olson, who were deemed superior to Filipino critics and writers like Teodoro E. Gener or Rufino Alejandro (Almario 1991, 5).

Among the first-generation novelists were Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Roman Reyes, Gabriel Beato Francisco, Patricio Mariano, Severino Reyes, Aurelio Tolentino, Lope K. Santos, Faustino Aguilar, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, and Juan Arsciwals. Born in the late 19th century, many of them finished secondary education at Ateneo de Manila, San Juan de Letran, or the Universidad de Santo Tomas, where they became familiar with the works of Quevedo, Cervantes, Galdos, Voltaire, Zola, Dumas, and Eugene Sue. Many were also educated during the American colonial period. The works of Shakespeare, Hugo, Dante, Milton, Tolstoy, and Dumas were studied for forms and themes. These works were translated into Tagalog by Gerardo Changco, Francisco Laksamana, Narciso Asistio, and Rosendo Ignacio.

article.value: Established by the American colonial government in 1908, the University of the Philippines (UP) and, in particular, its College of Arts and Sciences, greatly contributed to the rise of English as a literary language in the opening decades of the 20th century. Creative writing classes today may be traced to the composition classes under its Department of English during the American colonial period. In terms of training, no other Philippine university would go on to have a more “significant” and “sustained” impact in creative writing—particularly in English (Dalisay 2007, 7). Most of the first- and second-generation writers in English studied at UP. The undergraduate English classes served as their training ground as writers. Angela Manalang Gloria, Jose Garcia Villa, Casiano Calalang, F. B. Icasiano, Luis Dato, and Loreto Paras-Sulit, and, later, Manuel Arguilla, Bienvenido Santos, Arturo B. Rotor, Salvador P. Lopez, Maria Luna-Lopez, Maria Kalaw, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, and Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla were classmates in UP. Among the teachers were George Pope Shannon, Paz Marquez-Benitez, C. V. Wickers, Vicente M. Hilario, Cristina Jamias, Carlos P. Romulo, and A. V. H. Hartendorp. Paz Marquez-Benitez, who wrote the first Filipino modern short story in English, held a short story class thrice a week that proved to be training ground for many beginning fictionists. She encouraged new work, “good or bad,” helping students polish their style and technique (Alegre and Fernandez 1984, 98, 113). It was under her class where Casiano Calalang wrote “Soft Clay,” Paras-Sulit wrote “Laarni,” and Bienvenido Santos wrote “The Years are Very Long,” which she reputedly described as “the best story I have read written by a Filipino.”

article.value: Essay writing was taught by Professor Valenzuela, while literature teacher C. V. Wickers encouraged Angela Manalang Gloria and Luis Dato to write poetry. Other teachers included Tom Inglis Moore in poetry, Robert Conklin in advanced English, and Mrs Conklin in dramatic presentation. Today, UP Diliman is the only university that offers the full range of programs in creative writing in English and Filipino, from the two-year certificate to a PhD.

Organizations also became a venue for training writers, often in the form of workshops and other methods of informal tutelage. Many of the writers who were members of the UP Writers’ Club or staffers of the Philippine Collegian held informal sessions to discuss each other’s stories and poems as well as current literature. The works of Wilbur Daniel Steele, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg, Amy Lowell, Bernard Shaw, Vidal Tan, and Carlos P. Romulo were among those they discussed. The Ravens, which had started as an offshoot of the UP Writers’ Club, were mentored by N. V. M. Gonzalez, who conducted informal workshops at his residence.

Some first-generation writers also went abroad for formal training in creative writing. Maria Kalaw-Katigbak was awarded the Barbour Scholarship in Michigan in 1933 and majored in creative writing. In 1941, Bienvenido Santos, then president of Legazpi College, went to the United States on a Rockefeller Grant and at one point studied under American novelist Philip Roth. N. V. M. Gonzalez, also on a Rockefeller, went to the United States in the late 1940s and was influenced by a number of “Southern Agrarians” who championed a militant regionalism that resonated with his so-called rural sensibility. All three, including Salvador P. Lopez and Leopoldo Yabes, would become teachers.

The training for some second-generation writers consisted of reading as well as of direct interaction with other writers and critics. The books of Erskine Caldwell, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Thomas Wolfe were available to them. However, it was through writing workshops that most gained access to the works of others and improved their craft. The workshop model, together with the creative writing programs in universities, would prove to be the most defining training venues for Filipino writers, especially in English.

Edilberto and Edith L. Tiempo, who along with Ricaredo Demetillo and Dominador Ilio were the first Asians to attend the prestigious Iowa Writers’ Workshop, institutionalized the workshop model in the Philippines when they established the Silliman National Writers Workshop in 1962. Patterned after the pioneering Iowa Writers’ Workshop, it was originally under Silliman’s English department. It traces its roots to a university-based semestral workshop that was credited for two to three units, which students could get upon official arrangement with Edilberto Tiempo. Held every summer for five, and, eventually, three weeks in Dumaguete City, the workshop discussions center on the poems, short stories, plays, and essays submitted by the participants, the majority of whom write in English. Occasional works in Filipino and other regional languages were submitted with translations until it became an all-English workshop. Applicants submit samples of their works—three to five short stories, a suite of seven poems or so, three to five essays, a play—and recommendation letters from professors or former workshop fellows. Applications average 70-80 a year. Board and lodging, as well as minimal transportation and living allowances, are provided to the chosen participants.

The Tiempos ran the workshop for nearly 50 years, a period in which their name became synonymous with Silliman and all that it stood for in the literary world. Their daughter Rowena Tiempo-Torrevillas, herself a writer and professor at the University of Iowa, took over as director in 2011. Succeeding her were Susan Lara and Ricardo de Ungria. Over the years, regular panelists have included Dumaguete-based writers Cesar Ruiz Aquino, Myrna Peña-Reyes, Bobby Villasis, and Ernesto Superal-Yee, and guest panelists such as Gemino Abad, Merlie Alunan, Marjorie Evasco, D. M. Reyes, and Alfred A. Yuson.

The Silliman Workshop has had a “tremendous influence” in creative writing in English in the country, as well as in other writers’ workshops (Pernia 2002, 7). “Practically all Filipino writers of any importance” have gone to Silliman at one point, either as fellows, lecturers, or panelists (Bautista 1998). Its roster of alumni includes Gregorio Brillantes, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, Emmanuel Lacaba, Virgilio S. Almario, Ninotchka Rosca, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Cirilo F. Bautista, Ricky Lee, Aida Rivera-Ford, Estrella Alfon, Jun Cruz Reyes, Edel Garcellano, Merlie Alunan, Ophelia Dimalanta, Jose Dalisay, Marjorie Evasco, Rofel Brion, and Rene Amper. National Artists Nick Joaquin and Francisco Arcellana served as panelists at the inaugural workshop in 1962. Other former fellows include Bienvenido Santos, Doreen G. Fernandez, N. V. M. Gonzalez, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

In the same way that more than half of “second-wave” programs in the United States were founded by Iowa graduates, subsequent workshops in the Philippines are said to be modeled after Silliman. Former Silliman fellows and panelists went on to become part of other workshops, often bringing with them the critical praxis they had learned in Dumaguete. These include Jaime An Lim, Anthony Tan, Christine Godinez-Ortega, and Leoncio Deriada with the Iligan workshop; Erlinda Alburo with the Cornelio Faigao Workshop; Ophelia Dimalanta with the UST workshop; Elsa Coscolluela, Grace Monte de Ramos, and Marjorie Evasco with the IYAS workshop; Merlie Alunan with the UP Visayas workshops; and Aida Rivera-Ford and Ricky de Ungria with the Davao Writers Workshop.

The annual workshops in Dumaguete are also credited for the spread and ascendance of New Criticism as a critical lens and, consequently, a “Silliman school of writing,” which places a premium on craft above everything else (Alunan 1997, 115). Dominant in the United States from the 1940s to the 1960s, New Criticism views literary texts as autonomous, self-contained objects. The workshops at Silliman generally scrutinized works based on such standards, favoring those that have a certain “finish, smoothness, and polish” (119). This emphasis on aesthetics and form, while recognized for improving writers’ technique, has also been criticized for its willful disregard of context.

UP began the UP National Writers Summer Workshop three years after the founding of the Silliman workshop, in 1965, and was held every other year thereafter until 1980, when it started to be held annually for 10 days and, eventually, a week. The venue was mainly in Diliman and, occasionally, in UP’s other campuses in Cebu, Davao, Tacloban, Miag-ao, and Baguio, where it has been held since 2003. After it was established in 1979, the UP Creative Writing Center (UPCWC) started to take charge of the workshop. Alejandrino Hufana, Francisco Arcellana, and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio served successively as directors of the center and became prime movers of the annual workshop, assisted by a workshop director. Applicants submit samples of their works, which are then evaluated by the associate directors of the UPCWC. Board and lodging, as well as a minimal allowance, are provided for the students. Works in poetry, fiction, and drama, in both English and Filipino, are discussed. Sometimes, a particular genre, theme, or audience is given focus in a workshop. For instance, the 1983 workshop was in children’s literature, 1984 in poetry, 1985 in fiction, 1986 in drama, and 1990 in gender issues. Aside from the workshops, there are lectures and discussions on a certain topic. Among those who have been workshop directors are N. V. M. Gonzalez, Elmer Ordoñez, Gemino Abad, Jose Dalisay Jr, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, Domingo Landicho, and Thelma Kintanar. In 2007, the workshop was reformatted to cater to “mid-career” writers to respond to the dearth in mentorship for writers who are in a latter stage of their careers. Thus, only those who have already published a book or who are about to publish their first book are eligible.

Influenced by the university’s nationalist leaning, the conduct of the UP National Writers Workshop, including its theme, venue, orientation, and format, is seen as being more attuned to history, a counterpoint to Silliman’s formalist tendencies (Ordoñez 1993, 215). The analyses often “incline heavily towards all forms of Marxism” (Bautista 1998).

Like UP’s, the Ateneo Writers’ Workshop was also established in 1965 but lasted only until 1968, although the university had a workshop on writing in Pilipino in 1970. It was revived in 2001. UST held its first national writers’ workshop in 2000. It was discontinued in 2009 and revived in 2012 but limited to invited UST students. It became competitive and national in scope again in 2014. UP’s Department of Filipino and Philippine Literature set up the Palihang Rogelio Sicat (Rogelio Sicat Workshop) in 2008 for works in Filipino and other Philippine languages with Filipino translations. Criticism workshops include UST’s J. Elizalde Navarro National Workshop on Criticism and DLSU’s Kritika National Workshop on Art and Cultural Criticism.

For writers in the regional languages, workshops have long been a boon because of the dearth of other institutional support (Nadera 2007). The Cebuano Studies Center of the University of San Carlos in Cebu began the Cornelio Faigao Memorial Annual Writers Workshop in 1984 for works in Cebuano and English. Named after Faigao, who was then chairman of USC’s English Department, it is the longest-running workshop that accepts work in a regional language. The Iligan National Writers Workshop was set up in 1994 by the Mindanao State University–Iligan Institute of Technology. Explicitly geared to promote regional literature, it allocates slots to fellows from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. Works in Cebuano, Hiligaynon, Karay-a, as well as in English and Filipino, are eligible for the IYAS Creative Writing Workshop, established in Bacolod City’s University of St. La Salle in 2001. Other university-based workshops include UP Tacloban’s Panagsugat All-Visayas Workshop, Ateneo de Zamboanga’s Western Mindanao Writers Workshop, UP Clark’s Kapampangan workshops, and UP Baguio’s Cordillera Creative Writing Workshop.

Despite the apparent breadth and number of such activities, funding for writing workshops remains to be limited (Pernia 2002, 11). Even Silliman, which has achieved a measure of stature, “constantly faces the threat of dissolution because of financial constraints.” In 1990, Silliman University withdrew its support of the workshop, forcing organizers to look for government and corporate sponsors. It “returned” to Silliman only in 2008. The 17th edition of the Iligan workshop did not get its usual funding from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and fellows had to pay for their own transportation, board, and lodging.

Over the decades, workshops have also been a major project of most literary organizations, like the Galian sa Arte at Tula on poetry; Katha on fiction; Telon Playwrights Circle on drama; Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas on the teaching of literature; Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat on grassroots writing; and the Artista at Manunulat ng Sambayanan (Armas) on revolutionary literature. Campus organizations, like the UP Writers’ Club and Ateneo’s Heights, also hold annual workshops.

Now a yearly five-month-long course, the poetry clinic of Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo (LIRA) traces its roots to the weekly critiquing session of a small group of young poets under the guidance of Virgilio S. Almario. Over the years, it has produced a roster of important writers in Filipino, including founding members Romulo P. Baquiran Jr and Vim Nadera, as well as Teo Antonio, Luna Sicat, Michael M. Coroza, Fidel Rillo, and Rebecca Añonuevo. The LIRA clinic, which emphasizes “a strong grounding in Filipino literary traditions” before transitioning to more “modern” forms, conforms with the nativist poetics of Almario, who as workshop director emeritus continues to exert a strong influence on the clinic’s conduct.

In 2008, the group started a nationwide outreach program called Sining ng Tugma at Sukat (later Pambansang Edukasyong Pampanitikan) for nonmembers. The two-day seminar for teachers and students also focus on “native literary works and forms,” with sessions on “Sining ng Tugma at Sukat” (Art of Rhyme and Meter) and “Sining ng Talinghaga at Tayutay” (Art of Metaphor and Figures of Speech).

Poetry group and alternative press High Chair has also developed a poetry appreciation program called Compass, in which members visit school- and community-based writers’ groups and conduct discussions and workshops. The group Pinoypoets used the Internet as a venue to train members, mostly poets and poetry enthusiasts, with online writing exercises and workshops. The Lit Critters, a group of writers of speculative fiction, continues to hold workshops for members and prospective members alike.

Regional organizations also conduct workshops, from those that are exclusive to members to others that are open to the public: Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano iti Filipinas Inc and the Baguio Writers Group for writers from northern Luzon; Kabulig-Bikol, Parasurat Bikolnon, and An Banwa: Kultura buda Arte kan Tabaco for writers from Bicol; Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang, Women in Literary Arts, and Tarantula for writers in Cebuano; and the Davao Writers’ Guild for writers from Mindanao.

State cultural institutions also fund workshops. The NCCA has held workshops on regional writing, emergent literature, and women’s writing. The Cultural Center of the Philippines, through its Coordinating Center for Literature, offers workshop and venue grants for literary organizations and institutions. For example, it was funding from the CCP that helped revive Western Visayas writing through workshops in the late 1980s and early 1990s (Cichon 2006).

As a result of all these activities, by the 1990s, “young writing” had become inseparable from universities (Lumbera 1995, 5). The decade saw, in addition to even more workshops, the establishment or reopening of more university-based creative writing centers and programs similar to UP’s. These have provided writers with more “institutional resources to undertake training and publication projects” (Dalisay 2007, 8). These include the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices, 2000; the De La Salle University Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center, 1991; and the UST Center for Creative Writing and Literary Studies, 1999, reopened, 2012. Silliman University’s Creative Writing Center was renamed the Edilberto K. Tiempo and Edith L. Tiempo Creative Writing Center in 2012 after Edith L. Tiempo’s death the previous year.

Of these, Silliman has the oldest and longest-running creative writing program in the country, established by the Tiempos in 1951 as a possible area of concentration for English majors (Pernia 2002, 6). An MA was set up in 1960, which required attendance at the then-semestral writers’ workshop, a thesis in a student’s chosen genre, and an examination. An MFA, described as “a specialized degree program … intermediate between the usual MA and the doctor’s degree,” was briefly offered in 1972 before being canceled owing to the lack of enrollees (49). It currently has a PhD program under which students may submit a creative work with a critical introduction.

Other schools followed suit. In UP Los Baños, communication arts students can specialize in creative writing. UP Mindanao’s program, set up in 1995, is the only one of its kind in Mindanao. DLSU offers an MFA and a DFA, while Ateneo offers a BFA. UST, whose literature students can take creative writing electives, revived its MA program in 2012. Far Eastern University, Miriam College, and the University of San Carlos offer creative writing electives, but these do not lead to an academic degree. Starting in 1992, students at the state-funded Philippine High School for the Arts in Los Baños can major in creative writing.

This increase in creative writing programs, especially at the graduate level, mirrors a similar boom in postwar United States. In America, this surge is said to have had the most impact on postwar American literary production. It forged new roles for writers, turning “[older] writers into salaried writing professors and students into tuition-paying apprentices” (McGurl 2009, 4). As proof of the programs’ positive contribution, proponents point to the “surfeit of literary excellence,” the “system-wide rise” in the quality of American literature after World War II (410). In the Philippines, the relevance and efficacy of creative writing programs—and the workshop structure at their pedagogical core—have similarly been defended, often by the argument that training programs in other arts, such as in music and dance, are rarely, if at all, questioned (Dalisay 2013). Meanwhile, in the United States, critics have argued that the phenomenon has homogenized writing, with students coming up mostly with the “workshop story” or “McPoem” (Earnshaw 2007, 20). The New Critical emphasis on aesthetics and aversion to “extra-literary” ideas have also been criticized as simplistic and naive. The ideological underside of creative writing programs during the Cold War has also been up for scrutiny (Bennett 2014).

In the end, the full impact of training activities on the country’s literary landscape cannot be fully ascertained by any statistical data, although the achievements of writers who participate in workshops, undergo informal tutelages, and enroll in creative writing programs can be seen as products of these modes of training. Their effects are more “cumulative, rather than periodic … the effervescence evident in the writing scene” (Bautista 1998). While literary training platforms can be manipulated to be conduits of self-serving politics and ideology, at their best, they can help “inaugurate … the sensitivity, the imagination, and the craftsmanship” necessary in the writers’ continued practice of their vocation.  Written by Joi Barrios, updated by Glenn Diaz, with notes from Phillip Kimpo Jr, Mabi David, and John Bengan
