text:
Sections

Spanish Colonial Period
The American Colonial Period and the Japanese Occupation
After World War II
From the 1990s to the Present

 

Translation is the rendition of a work from one language to another, whereas adaptation is the retelling of a work that does not necessarily involve a change in language. When a work is adapted, it is modified to fit into certain conditions or conventions different from those in which it originally appears. Settings, for example, may be localized; and plots, rearranged, condensed, or extended to appeal to a target audience. Generally, translation is a matter of language; adaptation, of form. Thus, Gerardo Chanco’s Sa Gitna ng Lusak (Wallowing in Mud), 1918, would be a Tagalog translation of the Spanish version of Alexandre Dumas’s Camille, 1882; Cora Ifugo’s Lisa, being made for dance, would be an adaptation.

In the Philippine experience, however, translations and adaptations are not always separate. Ruperto S. Cristobal’s Ang Bulaklak sa Kabaret (The Flower in the Cabaret), 1920, for example, is both a translation into Filipino and, with its Filipinized setting, an adaptation of Dumas’s novel. Moreover, a translation may be more than one step away from its source. For instance, Joaquin Tuason’s Ang Bagong Robinson, Historiang Nagtuturo nang Mabuting Caugalian, na Ginauang Tanungan (The New Robinson, Story That Teaches Good Conduct, Done in Primer Form), 1879, is a Tagalog translation of a Spanish translation of a German adaptation of the English novel Robinson Crusoe, 1719, by Daniel Defoe.

 

Translation and adaptation are done for various purposes. They may be done to aid proselytizing and moral edification. The Philippine Bible Society, the Translator’s Association of the Philippines, and the Summer Institute of Linguistics, for instance, have translated the Bible into different Philippine languages—Tagalog, Cebuano, Kapampangan, Pangasinan, Waray, Ilonggo, Ilocano, Bikol, and Tboli—to evangelize rural and tribal communities. Bible translation has come hand in hand with literacy projects in which indigenous folklore has been translated or adapted. Other translations or adaptations are done to foster nationalism or spread political propaganda. During the 19th century, translations of revolutionary literature, such as Jose Rizal’s essay “El Amor Patrio” (Love of Country), 1882, helped to spur the local folks to overthrow the Spanish colonial government. The contents of these translations advocate the love of freedom and forward a strong nationalist sentiment. Some translations or adaptations serve to heighten one’s consciousness of other cultures, to explore one’s own culture, and to exhibit it to foreign audiences. Mga Piling Akda buhat sa Panitikang Aleman (Selected Works from German Literature), 1970, by B. S. Medina makes German literature available to non-German readers. Conversely, Hiligaynon Literature: Texts and Contexts, 1992, edited by Lucila Hosillos, and Gaddang Literature, 1984, edited by Ma. Luisa Lumicao-Lora, allow foreign readers to enjoy local literatures. Translation societies pursue the twin tasks of preserving national literature and conscienticizing local and foreign audience by translating works from the different local languages. Translations may also have pedagogical purposes. The translation of children’s literature has been driven by educational policy to promote the national language, and to implement mother tongue instruction in the initial grades, and likewise by the business prospects of instructional materials development. Still other translations or adaptations, especially those of the Western classics during the early decades of American rule, serve as literary models. Local writers received pointers in writing and in experimenting with form. Other translations function primarily to provide entertainment, such as N. B. Bacalso’s translation of Captain Blood and of the comics series Siegfred, and Piux Kabahar’s translation of Bertoldo, Bartolino y Cacaseno (Bertoldo, Bartolino, and Cacaseno) by Giulio Cesare della Croce.

 

The history of translation in the Philippines actually predates the colonial era. Centuries before the coming of the Spaniards, Southeast Asia, being located between India and China was at the nexus of trade with China, India, the Mediterranean and Eurasia. Trade cities developed quickly where Arabic, Italian, Portuguese, and Chinese were spoken, but where Malay was the lingua franca (Reid 2000, 23). Malay became an important source language in which hundreds of Malay words passed on to Tagalog. The region, the Philippines included, was thus fertile ground for translational exchange, although not in the form of published texts. Folk literature in various versions circulated especially in the borderless seas of maritime Southeast Asia.

 

Spanish Colonial Period

The desire of the Spanish colonizers, who began to arrive in the islands in the 16th century, to Christianize the natives led to the translation of many religious texts into the local tongues. To do this, missionaries learned the local languages first and codified these in artes (grammar books) and vocabularios (dictionaries). Then, the friars used their printing presses to publish the translations of European religious literature from the 16th to the 19th century.

The first product of these presses was Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala (Christian Doctrine in the Spanish and Tagalog Languages), 1593, by Fr Domingo de Nieva, in which the original Spanish text appeared first, followed by the Tagalog text in Roman alphabet and a translation in the baybayin, the local syllabary.

Some other translations of catechisms, or books that expound on Catholic doctrines and guide believers in such practices as praying and confessing, were Fr Francisco Blancas de San Jose’s Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua Tagala (Guidelines for the Christian Life in the Tagalog Language), 1605, which was translated into Chinese as Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua China (Guidelines for the Christian Life in the Chinese Language) in 1605, and Librong Pinagpapalamnan Yto nang Aalisin nang Tauong Christiano sa Pagcoconfesar at sa Pagcocomulgar (Book Containing the Things That Should Be Removed by Confession and Communion), 1608; Explicacion de la Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Tagala (Explication of the Christian Doctrine in the Tagalog Language), 1628, by Fr Alonso de Santa Ana; and Mga Aral na Mahal (Sacred Lessons) by Fr Pedro Lopez, based on Fr Juan Eusebio’s Practica del Catecismo Romano (Practice of the Roman Catechism).

Among the catechisms translated later were Catecismo na Pinagpapalamnan nang manga Pangadyi at Maicling Casaysayan na Dapat Pagaralan ng Tauong Cristiano (Catechism Containing Prayers and Short Narratives That Should Be Studied by Christians), 1868, by Fr Luis de Amesquita, based on the original by Geronimo Ripalda; Pagpapaonaua na Parang Tanongan sa Caocolang Dapat na Gagawin nang manga Batang Bagong Magcocompisal (Catechism on the Prerequisites to Be Fulfilled by Youths before Confession), based on a Spanish original by Fr Miguel de la Madre de Dios.

Other religious materials, such as prayer books, meditations, and novenas, were also translated. Among them were Meditaciones, cun manga Mahal na Pagninilay na Sadia sa Santong Pag Eexercicios (Meditations, or Holy Reflections Proper to the Spiritual Exercises), 1645, by Fr Pedro de Herrera, based on the Spanish Meditaciones, a retreat manual by Fr Francisco de Salazar; Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Commendation for the Soul of the Dying), 1760, by Gaspar Aquino de Belen, based on Thomas de Villacastin’s Recomendacion de las Almas, in turn a translation of Ordo Commendationis Animarum; and Pagsisiyam at Maicling Casaysayan Ucol sa Larauang Mapaghimala nang Mahal na Virgen nang Capayapaan at Mabuting Paglalayag, at nang manga Cababalaghang Gaua Niya, na Sinasamba sa Bayan ng Antipolo (Novenas and Short Narratives about the Miraculous Portrait of the Blessed Virgin of Peace and Good Voyage and Miracles Made by Her, Who is Worshipped by the Townspeople of Antipolo), 1835, by Mariano Pilapil, based on a Spanish original.

The earliest translations of prose narratives arose with the evangelical zeal of the Spanish missionaries. Works that expound on proper social behavior or holiness within a minimal narrative frame, generally called conduct books, were translated. Aral na Tunay na Totoong Pagaacay sa Tauo nang manga Cabanalang Gaua nang manga Maloualhating Santos na si Barlaan at ni Josaphat (Actual Lesson in Guiding People to Truth Based on the Holy Works of the Glorious Saints Barlaan and Josaphat), 1712, one of the earliest of its kind, is a translation by Fr Antonio de Borja of Jacobo Biblio’s Latin translation of a Greek version by San Juan Damasceno of the legend of Barlaan and Josaphat. During the European Renaissance, this tale was used by Spanish writers, such as Lope de Vega, who wrote the play Barlaan y Josafat, 1618. Joaquin Tuason translated another work with the same didactic intent: Ang Bagong Robinson, 1879.

 

Similarly, vidas, or biographies of saints, explain tenets of the Catholic religion through narrative. The lives of saints served as examples for the Filipino converts. Examples of vidas translated into the local languages include Roman de los Reyes’s Ang Sagrada Familia o Ang Buhay nang Mag Ina ni Jesus na Tumubos sa Atin (The Holy Family or the Life of the Mother and Her Son Jesus Who Has Redeemed Us), 1892, based on an excerpt from a book by Arcoiriz de Paz; Joaquin Tuason’s Ang manga Carangalan ni Maria (The Honors of Mary), 1878, based on the Spanish translation of an Italian original; Casaysayan nang manga Cababalaghan at Milagros na Guinaua nang Mahal na Virgen del Rosario na Sinasamba sa Capilla nang manga Pareng Dominico (Account of the Marvels and Miracles Made by the Blessed Virgin of the Rosary, Who is Venerated at the Chapel of the Dominican Priests) by Vicente Garcia; Buhay ni Santa Rita de Casia (Life of Saint Rita of Casia), 1895, by Fr Raimundo Cortazar, who appended a novena and prayers for the saint; and Buhay ni Santa Margarita de Cortona (Life of Saint Margaret de Cortona), 1888, by Joaquin Tuason, based on Luz de Menestral by Francisco Buina.

Adaptations of stories from the Bible and the Apocrypha were also done. Like the vidas, these give concrete insights into the lives of the faithful. Examples include Masamyong Bulaclac sa Jardin ni Jesucristo (Fragrant Flower in the Garden of Jesus Christ), by Lucio Caraan, which depicts the life of Jesus Christ, and Libro nang Martir sa Golgota (Book of the Martyr of Golgotha), 1886, by Juan Evangelista. Evangelista’s account of the life of Jesus is a translation of Enrique de Perez Escrich’s two-volume Spanish novel El Martir del Golgota: Tradiciones de Oriente (The Martyr of Golgotha: Traditions of the Orient), 1863. Joaquin Tuason’s Ang Malacas na Samson na Nagligtas sa manga Israelitas sa Caalipinan sa manga Filisteo (The Strong Samson Who Saved the Israelites from Slavery under the Philistines), 1879, is a retelling of the life of Samson.

Translation of prose narratives of the religious sort did not cease to be made after the Spanish period. In the 20th century, Epifanio Alfafara translated Jose Palles’s La Pasion del Redentor into Cebuano as Kasakitan sa Manunubos (The Sufferings of the Redeemer), and Elpidio Fegi translated Martir sa Golgota from Tagalog into Cebuano. Although they were not consciously translated to proselytize, as the conduct books had been, these translations reinforced the religious—specifically, Catholic—orientation of the local folks.

In translations of poetry, the religious impulse was equally strong, and in the case of the ladino poets, this was coupled with a pedagogic intent. This group of native poets was knowledgeable in both Tagalog and Spanish, and they wrote bilingual verses, which were popular in the 17th century. In their poems, a line in one language would be followed by its equivalent in the other language, one line explaining the other, as in Fernando Bagonbanta’s poem, an excerpt of which goes thus (Lumbera 1986, 240-41):

Salamat nang ualang hangga

gracias se den sempiternas,

sa nagpasilang nang tala

al que hizo salir la estrella;

macapagpanao ang dilim

que destierre las tinieblas

sa lahat na bayan natin

de toda esta nuestra tierra.

 

(Undying gratitude is due

to the one who caused the star to rise

and dissipate the darkness

everywhere in this, our land.)

Poems of this sort were meant to teach Spanish, but because of metrical constraints, the ladino’s translations were not always exact.

Among the most famous ladino were Tomas Pinpin, whose Tagalog translations of Spanish songs were collected in Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila (A Book for the Tagalog to Study the Spanish Language), 1610, and Fernando Bagongbanta, whose Salamat nang Ualang Hangga” (Undying Gratitude) appeared in Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua Tagala, 1605.

The 18th century saw the composition of the pasyon, or verse narratives recounting Christ’s life and sufferings. These were later translated from the Tagalog to other local languages. Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola (Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse), 1704, became the model of other pasyon to come in the different languages in the archipelago. It was translated into Cebuano as Pasion sa Atong Guinoong Jesuchristo (Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ).

A more popular pasyon is Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader), 1814, commonly known as Pasyong Genesis (The Passion of Genesis) or Pasyong Pilapil (The Passion by Pilapil). This pasyon has been translated into Pangasinan as Pasion na Cataoan tin Jesucristo, 1855; into Bikol as Casaysayan can Mahal na Pasion ni Jesucristo Cagurangnanta, 1867; into Kapampangan as Bienang Queralandalanan ning Guinutang Jesucristo, 1876; into Ilocano as Biag da Apotayo Jesu, Maria quen Jose, 1889; and into Ilonggo as Quinabuhi cag Pasion ni Jesucristo nga Aton Guinoo, 1892.

Although the bulk of the prose and poetry translated during the Spanish period was religious, translations of secular prose also existed and flourished during the 19th century. An emergent Filipino middle class created a demand for translations of such works, and opportunities for publishing were opening up with the establishment of commercial printing presses in Manila, such as the Imprenta de Amigos de Pais, then available to the wealthy, literate members of the middle class.

In the 1800s, translation of secular prose narratives works slowly caught up with translations of religious materials. Such were Jose Rizal’s translation of five of Hans Christian Andersen’s stories for children and Hermenegildo Flores’s translation of Antonio de Trueba’s El Angel y el Diablo into Filipino as Ang Anghel at ang Diablo (The Angel and the Devil), 1882, which appeared in Diariong Tagalog.

In poetry, side by side with the pedagogical and religious translations made by the ladino were translations of metrical romances: the awit and the korido. Although they indirectly espoused religious values, especially in their depiction of conflicts between Muslims and Christians, metrical romances were more escapist than edifying. European romances had been translated into local languages by Spanish missionaries as early as the late 1500s. Later, local writers translated and adapted such romances as the Charlemagne cycles, the Arthurian cycles, and the myths of Greece, often localizing them.

Examples of the awit and korido are Salita at Buhay ng Doce Pares sa Francia (Story and Life of the Twelve Pairs of France), a retelling of Historia del Emperador Carlo Magno (History of Emperor Charlemagne); Jose de la Cruz’s Ang Walang Pagkupas na Kasaysayan ni Bernardo Carpio (The Unfading Story of Bernardo Carpio), which combines episodes from Las Mocedades de Bernardo del Carpio, a play by Lope de Vega, and the Primera Cronica General; and Salita at Buhay ni Roberto el Diablo Anac nang Duque de Normandia at sa Huli Tinauag na Tauo nang Dios (Story and Life of Robert the Devil, Son of the Duke of Normandy and Later Called the Man of God), an adaptation of La Espantosa y Maravillosa Vida de Roberto el Diablo.

Whereas the translation of religious writings might have served a colonialist purpose, the translation of secular prose often had an opposite function. The rise of translations of nationalistic works in the 1800s paralleled the growing sense of discontent with Spanish rule. Wealthy Filipinos, educated in Europe and exposed to liberal ideas, clamored for reforms; poor Filipinos, weary of oppression, were calling for revolution.

Discursive writings that helped to animate the nationalist spirit include Jose Rizal’s translation of The Rights of Man, 1789, into Tagalog as Ang mga Karapatan ng Tao, 1891, which circulated in Manila in pamphlet form; and Marcelo H. del Pilar’s translation of Rizal’s essay “El Amor Patrio” (Patriotism) into Tagalog, which appeared together with the original Spanish text in Diariong Tagalog on 22 Aug 1882.

The pasyon itself, in one instance at least, became possessed by the revolutionary spirit. Hitherto used for edification, it became a site for propaganda when Marcelo H. del Pilar adapted the Pasyong Genesis into “Pasyong Dapat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Tauong Baba sa Kalupitan nang Fraile” (Passion That Should Inflame the Heart of the Person Who Suffers the Cruelty of the Friars), 1888. It was an attack on the Spanish clergy in the country.

 

The American Colonial Period and the Japanese Occupation

During the American colonial period, translation driven by nationalism continued. Apolinario Mabini’s El Verdadero Decalogo (The True Decalogue) was translated into Tagalog as Ang Sampung Aral ni Mabini (The Decalogue of Mabini), 1921, by Albino Dimayuga from the Spanish. Teodoro M. Kalaw translated his own memoirs titled La Revolucion Filipina from Spanish to English as The Philippine Revolution, 1925, which Virgilio S. Almario would later translate into Filipino as Ang Himagsikang Filipino, 1989.

Rizal was an obvious instrument of nationalism, his works periodically translated throughout the 20th century and beyond. Enjoying the most popularity with translators of Philippine poems is his “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell). Andres Bonifacio translated the poem into Tagalog in 1896 as “Pahimakas” (Farewell). It was later translated into Tagalog by Iñigo Ed. Regalado as “Ang Aking Pahimakas” (My Farewell), 1911; other Tagalog translations are by Julian Cruz Balmaseda, by Jose Sevilla, by Jose Gatmaitan, and by Vicente de Jesus. Mariano Proceso Byron Pabalan translated it into Kapampangan, and at least 15 Cebuano versions of the same poem exist. “Mi Ultimo Adios” has also been rendered into Ilonggo, Aklanon, Gaddang, Maguindanao, and Ilocano. English translations have been made by Charles Derbyshire and Nick Joaquin. Versions of the poem in Indonesian, Malaysian, Chinese, Japanese, and Bengali exist, as do translations in French, German, Italian, Hungarian, Swedish, and Latin.

Almost as popular among translators, and eventually used as a weapon against Americanism, is Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas. His farce La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante (The Elegant Native Woman and Her Aeta Suitor), ca. 1860, has an Ilocano translation by Efraim Fa. Ordinaria, published in Ilocos Times. Balagtas is better known, however, for Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1838, a metrical romance often interpreted as an allegory of national struggle. It has been repeatedly translated into Pangasinan and Ilocano. A Kapampangan version was done by Francisco Xavier Panlilio; a Cebuano version, by Adela del Rosario; a Bikol version, by Pelagio Guamil; and an Ibanag version, by Buenaventura Mirafuente. Balagtas’s romance was novelized by P. R. Villanueva in 1949.

Translations of Florante at Laura into foreign languages have also been made. Epifanio de los Santos and Felix Ferrer, on separate occasions, translated it into Spanish. Jose Rizal, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Rafael Palma, and Manuel Bernabe all did versions of the romance in Spanish. English translations were made by George St. Clair, Arsenia Yap, Adela E. del Rosario, and, as collaborators, Jose P. Villarica and Marcela Dayao Villarica. Rizal made a German version of Florante at Laura, as did Pablo Laslo and Otto von Scheerer. Madame Angela de la Cantera wrote a French version.

Balagtas’s works would be influential in the development of Philippine literature, especially the novel, which would follow them in using courtly love and complicated family relations or in depicting themes of good versus evil through allegorical characters. More importantly, however, the Balagtas tradition became a disguised mouthpiece against Americanization in the first two decades of the 20th century. The Balagtas poets’ reaffirmation of the traditions of Christianity and the spirit of the propaganda and revolutionary movements was to them a patriotic stance. Jose Corazon de Jesus’s Sa Dakong Silangan (In the East), 1928, is an example of anti-Americanism in the form of a romance.

In fiction, the choice of what was translated or adapted also hinted at nationalist inspiration. Among the authors frequently translated or adapted were 19th-century European writers Victor Hugo, Leo Tolstoy, and Alexandre Dumas, père and fils, whose works reveal social and political dimensions. Writers like Aurea Jimenez Santiago, Gerardo Chanco, and Narciso Asistio, who read the European writers in Spanish translation, made them available to the Filipinos in the local languages.

Hugo’s works, which were laced with flowery images and melodramatic hyperboles, clearly exhibited his love of liberty and sympathy with the common folk. They were thus compatible with the nationalist spirit of the time. Benigno Ramos’s Ang Anak ng Kalayaan (Freedom’s Offspring), 1926, is a translation of one of Hugo’s plays. Gerardo Chanco translated Les Miserables, a novel about the wretched classes in French society, into Sakit ng Sangkatauhan (Sickness of the Human Race), 1921-23, as did Aurea Jimenez Santiago, who titled her translation Si Jean Valjean, o, Ang mga Labi (Jean Valjean or the Dregs), 1952. Santiago also translated The Hunchback of Notre Dame as Ang Kuba sa Notre Dame, 1952.

Tolstoy, known for his altruism, his belief in liberalism, and his use of realism, was another favorite among Filipino translators. His masterpiece Anna Karenina was adapted by Narciso Asistio into Natapos Na ang Lahat (Everything is Ended), 1930, and What Men Live By was translated as Sa Ano Nabubuhay ang Tao, 1919, by Sofronio Calderon.

The Dumases, like Hugo, were known for their melodramas, but their works were nonetheless a favorite among reformists, such as Jose Rizal. Aurea Jimenez Santiago translated The Count of Monte Cristo as Ang Konde ng Monte Cristo in 1952. Another work, Amaury, was translated by Gerardo Chanco in 1919 as Amaury, o, Pumapatay at Bumubuhay (Amaury or One Who Kills and Brings to Life).

Rizal’s two novels enjoyed a number of translations throughout the American colonial period. Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, was translated into Tagalog by Sofronio Calderon in 1906, by Pascual Poblete in 1909, by Patricio Mariano in 1912, and by Pedro Gatmaitan in 1926 (Testa de Ocampo 2011, 521); into Kapampangan by Pedro Manike in 1933; and into English by Charles Derbyshire, who gave it the title Social Cancer, 1912, and by Feliciano Basa and Francisco Benitez in 1933. There were also translations into Ilonggo and Ilocano and incomplete translations in other Philippine languages. El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891, was translated by Tomas Alonso into Cebuano in 1911, by Charles Derbyshire into English as The Reign of Greed in 1912, by Pedro Gatmaitan into Tagalog in 1926, and by Santiago Fonacier into Ilocano in 1935.

 

The education system established by the American colonial government acquainted many local writers with the masters of Western fiction. Filipino writers translated Western short stories that were not originally in English through reading English or Spanish translations. “The Tell-Tale Heart” by Edgar Allan Poe, from whom Filipino fictionists learned “unity of effect” and the classic dramatic arc, was translated by Pascual de Leon as “Pusong Mapagsuplong,” 1914, and by Teodoro Agoncillo’s as “Pitlag ng Puso,” 1937.

Other translations of Western short stories during this time include “Ang Tatlong Pag-ibig” (The Three Loves), 1904, Gonzalo G. M. Adriano’s translation of a Russian story by Maria Krysinla; “Noon ay Pasko” (Once It Was Christmas), 1910, Sofronio Calderon’s translation of a French story; “Zorahayda,” 1913, Deogracias A. Rosario’s translation of Washington Irving’s “The Rose of Alhambra”; “Ang Wastong Pag-ibig” (The Right Love), 1919, S. D. Crisostomo’s adaptation of the story “No Danger to a Girl like This” by Harvey S. McGowan; “Kung Magnakaw ang Patay” (When the Dead Steal), 1921, Roberto S. Teodoro’s translation of a detective story of A. Conan Doyle; “Ang Impierno’y Muling Itinayo ng Simbahan” (Hell Was Rebuilt by the Church), 1922, a translation by Huling Lingap (pseud.) of Leo Tolstoy’s story; “Ang Kwintas” (The Necklace), 1929, Baltazar Villanueva’s translation of Guy de Maupassant’s “The Necklace”; “Isang Isdang Kapok” (The Cotton Fish), 1931, S. D. Crisostomo’s translation of W. Somerset Maugham’s “The Human Element”; “Ang Kamay ng Tadhana” (The Hand of Fate), 1936, N. S. Asistio’s translation of Mark Hellinger’s short story; and “Maria Concepcion,” Arturo Valencia’s translation of Katherine Anne Porter’s story with the same title.

Translations of longer works include Ang Diwa ng Pasko (The Christmas Spirit), 1932, Jacinto R. de Leon’s translation of Charles Dickens’s A Christmas Carol; Nang Mabuhay ang Patay (When the Dead Lived Again) by Francisco Laksamana, from Emile Zola’s novelette; Pulo ng Hiwaga (Island of Mystery) by Arsenio R. Afan, from Jonathan Swift’s Gulliver’s Travels; Aurelio Tolentino’s Saan Ka Paparoon? (Where Do You Go?), 1915, from Henryk Sienkciewicz’s Quo Vadis, and Ang Konde ng Monte Kristo from Alexandre Dumas's The Count of Monte Cristo.

Nationalistic or instructional reasons aside, there were also translations that appear to be simply for entertainment. These works usually revolved around love and romance. Spanish novels were among the favorite sources of such translators as Rosendo Ignacio and Rosalia Aguinaldo. Ignacio translated Los Amantes de Teruel (Lovers of Teruel) as Ang Martir na Pag-ibig (The Martyr to Love), 1923; and M. Ibo Alfaro’s Vivir es Amor (To Live is to Love) as Ang Buhay Ay Pag-ibig (Life is Love), 1918.

Other examples of translations of this sort include Ang Pag-ibig na May Piring (Blindfolded Love), 1929, by Rosalia Aguinaldo based on Salvador Farina’s Amor Vendado (Peddler’s Love); “Huling Tanda ng Pag-ibig” (Last Sign of Love), 1920, by Leonardo Dianzon, based on a short story by Jesus Balmori.

In the 1930s, commercialism was to direct the production of many translations. This orientation was reinforced by Liwayway magazine and its sister publications Bisaya, Bannawag, and Hiligaynon. These published novels, stories, and poems revolving around love, betrayal, filial piety, and suffering. Foreign works translated or adapted into the local languages include those by Alexandre Dumas, Lew Wallace, Rafael Sabatini, Charles Dickens, and Victor Hugo, whose sprawling works met the public demand for serialized fiction containing much sentiment and plot convolutions.

Charles Dickens’s David Copperfield was translated by Flaviano Boquecosa into Cebuano as Si David, ang Ilo (David the Pitiful), 1935-36. The novel would influence Boquecosa’s own output, especially his two novels: Ang Palad ni Pepe (The Fate of Pepe), 1937, and Ang Anak ni Pepe (The Child of Pepe), 1939. Boquecosa also translated Jane Eyre, 1947-48, and Anna Karenina, 1949-51. Dumas’s Camille was translated by Gerardo Chanco as Sa Gitna ng Lusak, 1918, and adapted by Ruperto S. Cristobal as Ang Bulaklak sa Kabaret (The Flower in the Cabaret), 1920. Local novelists, such as Fausto Galauran, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, and Rosauro Almario, would draw from the Camille character. Their novels in turn would be translated into other local languages and serialized in magazines. Examples include Ang Hatol ng Langit (Heaven’s Judgment) and Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God).

Catering to the readers’ taste for love stories and bildungsroman, the magazines in the different local languages serialized Tagalog novels in translation. Translated into Cebuano were Nemesio Caravana’s Sanlibong Pisong Kagandahan (Thousand-Peso Beauty) and Bagong Manunubos (New Redeemer); Lazaro Francisco’s Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1935-36, Pamana ng Isang Pulubi (Legacy of a Beggar), 1936-37, and Singsing na Pangkasal (Wedding Ring), 1939-40; Fausto Galauran’s Lihim ng Kumpisalan (Secret of the Confessional), 1939; and Adriano P. Laudico’s Si Pamela: Ang Mutya ng Palengke (Pamela: The Muse of the Market).

The rise of the cinema further encouraged the translation of works for entertainment. Many works of adventure, suspense, and romance were translated and adapted. Some of the most famous ones include Flaviano Boquecosa’s translations of Edgar Rice Burroughs’s Tarzan series, made between 1933 and 1934: Tarzan: Ang Tawong Unggoy (Tarzan: The Ape Man), Ang Pagbabalik ni Tarzan (The Return of Tarzan), and Ang mga Mananap ni Tarzan (The Beasts of Tarzan).

In poetry, classic works of Western literature, like the Divine Comedy by Dante and Paradise Lost by John Milton, were translated into the various Philippine languages. Rosendo Ignacio’s prose paraphrase of Divine Comedy was titled Ang Bathalang Dula, 1917. Spanish poems were also translated: Julian Cruz Balmaseda translated Roman de Campoamor’s “Cantares Amorosos” (Amorous Songs) into Tagalog as “Sa Aklat ng Pag-ibig” (In the Book of Love), 1915; and Jose Palma’s “Mi Caida” (My Downfall) as “Pagkasawi Ko” (When I Die), 1915.

English Romantic poets, such as John Keats, Lord Byron, and Percy Bysshe Shelley, were often translated, especially by the balagtasista, or followers of Balagtas, such as Gerardo Chanco. Manuel Aguinaldo translated Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s “Footsteps of Angels”; Benigno Ramos’s “Isang Tula ni Mutsihito” (A Poem of Mutsihito), 1911, is a translation of a poem by Emperor Mutsihito of Japan; Benigno Ramos’s “Ipagsakdal” (Accuse), 1920, is from a stanza of one of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s poems. Maria Caballero’s “Talinghaga ng Pag-ibig” (Metaphor of Love), 1923, is from Percy Bysshe Shelley’s “Love’s Philosophy.”

Meanwhile, the Pasyong Pilapil was translated into other local languages during the first half of the 20th century. Pascual M. Diaz translated the pasyon into Waray in 1916 as Casayuran nang Pasion nga Mahal ni Jesuchristo nga Guenoo Naton, and Jacinto Bernal translated it into Samal in 1916 as Pasion nan Catauan tamon Jesucristo sa Salita Sambali. An Ibanag translation appeared in 1948, titled Pasion nay Yatufam a Jesucristo Aquimallo tan Dios.

During the Japanese occupation of the Philippines, the Japanese government used translation to obtain the support of the Filipinos against the United States and to promote Japanese interests. Essays extolling Japanese benevolence and promising independence to the Philippines in the near future were rendered into the local languages or into English. Examples include Premier Tozjo’s Visit Brings the Philippines Closer to Independence, 1943, and Peace and Freedom, translated into English, Filipino, Cebuano, Ilonggo, Tagalog, and Bikol. One Nation, One Heart, One Republic, 1943, by Jose Laurel, was likewise translated into Ilocano, Tagalog, Bikol, Spanish, Waray, and Cebuano.

Books translated from the Japanese into English and Tagalog were The Flowering of the Racial Spirit, 1942, translated by Kazi-o Nisina; Kautusang Panloob ng mga Manggagawa sa Arsenal (Internal Rules for the Workers of the Arsenal) and Nippon at Bushido (Nippon and Bushido), 1943, translated by Gen Artemio Ricarte. A book that helped propagate the Japanese language was Mga Salitaan sa Nippongo ukol sa mga Filipino (Conversations in Nippongo about the Filipinos) by Swadi Kiyoshi, which featured typical conversations in Japanese for various occasions, with Tagalog translations.

Newspapers and magazines produced under Japanese supervision carried propaganda and, to some extent, Nippongo lessons. Some newspapers were La Vanguardia, whose contents were mostly Spanish translations of the news given out in the Tribune; and Panay Times, also known as Panay Shu-ho, published in English and Ilonggo. Shin Seiki, 1942-44, and Ang Kapitbahay, 1944, were magazines that featured articles in English and Tagalog.

A Tagalog translation of the Noli, by Guillermo E. Tolentino, was published in 1944 and titled Huwag Mo Akong Salingin.

 

After World War II

Rizal continued to be translated after World War II. Three Tagalog translations of the Noli appeared in 1950: by Bartolome del Valle and Benigno Zamora; by Dionisio S. Salazar; and by Maria Odulio de Guzman, Domingo D. de Guzman, and Francisco Laksamana. At least two more Tagalog translations—one by Leonardo A. Dianzon, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, and Dionisio San Agustin, 1956, and another by Felisa de la Paz and Carmen B. Mallari, 1970—were made before the declaration of martial law (Testa-de Ocampo 2011, 522). Lourdes Bengson Ungson translated it into Pangasinan as Agmoak Didiwiten in 1958. Camilo Osias in 1956, Jorge Bocobo in 1956, Priscilla Valencia in 1967, and Jovita Ventura in 1989 rendered the novel into English; but among the English translations, the most popular is The Lost Eden, 1961, by Leon Ma. Guerrero. Madeline Lao Lim and She Fen, on separate occasions, translated the novel into Chinese. German and Japanese versions of the novel also exist.

Rosendo Ignacio translated the novel El Filibusterismo into Tagalog as Ang Pagsusuwail (The Rebellion), 1958; and Lourdes Bengson Ungson translated it into Pangasinan as Say Isusungpad Uley, 1964. Translations into Ilonggo, Ilocano, and Cebuano have also been made. English translations of El Filibusterismo from this period include Greed, 1951, by A. A. Tablan and A. T. Veloro, and The Subversive, 1965, by Leon Ma. Guerrero. Henry Yeh made a Chinese translation of the novel in 1960.

The impact of Rizal’s two novels can be seen in the numerous adaptations made from them. Novels, from Florentino Suico’s Puthaw ug Dugo (Iron and Blood), 1931, to the underground Hulagpos (Breaking Free), 1980, by Mana de Verdades Posadas (pseud.), contain motifs found in Rizal’s works, as does the contemporary short story “Ang Pinakahuling Kuwento ni Huli” (The Final Story of Huli), 1989, by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago.

Apart from Rizal, prose narratives continued to be translated after American rule and World War II. The campus paper Dawn published Rogelio Mangahas’s translation of La Forma de la Espada by Jorge Luis Borges and Der Dichter by Herman Hesse.

Translations of foreign short prose narratives were published as an appendix to manuals in short story writing, such as Ang Sining ng Maikling Kwento (The Art of the Short Story), 1957, by Mariano C. Pascual, which contains 10 short stories. In 1967, Andres Cristobal Cruz made a collection of German fiction translated into Filipino, titled Paghahanap at Iba Pang Kwentong Aleman (Searching and Other German Stories), 1967. The book in turn was translated into Ilocano as Napili a Sarita Dagiti Aleman (Selected Stories from German), 1970, by Juan S. P. Hidalgo. Talaarawan ng Isang Baliw (Diary of a Madman) and Ang Pulang Lampara (The Red Lamp), both bearing a similar ideological slant, are translations from Lu Xun (Lu Hsun) and Mao Tse-tung, respectively. Lilia F. Antonio translated The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupery into Ang Munting Prinsipe, 1969.

Apart from novels and short stories, folktales were another form of prose narrative continually translated. Before the establishment of the New Republic in 1946, Rizal had retold the legend of Mariang Makiling and the fable of the monkey and the turtle, Dean Fansler had collected his students’ retellings of Philippine folktales in Filipino Popular Tales, 1921, and one of Fansler’s students, Lim Sian Tek, had introduced Chinese folktales in Folk Tales from China, 1926, and More Folk Tales from China, 1944.

Now in the 1950s, Maximo Ramos published retellings of Philippine folklore in these books: Tales of Long Ago in the Philippines, 1953; Philippine Myths and Tales for Young Readers, 1957; Creatures of Midnight, 1967; and Creatures of Philippine Lower Mythology, 1971. These books and other similar titles by Ramos would be republished in 1990 as a set titled Realms of Myths and Reality. Aesop’s fables were adapted by Bartolome del Valle in Isinatulang mga Pabula ni Esopo (The Fables of Aesop Rendered in Verse), 1974. Romance in Philippine Names, 1979, contains retellings of native stories on the origins of place names.

Samples of Philippine folklore were further translated in the 1980s in such books as A Treasury of Mandaya and Mansaka Folk Literature, 1980, which gathers the riddles, proverbs, songs, and tales from the Mindanao area and renders them in English; Cordillera Tales, 1989, by Luisa Igloria (then writing as Maria Luisa B. Aguilar-Cariño), which retells stories from the Mountain Province; and Mga Ginto sa Iloilo (Gold Nuggets in Iloilo), 1990, by Felicisima Torres-Campos, which renders tales from Ilonggo into Filipino. Susie L. Tan’s two volumes of Tales for Big Children, 1995, retell Chinese and Filipino folk literature.

In poetry, Jose Villa Panganiban made Japanese poetry accessible by translating a sample in Tanaga, Haiku, Pantun, 1963. About two decades earlier, Emilio Aguinaldo had translated haikus in El Renacimiento. The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam was translated into Filipino by Ildefonso Santos in 1952, based on Edward Fitzgerald’s English version, and by Rufino Alejandro in 1972. During the 1950s, the works of some Filipino poets, including Jose Garcia Villa and Jose Corazon de Jesus, were rendered into Chinese in Wénlián Zázhì (Literary Art Magazine) by members of the Philippine-Chinese Literary Workers’ Union.

Translations of foreign poems found their way into the collections of well-known poets, such as Amado V. Hernandez’s Isang Dipang Langit (A Stretch of Sky), 1961. The leading translator of this period, however, was the trilingual Federico Licsi Espino Jr, whose works include Sa Paanan ng Parnaso (At the Foot of Parnassus), 1965, and Toreng Bato, Kastilyong Pawid (Stone Tower, Castle of Palm Leaves), 1966. Licsi Espino translated poets from England, America, Poland, Russia, and Czechoslovakia in Kudyaping Banyaga (Foreign Lyre), 1966, with Rufino Alejandro; Balalayka ni Pasternak (Balalaika of Pasternak), 1967; and Makabagong Panulaan (Modern Poetry), 1974. Espino also translated his own Spanish poems into English in Bird in the Lyric Cage, 1970.

The works of the modernist poets such as T. S. Eliot, Arthur Rimbaud, Charles Baudelaire, Ezra Pound, Federico Garcia Lorca, Salvatore Quasimodo, Wallace Stevens, Robert Frost, and Pablo Neruda were popular among translators in Philippine colleges. Most of these translations appeared in campus journals and newspapers. Rogelio Mangahas, Virgilio S. Almario, and Licsi Espino were among the most active translators. Bienvenido Lumbera made a Filipino translation of T. S. Eliot’s “The Waste Land.”

However, the modernists were not the only poets translated. Translation production increased markedly during the martial law era in the 1970s, spurred by protests of nationalist and anti-imperialist movements against the dictator. The turbulent times of the Marcos years (1965-86) produced Kamao (Fist), 1971, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson, a collection of protest poems by Mao Tse-tung, Bertolt Brecht, Che Guevarra, Pablo Neruda, Otto Rene Castillo, and other progressive poets, translated from English into Filipino. An interest in Third World literature is indicated by the Filipino translations of Licsi Espino’s Mga Tulang Afro-Asyatiko (Afro-Asian Poems), 1975, and Ang Panulaan ng Afrika at Timog-Silangang Asya (The Poetry of Africa and Southeast Asia), 1981, with co-translator Paula Espino.

 

Just as Marcelo H. del Pilar had adapted the pasyon to expose the abuses of friars, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo adapted the pasyon to criticize martial law in Pasyon sa Kamatayan ng Ating Kalayaan (Passion on the Death of Our Freedom), 1975.

Translations of prose works aimed at heightening the political consciousness of the Filipinos continued to be produced in the 1970s. Among such works were Edukasyong Mapagpalaya (A Liberating Education), a chapter from Paolo Freire’s Pedagogy of the Oppressed; Mga Talumpati sa Palitang-Kuro sa Yenan tungkol sa Panitikan at Sining (Talks at the Yenan Forum on Literature and Art) by Mao Tse-tung; and Ang Teolohiya ng Pagpapalaya (The Theology of Liberation) by Hugo Assman. La Solidaridad, the newspaper of the reform movement, was compiled in a two-volume, bilingual edition (Spanish and English) by Guadalupe Fores-Ganzon in 1967 and 1973.

The 1980s saw Solar Publishing Corporation producing a series of translated and abridged versions of classics: Kapag Bigo Na ang Lahat (When Everything Has Failed), 1985, of Jane Eyre; Halik sa Lupa (A Kiss on the Earth), 1987, of Lady Chatterley’s Lover; Ang Titik na Pula, 1990, of The Scarlet Letter; Sa Pagitan ng Langit (Amid the Heavens), 1985, of Silas Marner; Kay Lapit, Kay Layo ng Ligaya (How Elusive is Bliss), 1992, of Wuthering Heights; and Majella, 1992, of Ramona.

Conversely, translations of local novels into foreign languages have been done. Celso Carunungan’s novel Satanas sa Lupa (Satan on Earth) was translated into Chinese and serialized in 1989 in World News, a Chinese daily. P. B. Lataquin’s Ilonggo novel Pagsalig sang Babai (A Woman’s Faith), was translated into Spanish as La Fe de la Mujer by the author.

English translations of Philippine literature in Spanish were published in the 1980s: Pilar Mariño’s Philippine Stories in Spanish, 1989, is a bilingual edition of the stories of Cecilio Apostol, Rafael Palma, Manuel Guerrero, Jesus Balmori, Antonio M. Abad, Manuel Bernabe, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, and others. Cuentos de Balmori (Balmori’s Stories), 1987, also by Mariño, is a bilingual edition of selected stories by Jesus Balmori.

Similar bilingual editions are 55 Poems , 1988, Hilario Francia’s translation of Jose Garcia Villa’s English poems into Filipino; Rio Alma: Selected Poems 1968-1985, 1987, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga’s translations of the poems of Virgilio S. Almario from Filipino into English; and The Birthing of Hannibal Valdez, 1984, Salanga’s novella, which comes with Romulo Sandoval’s Tagalog translation.

As the 1980s drew to a close, the literary journal Mithi published an issue devoted to translations, titled “Makabagong Tinig ng Siglo” (New Voice of the Century), 1989, which includes translations of the prose works of Chinua Achebe, William Saroyan, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and Salman Rushdie and of the poetry by Archibald MacLeish, Erica Jong, T. S. Eliot, William Carlos Williams, Wallace Stevens, and others, by Rolando Tinio, Teo T. Antonio, Virgilio S. Almario, and Mike Bigornia.

In Sa Daigdig ng Kontradiksiyon (In the World of Contradictions), 1991, Jose Lacaba translates poetry from Europe, the Americas, and Asia, as well as from the Philippines.

The years immediately after the fall of the Marcos government saw two developments that fostered translation activity driven by nationalism, which sought the creation of a national language based on the languages of the Philippines culture and the retrieval of Philippine literatures and cultures so they could be recycled into a national literature and culture. The first was the launch of the Panitikan series in 1986 by a consortium of the University of the Philippines Press, the Ateneo de Manila University Press, and the De La Salle University Press. The second was the alignment of cultural institutions in promoting regional literature.

The Panitikan series made Philippine works in the different local languages available to modern readers. Works written in local languages were reprinted in the original with an accompanying translation into English or Filipino or both. The primary purpose for the Panitikan series was to translate works from various regional literatures into Filipino so these would become part of a national literature. The series was sustained till the 1990s. A total of 36 works from the various regional languages were translated into Filipino, among which were Zoilo Galang’s Kapampangan novel Ing Capalaran (Fate), 1923, translated by Lourdes H. Vidal in 1992; Marcel Navarra’s Cebuano short stories, translated into English and Filipino by Teresita Gimenez-Maceda in 1986; and several short stories in Ilonggo collected in Sugilanon (Tales), 1990, translated into Filipino by Rosario Cruz-Lucero; Maikling Kuwentong Kapampangan at Pangasinan (Kapampangan and Pangasinan Short Stories), 1996, edited by Lourdes H. Vidal and Ma. Crisanta S. Nelmida-Flores; Siday: Mga Tulang Bayan ng Panay at Negros (Siday: Folk Poetry of Panay and Negros), 1997, edited by Corazon D. Villareal; and Kudaman: Isang Epikong Palawan na Inawit ni Usuy (Kudaman: A Palawan Epic Sung by Usuy), 1992, by Edgar B. Maranan and Nicole Revel-Macdonald.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) established the journal Ani in 1987, which was originally intended to be a venue for contemporary writings. It devoted issues to regional literature with translations of the works: Cebuano in 1987, Ilocano in 1988, and Hiligaynon in 1989. In the 1990s, the practice continued, with literature from Samar, Mindanao, Cordillera, Bikol, Pangasinan, and Aklan. Apart from Ani, the CCP published Handurawan (Ideals), 1990, a trilingual anthology of poems by winners of the CCP literature grants for poetry, 1988-89.

Outside of these institutions, there were other efforts, individual or institutional, to translate regional literature. Cebuano poetry has been made available to non-Cebuano speakers by Resil Mojares, E. K. Alburo, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Vicente Bandillo in Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak: Until 1940, and Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak: 1940-1988, both in 1988. These books would be supplemented 30 years later with the publication of Cebuano Fiction / Sugilanong Sugboanon: Until 1940 and Cebuano Fiction / Sugilanong Sugboanon: 1941-2005, 2009, both books the product of the same team behind Cebuano Poetry. Kapampangan literature was translated in at least three volumes: Kapampangan Literature: A Historical Survey and Anthology, 1981, edited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Literature of the Pampangos, 1981, edited by Rosalina Ichban-Castro; and Kapampangan Writing: A Selected Compendium and Critique, 1984, by Evangelina Hilario-Lacson.

Mamitua Saber and Sr Delia Coronel, ICM, supervised the multivolume translation of the Maranao epic Darangen, 1983-86. The Committee on Culture and Information of the ASEAN produced Epics of the Philippines, 1984, which contains five Philippine epics in English translation—Aliguyon, Lam-ang, Labaw Donggon, Agyu, and Sandayo—and Philippine Metrical Romances, 1985, with translations of Bernardo Carpio, Juan Teñoso, Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Florante at Laura, and Abdulla and Patli Isara.

A third development may be mentioned. The Solidarity Translation Series, funded by the Toyota Foundation and published by the Solidarity Publishing House, was begun in 1987. While institutional efforts to translate works in the Philippine local languages into Filipino to develop a national language and literature were vigorous, the translation of Asian literature was limited in comparison. The Solidarity Translation Series rendered Japanese and Southeast Asian titles into Filipino. The source texts were mostly English translations of Southeast Asian works, although a number of translators worked directly with the foreign language texts.

The series came up with 63 titles between 1987 and 1994 (Zafra 2004). Among these are Si Taw at Iba Pang Kuwentong Thai (Taw and Other Thai Stories), 1988, translated from an English translation by Lualhati Bautista; Oe Kenzaburo’s Isang Personal na Bagay (A Personal Matter), a translation into Filipino by Rogelio Mangahas of John Nathan’s translation in English from the original Japanese Kojinteki na Taiken, 1992; Mga Kuwentong Bayan mula sa Vietnam (Folktales from Vietnam), 1992, translated from English into Filipino by Fanny Garcia; Pramoedya Ananta Toer’s This Earth of Mankind, translated by Thelma Kintanar from the original Bahasa Indonesia into Ang Daigdig ng Tao, 1992; and Yasunari Kawabata’s Snow Country, translated by Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat into Lupain ng Taglamig, 1991, from Edward G. Seidensticker’s English translation.

 

From the 1990s to the Present

The work of translating Asian literature continued in the 1990s. An important translation is Mario Miclat’s Taong Yungib ng Peking (The Peking Man), 1999, a translation into Filipino of Cao Yu’s play. Most translations of foreign works in the Philippines are sourced from the English translations of foreign texts, but Miclat worked from the original Chinese. The book is also one of the few individual efforts at translating works from Asia. Joaquin Sy has translated a number of works written in Chinese, including Bai Ren’s novel, rendered as Lagalag sa Nanyang (Adrift in the Southern Sea), 2007.

Initiatives also came from the Committee on Culture and Information of ASEAN. This was part of the goal of the overall ASEAN COCI to publish translations of classic texts and key modern texts in English and in the national language of each participating country. Other than the translations of epics and metrical romances in the Philippines mentioned earlier, another title is Romulo P. Baquiran Jr’s ASEANO: An Anthology of Poems from Southeast Asia, 1995.

Religion remains a driving force but it is no longer as pervasive. It is confined largely to the translation of the Bible in different languages by the Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL) and the Philippine Bible Society. Translations have also been a necessary component of studies on religion and culture, and critical assessments of these in the postcolonial period. Among these is the pathbreaking study Contracting Colonialism: Christian Conversion in Tagalog Society under Early Spanish Rule, 1988, by Vicente Rafael; Alcina’s Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas (History of the Islands and Indios of Visayas) of 1668, translated into English in 2002 by Cantius J. Kobak and Lucio Gutierrez; and the modernized edition of Barlaan at Josaphat by Virgilio S. Almario in 2003.

The tradition of translating revolutionary literature which galvanized the anti-Spanish sentiments in the 19th century continues, the most popular being Rizal’s Noli and El Filibusterismo. There are Soledad Lacson Locsin’s and Ofelia Jamilosa-Silapan’s in English; and Virgilio S. Almario’s and Ligaya Tiamson-Rubin’s in Filipino. Likewise, adaptations are being produced, among them a five-volume adaptation into comics of the two novels by Adam David.

Literature in Spanish continues to be translated: The Other Stories, 1900-1910, 2002, edited by Lourdes Castrillo Brillantes, Patricia Brillantes, and Edgardo Tiamson Mendoza; Jose Montero y Vidal’s Cuentos Filipinos (Philippine Stories), 2004, edited by Renan S. Prado and Lourdes C. Brillantes; Writing Athwart: Adelina Gurrea’s Life and Works / La Escritura Entrecruzada de Adelina Guerra, 2009, edited by Beatriz Alvarez Tardio, which contains translations of selected poems and prose of Gurrea; and Cuentos Hispanofilipinos / Hispano Philippine Stories, 2009, edited by Edmundo Farolan and Paulina Constancia. The Premio Zobel issues Filipino-Spanish classics in bilingual editions. Conversely, Philippine poetry and prose in Spanish translation are being published in Perro Verde, an annual magazine published by the Instituto Cervantes.

Within the second decade of the new millennium, Soledad Reyes translated Tagalog classics into English: Macario Pineda’s The Gold in Makiling, 2012; and Rosario de Guzman Lingat’s What Now, Ricky?, 2013, and The Death of Summer, 2013. Maria Luisa F. Torres’s Sipat Salin / Transfiguration, 2011, is a collection of translations of Torres’s poems into Chinese, German, Bahasa, and other languages.

Two institutions have proved important in promoting translation: the Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, based in the University of the Philippines, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). Established in 1989, the primary concern of the Sentro ng Wikang Filipino is to install Filipino as the medium of instruction, research, publication, and language for official communication in accordance with the Philippine Constitution of 1987. One of its major programs is translation materials production and translator training. In this connection, it publishes a journal called Daluyan, begun in 1996, which has devoted issues to translation and publishes translations, and it has supported and published literature translated into Filipino from the Philippine regional languages such as Selebrasyon at Lamentasyon: Antolohiya ng Maikling Kuwento ng Panay (Celebration and Lamentation: Anthology of Short Stories of Panay), 1989, edited by Carmen L. De los Santos, containing translations by Carmen L. De los Santos, Ma. Milagros G. Lachica, and John E. Barrios.

It has also translated classic foreign texts from English into Filipino. These include Si Alice sa Daigdig ng Diwata, 2000, by Aurora Batnag, based on Lewis Caroll’s Alice in Wonderland; Ang Matanda at ang Dagat, 2000, by Jesus Manuel Santiago, based on Hemingway’s The Old Man and the Sea; and Talulot ng Dugo, 2002, by Romeo G. Dizon, based on Petals of Blood by Ngugi wa Thiong’o.

 

A landmark bibliography on translation published by the Sentro is Apat na Siglo ng Pagsasalin (Four Centuries of Translation), 1999, by Lilia F. Antonio, which covers translation in the Philippines from 1593 to 1998.

Translation projects and publications have been initiated by the NCCA, especially for regional literature. Among these are Tinipigan: An Anthology of Waray Literature (Hidden Treasures: An Anthology of Waray Literature), 1995, edited by Victor Sugbo, consisting of 67 poems, mostly written in 1920-60, by 37 poets; Patubas: An Anthology of West Visayan Poetry: 1986-1994, 1995, edited by Leoncio P. Deriada, containing translations of Karay-a and Aklanon texts; Balsa: Poemas Chabacanos / Chabacano Poems, 2011, poems by Francis Macansantos with English translations; Austrelegina Espina-Moore’s Ang Inahan ni Mila / Mila’s Mother, 2008, a novel in Cebuano translated into English by Hope Sabanpan-Yu; and Temistokles M. Adlawan’s Kay Dili Buta ang Gugma ug Ubang Sugilanon / Because Love is Not Blind and Other Stories, 2012, translated by Merlie Alunan.

The NCCA’s Ubod New Authors Series, launched in cooperation with the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices, publishes single-author collections in the original language with translations of selected works in either English or Filipino. Among the titles are Siso Sakradang ug Iba Pa nga mga Siday han Tagoangkan (Seesaw Up and Down and Other Poems of the Womb), 2010, poems in Waray by Janice Claire Salvacion; Tanang Namilit sa Hangin (All in the Air), 2010, poems in Cebuano by Noel P. Tuazon; and Ini an Sakuyang Hawak asin Iba Pang Bersong Bikol (This is My Body and Other Poems in Bicol), 2010, poems in Bikol by Adrian Remodo.

In the last decade of the 20th century, shifting realities in the national, regional, and the global scenes and the impact of technology and market forces in publishing and mass media have opened new areas for translation. Among these areas are translations of children’s literature and romance novels and best sellers.

The translation of children’s literature has been driven by educational policy to promote the national language, and to implement mother tongue instruction in the initial grades, and likewise by the business prospects of instructional materials development. A pioneering stakeholder has been Adarna House, and in the late 1990s, Lampara Books. Most titles from Adarna are in Filipino, in keeping with its vision of promoting reading and love of country, and propagating the national language, but some titles are bilingual, such as Si Ambongan (Ambongan), Lamberto Antonio’s adaptation into Filipino of Gemma Cruz Araneta’s The Little Hero of Mactan, 2012, with a translation into Cebuano by Erlinda Alburo; Virgilio S. Almario’s Ang Kamatis ni Peles (Peles’s Tomato), 2013, published in Filipino and Cebuano; Kristine Canon’s Bakit Matagal ang Sundo Ko (Why Is the Person Picking Me Up Late?), 2003, published in Filipino and English.

Lampara has created the Easy-to-Learn Books (ETLB) for early academic learners. Most titles come out in two languages, Filipino and English. The texts in both languages are adaptations of Western classics and Filipino myths, legends, and other stories to suit the developmental stage of the readers. Among the adaptations of Western classics are Gulliver’s Travels, Robinson Crusoe, Alice in Wonderland, Beauty and the Beast, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, and Aesop’s Fables. But there are adaptations and illustrated titles for young adults, such as Sense and Sensibility, Kidnapped, The Picture of Dorian Gray, and The Scarlet Letter. Classic legends and myths in the Philippines are retold for today’s young readers. Young adult novels have been translated into Filipino: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone, by Becky Bravo; Charlotte’s Web, by Eugene Evasco; and The Fault in Our Stars, by Danton Remoto.

As the survey has shown, translation has been carried out largely for academic and religious purposes, but an important development in the past few decades is the tie-up between translation and the global book industry, For instance, Lampara titles have been translated into various foreign languages as a result of the company’s efforts to tap the foreign market. It has given Wins Holland the rights to translate ELTB titles into Dutch and Portuguese for the European and Brazilian markets; likewise, it has permitted a Singaporean book distributor to translate some ETLB titles into Mandarin, Malay, Bahasa, and Tamil for the Southeast Asian market. Lampara has also acquired the rights to produce books on popular non-Filipino characters such as Dora the Explorer, Winnie the Pooh, and the superheroes of Marvel comics.

Commercialism was noted with regard to the translation of popular literature in the 1930s. Today, one factor for the commercialization of translation is the demand for romance novels in Tagalog. It is the most widely read book in the country, second only to the Bible (“Survey” 2003). A significant slice of the market is Filipino overseas contract worker sector which has been feminized since the early 2000s.

An offshoot of the market for romance novels in Tagalog is the translation of foreign best sellers. Securing rights from international publishing houses, Precious Pages Corporation has published translations of best sellers such as Twilight, New Moon, some Barbara Cartland titles, the Hunger Games trilogy, Fifty Shades of Grey, among others. Other titles in the pipeline are novels by other best-selling authors such as Danielle Steele, Sidney Sheldon, and Nicholas Sparks.

Literary best sellers have also been translated into Filipino, like The House of Spirits, by Rosario Torres-Yu, and The Alchemist, by Edgar Maranan. A parallel development is the translation of classics into Filipino for an academic readership. This is the target of Anvil Publishing Inc, which has published titles from Shakespeare and Oscar Wilde. This is not as lucrative as the translation of best sellers. Such translations are significant for their contribution to value formation and cultural literacy.

In sum, much translation in the period has been produced with a clear sense of purpose: to develop a truly national language, not just a Tagalog-based Filipino, and to mainstream regional works into a national literature. This is a long, arduous process because of our diverse cultures and languages and the difficulty of agreeing on what the national language should be, what is the canon of national literature, and how to move away from colonial and center-periphery dynamics. For instance, literatures in the local languages translated come mainly from the eight major languages, which were the preferred target ever since the Spanish period. The indigenous cultures must find their place in a national literature through translation, even while some translations have already been published, among which in this period is Carmen Unabia and Victorino Saway’s Tula at Kuwento ng Katutubong Bukidnon (Poetry and Stories of the Native Bukidnon), 1996. A number of publications are valuable retrievals of ethnic literatures; some of these are Manuel Dularawan’s Oral Literature of the Ifugao, 2005; Gerald Rixhon’s Voices from Sulu: A Collection of Taosug Oral Traditions, 2010; Nicole Revel’s Literature of Voice, Epics of the Philippines, 2005; and Yukihiro Yamada’s Ichbayat Folkways, 1995. But these are in English translation, making minimal their contribution to the national language.

Other factors in the last decades have had an impact on the nature and shape of translation production in the country. These are the global economy, the attendant technologies, and a growing consciousness of our Southeast Asian connections, as manifested institutionally in ASEAN initiatives. More than ever, there is need for a vigorous and well-coordinated translation program to keep in step with these changes. Along with such programs must be developed theory and criticism on translation and adaptation grounded in Philippine experience.

Some publications have addressed these concerns: Salin-Suri: Panimulang Pagmamapa ng mga Larangan ng Pag-aaral sa Pagsasalin sa Filipinas (Translation-Analysis: Mapping Out the Field of Translation Studies in the Philippines), 2009, edited by Galileo Zafra; Maria Theresa L. de Villa’s Teorya at Praktika sa Pagsasalin ng “Philippine Society and Revolution” ni Amado Guerrero 1968-1982, 2002; and, with respect to adaptations, Patrick Campos’s “Adaptation Criticism of Screen Rizal as Metacriticism,” 2011, and Joyce Arriola’s “Korido-Komiks to Film: Sourcing, Adapting and Recycling the Bernardo Carpio Story,” 2014. A comprehensive study of Rizal’s Tagalog translation of Schiller’s William Tell is Ramon Guillermo’s Translation and Revolution, distinctive for its use of computer-aided method of analysis and its ideological framework. Apart from the landmark bibliography on translation Apat na Siglo ng Pagsasalin mentioned above, other useful references are Nilo Ocampo’s survey of theses and dissertations in the book Pananaw at Karanasan sa Pagsasalin: Mga Teorya at Lapit, 1992,edited by Ofelia J. Silapan, and two compendiums in which translations are listed: A Bibliography of Philippine Linguistics, 1996, and Bibliography of SIL in the Philippines, 2003.

Still, translation has been largely unexamined, an indication that it continues to be an activity secondary to creative practice and literary scholarship, with most translators remaining invisible. Theory and practice will need to be informed with new paradigms on translation that confront central issues having to do with questions on originality, loss, infidelity, equivalence, neutrality, and source-target relations, and that explore the interdisciplinary connections of translation.  Written by Lilia Antonio, Jonathan Chua, and Galileo Zafra, updated by Corazon Villareal, with notes from Teresita Ang See

article.value: Sections

Spanish Colonial Period
The American Colonial Period and the Japanese Occupation
After World War II
From the 1990s to the Present

Translation is the rendition of a work from one language to another, whereas adaptation is the retelling of a work that does not necessarily involve a change in language. When a work is adapted, it is modified to fit into certain conditions or conventions different from those in which it originally appears. Settings, for example, may be localized; and plots, rearranged, condensed, or extended to appeal to a target audience. Generally, translation is a matter of language; adaptation, of form. Thus, Gerardo Chanco’s Sa Gitna ng Lusak (Wallowing in Mud), 1918, would be a Tagalog translation of the Spanish version of Alexandre Dumas’s Camille, 1882; Cora Ifugo’s Lisa, being made for dance, would be an adaptation.

In the Philippine experience, however, translations and adaptations are not always separate. Ruperto S. Cristobal’s Ang Bulaklak sa Kabaret (The Flower in the Cabaret), 1920, for example, is both a translation into Filipino and, with its Filipinized setting, an adaptation of Dumas’s novel. Moreover, a translation may be more than one step away from its source. For instance, Joaquin Tuason’s Ang Bagong Robinson, Historiang Nagtuturo nang Mabuting Caugalian, na Ginauang Tanungan (The New Robinson, Story That Teaches Good Conduct, Done in Primer Form), 1879, is a Tagalog translation of a Spanish translation of a German adaptation of the English novel Robinson Crusoe, 1719, by Daniel Defoe.

Translation and adaptation are done for various purposes. They may be done to aid proselytizing and moral edification. The Philippine Bible Society, the Translator’s Association of the Philippines, and the Summer Institute of Linguistics, for instance, have translated the Bible into different Philippine languages—Tagalog, Cebuano, Kapampangan, Pangasinan, Waray, Ilonggo, Ilocano, Bikol, and Tboli—to evangelize rural and tribal communities. Bible translation has come hand in hand with literacy projects in which indigenous folklore has been translated or adapted. Other translations or adaptations are done to foster nationalism or spread political propaganda. During the 19th century, translations of revolutionary literature, such as Jose Rizal’s essay “El Amor Patrio” (Love of Country), 1882, helped to spur the local folks to overthrow the Spanish colonial government. The contents of these translations advocate the love of freedom and forward a strong nationalist sentiment. Some translations or adaptations serve to heighten one’s consciousness of other cultures, to explore one’s own culture, and to exhibit it to foreign audiences. Mga Piling Akda buhat sa Panitikang Aleman (Selected Works from German Literature), 1970, by B. S. Medina makes German literature available to non-German readers. Conversely, Hiligaynon Literature: Texts and Contexts, 1992, edited by Lucila Hosillos, and Gaddang Literature, 1984, edited by Ma. Luisa Lumicao-Lora, allow foreign readers to enjoy local literatures. Translation societies pursue the twin tasks of preserving national literature and conscienticizing local and foreign audience by translating works from the different local languages. Translations may also have pedagogical purposes. The translation of children’s literature has been driven by educational policy to promote the national language, and to implement mother tongue instruction in the initial grades, and likewise by the business prospects of instructional materials development. Still other translations or adaptations, especially those of the Western classics during the early decades of American rule, serve as literary models. Local writers received pointers in writing and in experimenting with form. Other translations function primarily to provide entertainment, such as N. B. Bacalso’s translation of Captain Blood and of the comics series Siegfred, and Piux Kabahar’s translation of Bertoldo, Bartolino y Cacaseno (Bertoldo, Bartolino, and Cacaseno) by Giulio Cesare della Croce.
